PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Lawa Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel: the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Newman (from 2,116 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 400 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that many Australians are concerned that the Federal Government is not supporting efforts to introduce a timetable for the elimination of nuclear weapons at the April extension conference of the NPT:

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE COMPLAINTS LEVY BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 May.

PROCTEXT.PARA: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—The committee is considering the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994. When the committee was last considering the bill, Senator Crowley had moved government-Democrat amendment No. 30. The question is that the amendment be agreed to. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —We may need the Minister for Family Services. I asked a question last night and I would like an answer to that question.
—The minister is coming; you may like to repeat the question. I am sure the minister will be able to give us that answer soon.
—If the minister does not remember, I am happy to read the Hansard of yesterday, if that is what you wish me to do, Madam Chair.
—Madam Chair, if Senator Herron would like to ask his question very slowly and thoughtfully, the officers might be able to get into the chamber and then we can assist him.
—Would you like a doctor?
—Thank you very much, Senator Panizza. It is very early in the morning to be so abusive. How about we calm down?

—Madam Chair, I object. There is no abuse from this side of the chamber. We were trying to assist the minister to get her breath back and wait for her advisers to appear. I resent the implication that we are being abusive. As the minister knows, at all times we are trying to assist with legislation and help the government to sort out this scrambled egg of a bill—if I may use that phrase—where 54 amendments were introduced at the last minute, changing the whole complexity of the bill, with a department that is in shambles and does not know what is going on and with the advisers not being able to answer questions. To say that we are being abusive, I find objectionable first thing in the morning.
—This is not first thing in the morning.
—That was the minister's statement; your own minister said `first thing in the morning'.
—Order! Do we have any advisers or not?
—We do not at the moment. Senator Herron might like to proceed and ask the question again.

—Minister, you may recall, without reading the Hansard again, which I do not wish to do, in relation to that last amendment, I put it to you that if the practitioner does not have an agreement with the fund, the level of benefit payable in respect of the services is severely limited in reference to the schedule fee for those services. That is clearly a form of financial coercion on practitioners which could destroy the assumed voluntary nature of purchaser-provider agreements.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, you did not accept that. The advice that you received was that there was no financial coercion if a voluntary agreement was not entered into. The question was: is there an implied financial coercion if there is no agreement between the practitioner and the Health Insurance Association member?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do believe it would be better if we waited until the officers were here. The answer I can give you now is that that understanding is wrong. If there is no agreement of the sort you are describing, then what will happen is what happens now.

—Then why have a purchaser-provider agreement if what is going to happen is what happens now? Senator Crowley, you are saying to me that there is no need for a purchaser-provider agreement. If that is correct, then not only have we had the necessity for agreements between the private hospitals and the insurance associations blown out of the water—because they have done it already while we are still discussing the legislation—but you are saying to me now that it makes no difference; it is going to go on as it does now whether there is a purchaser-provider agreement with medical practitioners or not. Why are we discussing this legislation? In addition to that, the Medicare levy is increased, which automatically puts further pressure on people to go out of private health insurance. Minister, what is the point of this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Herron is well aware that without this legislation it will not be possible for doctors to enter into contracts that mean no gap for patients to pay; in other words, people will have some certainty that, when they are paying for private health insurance, that is the end of it. As you well know, without this legislation it is possible now for contracts to be entered into with hospitals. It has happened in Victoria and it happens in my own state. But the gap is still there for medical expenses, and this is one of a number of things that this bill is doing.

PARA.TAB: If people do not want to insure under those tables, or doctors do not want to participate, that is fine; the existing arrangement stays. This is why some of the lobbying on behalf of the doctors has been so damaging and so misleading. Some doctors are saying on radio that only contracting doctors will be able to work in the private sector, which I find very difficult to come to terms with, considering doctors are a well educated group in the community. Also, some of the lobbying information that has been circulated amongst some of the professions is disgraceful. Doctors have not taken the opportunity to become informed and to talk to people about this legislation but have gone off at tangents trying to convince their profession not to sign contracts, for very spurious reasons. I think some of this has been most unfortunate. If anything, the misinformation is damaging the doctors' patients because it is unnecessarily concerning them. They will have the option to stay where they are now if they wish, but this legislation is giving them an additional choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron, you cannot make sense of this legislation if you keep changing the argument in the course of every question and answer. You asked me what would happen if there were not a purchaser-provider agreement. The answer is: what happens now. Senator Lees has just reinforced that. If you then want to use that and say that there is no need for the legislation, you can do that, but it is not the correct understanding of what the legislation is or of the answer I have given. It is to misrepresent the point in the debate. It is no help to us, and certainly not to you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the budget last night there was an increase in the Medicare levy. We have got a problem with health in Australia; there is no doubt about that. I think there is a lack of understanding of how health legislation impacts on the whole of the community. It is in a mess; there is no doubt about it. I am glad the minister has now got her advisers here so that we can get somewhere with it.

PARA.TAB: The revenue from Medicare increased by something like 5.6 per cent in 1993-94 and the cost of health services rose by some six per cent in 1994-95. The cost to taxpayers is something like $19 billion a year, and only something like $3 billion is collected. I am very concerned about people being tied into agreements, and such is the case for country people. I understand from Australian hospital associations that the legislation will threaten the public hospitals and will do nothing to stop the decline in private health membership. I understood that this legislation was all about reducing that threat.

I can see, from a country person's point of view, that if there is a problem in a country area at a hospital that cannot supply me the services that I require because of some emergency, and then I am taken to Sydney, then when I get to Sydney and I cannot find a hospital that actually has a contract for the same health fund as I am in, I cannot find a doctor who is not tied to the same insurance that I am tied to and I cannot find an anaesthetist who is tied to the same fund that I am tied to, how do I actually get attention? How do I get into that hospital that is going to cater for me? I might find that the hospital, the doctor or the specialist that I have to see in Sydney are not tied to the fund that I am a member of. I would like that part cleared up. I think it pertains to certain parts of this amendment that is being moved at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am advised that if it is an emergency situation that has a patient transferred from a country hospital to a city one then they are covered by the emergency benefit. You would be covered by the emergency benefit arrangements and that should cover the concerns that you raised there, so there would be no particular financial worry in an emergency situation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if it is not an emergency and I am transferred to a place where I will get much better attention, much better health care, than if I were in some out-of-the-way country hospital?

—If the worst came to the worst and the insurance company that you or your hospital—or the hospital you found yourself in in Sydney—were with simply did not cover the situation, then you would at least be protected by the default benefit, the minimum payment. It is a bit unusual to consider, though, that the insurance company you, as a member of rural Australia, have your insurance with did not also have coverage in hospitals in the city but, if it does not, the fall-back position is that you would be protected by the default benefit.

—Going back to the emergency situation, how does Senator Brownhill find out whether the medical practitioner has a purchaser-provider agreement in an emergency situation? He is unconscious, he has a subarachnoid haemorrhage, his relatives are distraught and concerned about his survival; who does he ring up to find out then which doctor to go to?
—Under the legislation the hospital can seek that information from the organisation of which he is a member.

—With respect, we are discussing the medical purchaser-provider agreements under the particular amendment that we are discussing at the moment. I am not talking about the hospital; I am talking about the medical provider under purchaser-provider agreements.
—The organisation is also able to discover whether there is a medical agreement as well.

—Senator Brownhill's doctor rings through to the appropriate neurosurgeon. He rings Dr Bloggs and says, `I am sending this patient down. You are the expert in this particular field of subarachnoid haemorrhages; you are recognised as an authority in this area. I am sending this patient down; would you look after him?' He says, `Yes'. Senator Brownhill's medical attendant rings through to the hospital, but what happens then? Is it a requirement on the neurosurgeon to ring the hospital, to ring Senator Brownhill's doctor? This is the practicality of it about which I suspect you have not got a clue.
—It does depend very much on how this referral comes. Is this patient unconscious? Is this an emergency?
—Yes.
—That is, as I have just explained, covered by the emergency arrangements.
—The emergency arrangements I am asking about are in relation to the medical practitioner—not in relation to the hospital.
—Can I be clear as to what exactly it is you want to know?

—What is the mechanism under this legislation for the legislative requirements on the medical practitioner who is caring for Senator Brownhill in relation to referral, in this hypothetical case, to a neurosurgeon in Sydney, in order to ensure the patient's coverage in relation to his medical expenses? That is what this amendment is all about.
—You want to know what is the patient's coverage?
—Yes.

—I am advised, Senator Herron, that the neurosurgeon will get, as now, 100 per cent of the medical benefits schedule; 75 per cent plus the 25 per cent. Or, if he is under contract to the hospital—presuming it is a he—he would go all the way to 100 per cent of the cost.
—Thank you very much, Minister. You have made the point—

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am on my feet minister. I made the point before that this is restricting it—Senator Lees should listen to this, too—to the schedule fee in relation to this episode; yet you say there is no coercion in that respect. That is the first point. The second point relates to the mechanisms by which this occurs. Let us say this happens at 2 o'clock in the morning. All good little public servants will be away in their beds, I trust, girding up for the next day's work as, similarly, will be the Health Insurance Association employees. It is only doctors who are available 24-hours a day, seven days a week. It is a requirement of their profession that they be so.

PARA.TAB: If the patient wants full coverage, the doctor is expected, presumably—no-one else is awake—to ring the hospital at 2 o'clock in the morning and ask, `Is there a contract with this neurosurgeon,' ring the insurance agency and say, `Do you have a contract with this neurosurgeon,' or ring the neurosurgeon and say, `Do you have a contract with this particular hospital that the relatives want to go to because it is next to the son or the daughter of the patient?'

These are the sorts of things that need to be questioned, not on behalf of the doctors, Senator Lees—you have an obsession about doctors—but on behalf of the patients and the relatives of the patients. These are the practicalities, as you well know, Senator Crowley. You have practised medicine and you know these are the practicalities. It is not about who is going to get what and where. You said that the surgeon would be paid a certain amount but it is the patient, under your legislation, who gets the refund.

We do not have conscription in this country or a socialised health system, although we are heading in that direction with this legislation whereby government will have total control. That, after all, is the unwritten objective. That aside, the point is that refunds go to the patients who, in turn, are responsible to the medical practitioner for the bill.

In relation to this amendment, it is fatuous to say that there is not pressure on the medical practitioner. I digress a little to ask: how is the patient covered in an emergency situation in relation to this legislation? That was the point that Senator Brownhill started with; that is, an emergency situation. We know what is happening at the moment with prescriptions and authority prescriptions—a total shambles. It is another bureaucratic exercise which has not been responded to. I forewarn Senator Crowley's advisers that I will be questioning them at estimates, because I am constantly getting complaints about people seeking authority prescriptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. With the greatest respect, I am trying to see the passage of this legislation and to assist Senator Herron in any way that I can. But it would be of great help if Senator Herron were assisted to stay on the point in question. Pharmaceutical benefits may be of great interest, but right now we are dealing with amendment 30. I am doing my best to answer the questions of Senator Herron, which seem to be changing. If he is really looking for information, I would be very pleased to find it for him. Madam Chair, it would be helpful if you could ask Senator Herron to stay on the point.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Point upheld. Senator Herron, I would appreciate if you would keep your comments relevant to the legislation. That is your last digression.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that, Madam Chair. The question I asked related to emergency situations. What do the medical practitioner and the relative do in that situation to find out what is in place in relation to purchaser-provider agreements?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Crowley, is it not correct that in the vast majority of cases—such as maybe 99 per cent—in an emergency the patient will end up in a large public hospital and will be dealt with immediately as an emergency? If, by some strange means, somebody who is unconscious was able to ask to go to a private hospital, I can assure Senator Herron that they would also deal with that patient as an emergency.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Herron is trying to paint is that somehow the patient's wellbeing will be in danger because someone is doing some checking. Obviously, that is not going to happen. I hope the minister will correct me if this is not the way the legislation works, but I imagine that an emergency is an emergency. The vast majority of what we are dealing with here is elective surgery. If at some stage down the track a person is recuperating in the public sector or in a facility that he or she does not want to be in, that person can elect, as anybody can under this legislation, to fully use his or her private insurance to go somewhere else. Senator Herron, are you trying to suggest that somehow a life would be in danger because of this legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are more private accident emergency centres in Brisbane than public accident emergency centres. Senator Lees believes that 99 per cent of emergencies go to public hospitals.
—In Adelaide.

—They may in Adelaide—that is the very point. We are all confined by our knowledge of local circumstances, just as Senator Brownhill was talking about the rural areas. This legislation is all encompassing. Certainly in my city, the figure of 99 per cent is not correct. The only private MRI facility is in a private hospital in Brisbane. The only lithotriptor is in a private hospital in Brisbane.
—Senator Herron, could you please relate this to the bill.
—I was asked a question to which I was responding.
—Yes, I know, but I think MRIs and lithotriptors are a little—

—I asked a question and still have not received an answer from the minister. In relation to emergency situations, what occurs in practical terms? If a patient goes to a private accident emergency centre, what happens?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to discuss the situation of a person having a baby in a country area. We have to remember that plenty of country towns do not even have their local surgery and hospital staffed full time all the time. What happens if it is not an emergency and that person is being sent to Sydney because better care and attention can be given in another area?

PARA.TAB: Do these people first have to ring up and find out for whom that hospital provides? Do they have to find out which doctor works for that fund? This is not an emergency but a very serious position for somebody in a country area.

As you would well know, Madam Temporary Chair, many country areas do not have as many practitioners as they used to, even though your government has been trying to entice doctors to country areas. I think only 70-odd have taken up the offer since that program has been going. Something like 450 to 500 general practitioners have given up practice in country areas over the same period.

In the case of a person having a baby, if the doctor decides that that woman should go to Sydney or wherever to have better attention—this is not an emergency—do they then have to find out what fund she is in, what hospital is tied to that fund and what doctor can actually deal with her at that hospital? I am bringing up the fact because it is one of the areas that is really worrying people in country areas. Here again, we believe that we may be the forgotten and lost people out in the rural areas because I do not think the Keating government has always been very attentive to the needs and aspirations of country people.

Also there are problems as far as the hospitals are concerned. I am waiting for the minister to get some advice on the question I have just asked about the person who is not in an emergency, having a baby and wanting to get better attention and how she can be attached to whichever hospital.

If an anaesthetist was required somewhere along the line, she would also have to find the anaesthetist that was tied to the fund that she was a member of to make sure that she got full and proper attention. I am really concerned about the effect this legislation will have on some country hospitals as well.

The minister has a lot of answering to do because health is in a chaotic position in country areas around Australia and a lot of that is due to the uncertainty of this legislation that has been brought before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, as I understand it, your patient is now pregnant and not in an emergency—I presume it is now not Senator Brownhill—and her general practitioner is a bit concerned, so he recommends a specialist down in the big city. I am not sure what your concern is—whether your concern is for the patient or for the general practitioner, but let us say your concern is for the patient.
—Just to clarify that, my concern is for the patient because the end-user is the person for whom we should be concerned.

—I was just about to presume your concern was for the patient. If the general practitioner refers to specialist X, your concern is whether the patient will be disadvantaged in any way by that referral. The concern is whether the new arrangements will disadvantage Mrs Patient when she gets to the big city and sees that specialist. The advice I have is that the situation will remain as it is, or they will have full cover or something approaching full cover depending on the contract.

PARA.TAB: I return to the woman sitting in the waiting room and the general practitioner says, `Mrs Jones, I think you should go to see a specialist in the hospital.' It is then open to the doctor to say, `Do you have private insurance? Which is your private insurance company', and then ring them immediately and say, `I'd like to refer to specialist X. Can you provide me with any information about whether they are under a contract?' That information can be provided there and then, and sorted out straightaway.

If the doctor is not under a contract but the general practitioner would still like to refer that patient to that specialist then the current arrangements that provide remuneration for Mrs Jones and the doctor prevail, otherwise they are benefited by the new contract arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister will come to my question about the emergency situation, because I am still waiting on an answer.

—I think I have answered that question. I will see if there is further information that could be provided. Senator Herron's concern, as I understand it, is what the arrangements will be when a person goes to a private emergency facility. As Senator Lees pointed out, an emergency is an emergency. Is Senator Herron saying that it is different in Queensland?
—No.
—As I understood it, Senator Herron's concern was about what happened when a person is referred to a private emergency facility. Is that right?

—I was referring to a question raised by Senator Lees with regard to private emergency centres. My previous question was in relation to the emergency situation, where a patient is referred from a country area to a city area. I want to know what the mechanism is for discovery of the coverage a patient has for medical expenses. In an after-hours, emergency situation, what is the mechanism whereby a patient—or a relative, if a patient is unconscious—discovers whether the patient has coverage under this legislation? How does it work? How does it affect the patient?
—The answer is that it will be as it is now: patients can ring up and find out, or medical practitioners may be able to assist the family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that there is a fair rapport between country doctors and the specialists in the cities to whom they refer patients. If a country doctor has a concern, not necessarily in an emergency situation, and that doctor has an understanding with a particular specialist in a city area, in a lot of cases that would mean that if that specialist was not in the same fund as the patient attended to by the country doctor, the patient would be at a disadvantage. The patient would have to be pushed along to another specialist who might not have the same rapport with the country doctor.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry to be labouring the point but this is something that country people are very worried about, and quite rightly so. The answers I have heard this morning would not satisfy anyone who is in a country area. Perhaps we are moving towards nationalised health. I thought the object of the legislation was to get more people to take out private cover but I think this will do the opposite; it will have more people relying on Medicare. If this government ever produces another budget, we will see the Medicare levy pushed up even further because of the shortfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Brownhill's concern is about the very good relationship the country doctor has with his patient, the country woman. His concern is that the doctor may not be able to easily refer that patient to a preferred specialist in the city. The answer is that the doctor certainly can refer to a preferred specialist. That has always been the case and will continue to be the case. Mrs Jones may have a say; that depends.

PARA.TAB: Senator Brownhill is asking whether there will be any problem with costs. If the specialist is not part of a contract—I have said this before and I say it again—the arrangements will be as they are now. The patient will be able to get 100 per cent of the scheduled fee as a default payment. If the doctor is under contract, it is very likely that there would be an even better benefit. The senator might think these concerns are very real but the answers show that they are not to be worried about. Perhaps Senator Herron will put his question about emergencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It follows on, Minister, from what you have just been saying. In an emergency situation, the out-of-pocket expenses are a very real concern for the patient. Is there a requirement then for the patient or their relatives to say to that surgeon, `Do you have a contract with hospital X?' or, `We would like to go to hospital Y, but do you have a contract with hospital Y? We are concerned about expense, and we would like to know what our out-of-pocket expenses are.' One of the purposes of this legislation, theoretically anyway, is to cover that eventuality.

PARA.TAB: The questions that I asked were: whose responsibility is that, and whom do they contact in that situation? It is a very legitimate question. It is not, Minister, just as it goes on now because this legislation, when enacted, changes the whole complex of the situation. It is not just as it is now because under the legislation some may have contracts and some may not have contracts—it is voluntary. What occurs in practice in an emergency situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is an emergency, the practice of good medicine is that you fix the emergency. No-one is going to say, `We're not going to treat this patient.' And I am sure no unconscious patient or patient's relatives are going to argue that, `We'll wait until we find out.' If it is an emergency, it will be treated as an emergency. The situation of coverage will be, at least, as it is now. But, if there is a contract, it will be very likely much better than that.
—You say `very likely much better than that'. Could you quantify that?

—There may well be an arrangement that covers that person for 100 per cent if they have that kind of contract or insurance arrangement, but there is a whole range of things. Nobody is going to be worse off. It is very likely under the purchaser-provider arrangements and the arrangements with doctors that the patients will be better off.

—One hundred per cent of what? These are practical points, Minister. You may nod your head and say, `Oh, this is too detailed to be of any consideration,' but it is your legislation. I think the patient is entitled to know. When you say `100 per cent of the contract', is that 100 per cent of the scheduled fee? Is that what you are referring to, or are you referring to a negotiated benefit above the scheduled fee which is limited perhaps by 15 per cent, 20 per cent or 25 per cent?

—The arrangements are, as they are now or under a contract, better than that. It is pretty simple. Depending on how that contract goes, it may well be 100 per cent coverage and, yes, Senator, it can be above the current scheduled fee.
—Are there any limits on the contracted fee that is negotiated?
—No.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go back to my example of a person who has to go to Sydney. The gap could be quite considerable for some of those people if they cannot get to their contracted hospital or contracted doctor, for example. Those persons are definitely going to be very much disadvantaged by the fact that there is going to be a hell of a gap to pay.
—It will either be as it is now, where there is a considerable gap, or it will be better.
—And it could also be worse.

—I do not understand that it will be worse in any situation. If there is no contract, the situation that exists at the moment, where patients may indeed find themselves having to pay a considerable gap, will continue. If there is a contract, it is most likely that that gap will be all the way from nothing to smaller than it is now.

—Many small rural areas operate with one general practitioner, and a problem could arise if the medical practitioner has an agreement with the health fund but the local hospital does not. Would that not lead to increased costs? The other aspect would be fewer admissions to the local hospital and therefore the viability of the hospital would be affected.

—If Senator Harradine is saying that the doctor has a contract with the insurance company and the hospital has not, I understand that the patient would be covered for hospital costs to the default benefit level.
—In other words, the patient would be reimbursed for all the additional travel expenses that are needed? Are you saying that that would be the situation?
—I was presuming that Senator Harradine meant a small rural local hospital and that there would be no travel costs. I do not understand what Senator Harradine's question is about travel costs.
—Is the Minister saying that therefore the patient would be able to be admitted to the local hospital and that all the costs would then be paid?

—No. I am saying that the patients can be admitted to the local hospital, that is correct, and would receive remuneration to the default level, effectively the base coverage level, for their hospital costs.

—In other words, is it correct that the costs of hospitalisation would be met? We are talking now about insurance. This is the whole business involving the arrangements the minister is talking about. In other words, rural patients would be treated differently from a person with the same complaint who lives in a city where the doctor has an agreement with the health fund as does the hospital.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me there are two situations here. In a city the medical practitioner has an agreement with the health fund as does a particular hospital, which is very handy to the patient. Obviously that person is in a position whereby the costs would be met. If we take a similar situation as applying to a rural area but where the medical practitioner has an agreement with the health fund and the hospital does not have such an agreement, will persons in the rural area not be at a disadvantage compared with their city counterparts?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's question is being slightly extended, but I will give the reply again. If a patient goes to see a doctor who has a contract with an insurance company and is admitted to a private hospital or hospital in the country with which the insurance company has no contract, the patient will be covered for hospital expenses to the basic table. That may not cover all the hospital expenses. If the hospital has a contract and the doctor has a contract in the city or in the country, the remuneration will be different.
—That is right.
—Well, it may be different. It depends on the hospital costs, but most likely it will be different. I hope that is clear to Senator Harradine.

—Surely, Senator Harradine's point is correct. In this case, because the rural hospital gets only a default payment, then that hospital is at a disadvantage. The point of your legislation is to try to encourage them to have purchase-provider agreements with insurance agencies. So Senator Harradine's point is perfectly correct: they are at a disadvantage. The patient only gets a default payment.

—Senator Herron, we can go on and on, finding examples of these sorts of things. The default payments are the basic table cover which is, effectively, what exists at the moment. We also have passed amendments to this legislation that say insurance companies will not be able to discriminate against taking up contracts with hospitals which have very small bed numbers, which may have been seen as a reason for insurance companies not to take up contracts.

PARA.TAB: We are actually anticipating all sorts of hypothetical situations. In the case of Senator Harradine's hypothetical situation, I have given an answer. I think it is a hypothetical situation. It would be important to wait and see the take-up and the coverage of hospitals by insurance companies. But in the end I do not think it is a matter of Senator Herron discovering it. That is quite right; if a hospital does not have a contract with insurance companies, they will be covered to the default benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hooray.
—I do not think you should cheer as though it is a discovery.
—Well, why didn't you say that at the beginning?

—Because we have known it. Senator Herron, you are asking questions that are so basic to the understanding of this that it puzzles me that you still seem not to know them. I thought we were dealing with amendment 30.

—I have to reply to that. I do not know why the minister just did not agree with Senator Harradine in the first place because that is what she was saying and that is what he was questioning her about. She then did a little bit of point scoring. Yes, Senator Harradine, you are correct.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 15Schedule 1, page 19, item 69, proposed subsection 20A(2A) omit:
"the eligible person is taken, for the purposes of this Act, to have assigned his or her right to the payment of the medicare benefit to the organisation",
substitute
"the eligible person may, for the purposes of this Act, assign his or her right to the payment of the medicare benefit to the organisation".
16Schedule 1, page 19, after item 69, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "69A. After subsection 20A(5)
Insert:

'(6) An agreement or instrument assigning, and an assignment of a medicare benefit under this section is not subject to any duty or charge under any law of a State or Territory or a law of the Commonwealth that applies only in relation to a Territory.' ".

SPEECH.PARA: Item 69 deems the assignment of a patient's Medicare benefits for an agreed episode to the fund. Our amendments would ensure that this is a conscious decision by the patient and effectively would allow insurers to act as agents of the Health Insurance Commission for the payment of medical services for all privately insured patients.We would then seek to insert new section 20A(6) to ensure that any agreement or instrument assigning, and an assignment of a Medicare benefit, is not subject to any Commonwealth, state or territory duty or charge. So amendment 16 simply makes any instrument of assignment exempt from duty.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to amendment 15, does Senator Herron not believe that this is now complicating the situation, particularly for patients, looking at the patient's need to then be involved in this process? As it stands, the amount is automatically assigned when a contributor has a contracted doctor. Surely, one of the benefits of this legislation is that people know not only that there is no gap but that they do not have to be concerned about the various payments. What Senator Herron is doing now is putting part of the onus back on the patient. Do you see a problem with the complication?

—It informs the patient. The patient then becomes aware of what is occurring. I would have thought that that is to the benefit of the patient. Surely the patient should be aware of what is going on. The object of the amendment is to have the patient making a conscious decision rather than it just occurring without the patient being aware of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that the patient needs to be aware of the amounts that the doctor is getting? What do you believe the patients need to be aware of?

—I think there should be full awareness on the part of the patient, yes. There is a contract between the patient and the doctor and I think that is to the advantage of the patient. If the patient is aware of the amount that is charged, he may or may not feel that he is getting value for money.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31)Schedule 1, page 19, item 69, add at the end:

TAB.TAB: `(2B) Despite subsection (4), in subsection (2A):

SPEECH.PARA: "medical practitioner" includes:

PARA.TAB: (a)an accredited dental practitioner; and
(b)a dental practitioner approved by the Minister for the purposes of the definition of "professional service" in subsection 3(1); and
(c)a person on whose behalf a medical practitioner (within the meaning of subsection 3(1), or a dental practitioner of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), renders a professional service.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment takes into account the provisions of the act which allow for persons to render professional services on behalf of a medical practitioner.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 17Schedule 1, page 19, after item 69 insert the following item:

TAB.TAB: (a)Insert in subsection (1) before `The Minister may', `Subject to subsection (4)'.
(b)Insert after subsection (3) the following subsection:
'(3A) For the purposes of this Act and the National Health Act 1953 a declared private hospital must provide data specified in the Hospital Casemix Protocol:
(a)in a patient identifiable state, to a registered private health insurance organisation which has an applicable benefits agreement with the patient; and
(b)in a patient de-identified state to a data bureau established, no later than 1 January 1996, by statute, for the purpose of receiving and disseminating such data; and

(c)the role and responsibilities of the data bureau shall be defined by statute after appropriate consultations with registered organisations, hospitals and medical practitioners, and with due reference to the data requirements of the hospital casemix protocol.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the privacy provisions and the uncertainty about why data is needed under the existing proposals. It came out in evidence that the government, the hospitals and the insurers are divided on what data is needed and why and who should collect it. I questioned this matter previously in relation to another amendment. Section 23EA(1) was amended to authorise private hospitals to provide relevant casemix data to a private hospital independent data bureau established for the purpose of collecting, collating, analysing and reporting on all private patient data from 1 July 1995. This section would commence on 1 July 1995, not 1 April 1996, because we recognise the importance of data collection and analysis as a proper precursor to this package being implemented effectively.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Private Hospitals Association has expressed a preference for an independent data agency. The coalition recognises the importance of data collection and the importance of privacy in relation to this data. Under the aegis of the Privacy Commissioner there are restrictions as to the availability of this data. However, we believe that there should be a statutory agency established to achieve this, even though it would still be within the scope of the Commonwealth administrative and privacy laws. We think that is of great importance in putting the collection of data at arms-length.

I might refer back to the pharmaceutical benefits provisions in relation to the provision of data to a public servant. This concerned a case of genital herpes in a small town where permission was being sought for the use of a restricted drug. In that case the general practitioner had to ring a public servant to gain permission for this prescription to be allowed under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

This illustrates the point I am making in relation to that being at arms length. Of course somebody has to know about it, but if that data can be collated and is protected by a specific agency, and the same sort of information is given to government, then the objective will be achieved while protection is provided by putting a statutory authority between the private hospitals and the government. That is an added check.

As I said, we are proposing the agency be in place by 1 January next year; although, in practice, this could be sooner, depending on how long it took to establish. However, the role of the agency and the data needs of the respective interested parties need to be taken into account in a process of consultation. It seems to us that this, for whatever reason, has not properly taken place up until now.

This provision goes to the heart of one of our pre-conditions to entertain the bill—that is, adequate protection of privacy. There are no clear indications of why the department and PHIAC should have a central role in data collection and dissemination and how they would use this data they collect. The minister will recall that I questioned this at some length in the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee hearings and I did not get an adequate answer to those questions. Because of that, we are submitting this amendment. We still are not convinced that we can support the government-Democrat data arrangements as they exist at the moment.

We offer this amendment as a compromise that has the best chance of gaining a consensus among the affected parties. This amendment ensures that insurers are not prevented from getting access to patient data from private hospitals for payment purposes. That still continues under this amendment. We appreciate that the chamber has accepted an earlier government amendment to section 73AB. But we cannot state too strongly that we continue to object to the arrangements outlined in that section. Because of that, we offer our alternative, which we think will achieve the objective of the government and will allay the concerns on privacy.

I must say that I am a little surprised we are not supported by the Democrats in this regard. It seems to me that they have also flagged an interest in the confidentiality of data collection. It does not seem such a major thing to ask that there be an added safeguard in relation to this data. It is for that reason that I move this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very major issue and the government is not going to deign us with its view about the question of privacy. Why won't the minister get up and express her view about this particular proposition that has been advanced by Senator Herron? We are waiting expectantly.

PARA.TAB: The reason I have risen is that I want to hear what the government has to say about this. It is all very well, Minister, for many of your people who are in their rooms or anywhere else to possibly not listen to this debate. They are going to come in here and vote how the whip tells them to on this matter. I have to listen to what the government has to say about it.

The argument advanced by Senator Herron thus far appears, on the surface, to be attractive. No doubt the Greens are listening to this debate, as I have to. When I am in my office, I have to listen to the committee discussions and attempt to do other things as well. Frankly, the matters raised by Senator Herron warrant some response by the government. If the government is not going to respond to them, then obviously there is only one explanation for that: it has no answer to the proposition that has been put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that the public is totally unaware of what data is available at the moment. As a medical practitioner and a surgeon, I am entitled to get a print-out every six months. That print-out details what operations I have done, whether I have charged the scheduled fee or not, what pathology tests I have ordered and which pathology firm I have ordered them from, and what radiology tests I have ordered and which radiology firms I have ordered those tests from. It details where my pathology or radiology ordering practice varies from the average in my particular specialty. It details not what is available to me because I have that data anyway, but the names, addresses and sex of patients and the conditions that they have been treated for. That is the medical side. All this data is collected.

PARA.TAB: On the individual side, I instanced previously the case of a young girl with genital herpes in a country town. Big brother is here! All this data is available. To give another example of how it has been circumvented illegally in the past, I had a prominent personality, well-known in Australia, who had a fever of unknown origin. I needed an AIDS test done on him. I said to him, `Regrettably, I need to get you tested for HIV because it may be the diagnosis.' I questioned him; he had been exposed to the possibility.

His instant concern was, `This will be on the front pages of the nation's newspapers tomorrow.' So I rang the pathologist and explained the situation to him and he laughed. He said, `Do you realise this will be the tenth HIV test I have had this year?' I said, `What do you mean'? He said, `In this circumstance, with these people, I put my own name on the request form.' So, illegally, he circumvented the legislation. No doubt, on the computers he will be queried as to why he needed an HIV test every few weeks for the last 12 months or so.

I use that illustration as an example of the data that is available in this country. We have already had examples in the press about the availability of our credit cards and how people can hack into them. It would not be very difficult, I suspect, although I do not know, to hack into the Medicare computers. I know they are very sophisticated. I have inspected them on a few occasions and the data that is available on them.

Okay, the minister—as do I, Senator Lees and everybody in this chamber, I suspect—wants her medical details and her privacy to be protected. Surely by inserting an independent agency we can have a bit of control over data because one of the biggest problems for us in the future will be privacy; it is now. It is not being obstructionist. I think as Senator Harradine said, there is a requirement for the minister to tell us why she will not have an independent agency inserted between government and the collection of this data. I think Senator Lees has a requirement to answer the question too. The minister deigns not to reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the one area in the bill that we still are concerned about. We have ongoing discussions with the department and with others on this issue. I have a letter here from the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), which I am happy to table later. It was dated yesterday as we were having these ongoing discussions. This data is de-identified. My major problem is that I cannot see any greater protection from this agency. I think there are still the same possibilities for information to find its way to where it should not be going, whether it is to an independent agency—as you are suggesting—or to the department. I believe the greatest reason that we are still slightly swayed towards leaving it where it is is that we can have a far better handle on what is happening in terms of ministerial responsibility than we would be able to with the independent agency, but that is a balanced decision on my part.

PARA.TAB: I will go through what this letter has pointed out. Dr Loy from the department, and Dr Herring from the Australian Private Hospitals Association, are still discussing issues relating to this, based around Dr Herring's paper as well. The letter reads:

The Government proposes to develop, in consultation with all sectors of the private health industry, a set of guidelines to govern use of the data. They would describe the work proposed, set out the approach for publication of analysis of the data, and establish arrangements for other parties to have such access to the data as is consistent with the legislation.
The Government envisages using the data to evaluate the effects of many aspects of the reforms, including:

SPEECH.PARA: .the impact on different groups of consumers and service providers;
.the effects of contracting, including impact on premiums;
.comparison between different casemix based payment systems in terms of their impact on funds, hospitals and consumers;
.research into the impact of case mix based payment systems on particular hospital groups to identify any instances of treatment perceived to be `unfair'.

I believe that, on balance, we in this place have greater control over a minister, making sure the minister is answerable step-by-step as the guidelines are established than we do over an independent agency. Again, we would obviously have to be very careful about de-identification of data and exactly what the agency was doing.

TALK.START.PARA: 10.57 a.m.)—I thank Senator Lees for that. I smile because that was the sort of information that I was requesting at the committee hearing, and I now hear it in the chamber from the Democrats, not from the minister or from the department. I would very much appreciate seeing that letter. I do represent the opposition in the Senate; it is numerically the largest group in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees, you say to me that you have control over the government. You may have control over the government because you have access to it and because you have the balance of power. But from the opposition's point of view, that is certainly new information. That is a classic example of the point that I am referring to. You have got no control over the government. It will be nice to you about this legislation. As I expected, you do have genuine concern about it. But to say that, by leaving it with the government, you have some sort of control over it—Senator Lees, I know you are not ingenuous. Of course the government will communicate with you on legislation where you have got a balance of power. But where it does not need you, you will not get access.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron, if you do your numbers, the two of us working together certainly do have power to make sure that this works.

—I appreciate that, but the point that I was making is that you will only have access to government when it needs you. You will only have access to us when we need you. That is the balance of numbers in the Senate. With an independent agency, with de-identification of data, it is an added safeguard. That is the point I was making. If you want Big Brother controlling everything, go for it.

—I guess it is best to avoid responding to all the abuse that comes around in this place. The Temporary Chairman will put this amendment to the vote, and as this has been very extensively canvassed—it has all been discussed at length before—one way to expedite matters would be to allow that to go through. Senator Harradine seems to want further information, and we are very happy to provide this. I must say that I do think this legislation would be helped if there was less abuse. Senator Herron, just because it is pronounced correctly does not make it less abusive.

PARA.TAB: The government considers this portion of the amendment unnecessary. I find it interesting to listen to Senator Herron argue that Big Brother has got us all now, and then propose an amendment to create another brother, perhaps a little sister. Also, his argument about genital herpes would mean that there would just be more people knowing about it.

In some ways the best argument is that there is no justification for the creation of an additional statutory authority to handle data. The department and the private health insurance advisory council will not have access to patient-identified data and the department is already subject to stringent secrecy provisions under the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Act, the Privacy Act and the Crimes Act. Secrecy provisions as applicable to a data bureau as proposed in this amendment would not be subject to the same stringent secrecy provisions. An authority outside the Commonwealth bureaucracy would not be subject to these provisions and thus the patient confidentiality could be less protected.

Claims have been made that the private health insurance advisory council's proposed task of collecting and disseminating information about products for their comparison is impossible. This suggests that consumers would find the task equally impossible and should hence rely on intuition, prejudice or inertia. In such an environment persons not holding insurance would find it impossible to make an informed choice and presumably would continue not to hold insurance. This is not the way to encourage insurance amongst the population.

I have also been handed a copy of a letter which I presume is, if not the same, very similar to the one that Senator Lees referred to. I am not sure whether that letter is able to be made available to Senator Herron but if it is we will certainly make that available.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a bit late; I've got it. Senator Lees gave it to me.

—I am pleased you have it, Senator. If the senator finds that he is not getting access to information from this government, then I think that is something we would be very pleased to rectify. In passing this legislation I do not believe we will be helped by sitting poles apart, so if the senator thinks he is not getting this information, he should please make that known to us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the assurance, Minister. That is the first I was aware of the letter, and I thank Senator Lees for making it available to me. Previously I had sought that information almost ad nauseam from you, Minister, if not from others.

PARA.TAB: The point the minister seems to be unaware of is that the private hospitals have all that information anyway. They are dealing with the patients who are in those hospitals; they have all that data. To allege that another agency will make more information available seems to convey a complete misunderstanding of this amendment. The private hospitals have all that data. They have the hospital notes, if you like. They already have more data than is available to the government. We are asking that it be collated by the private hospitals and that it then go to an independent authority, given that all those privacy restrictions cover the data anyway.

I cannot see why there is so much objection, except that Big Brother wants to control it all. The minister might feel that it might be some sort of impediment to the legislation, but that is the only argument she has, I think. She cannot have these other considerations because the hospitals have all that information anyway, as the Minister well knows.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that much of this discussion that has taken place about this piece of legislation has not been full, free and open to all. The Senate committee undertook its task for the benefit of all of us. The committee reported on the various aspects that were canvassed before it. That report, as well as the material that came forward from various organisations and individuals throughout Australia, provided me with a very good basis upon which to examine my attitude to the legislation. We have here an important matter relating to privacy.

PARA.TAB: One of the major functions of this chamber is to ensure that the rights of individuals are upheld. For the rights of the individual to be upheld this question of privacy is essential; it is most relevant. Examples have been given by Senator Herron and other examples have come to my mind. From my discussions in estimates and on other committees, I have become of aware how the department operates. In many instances there is, unfortunately, complete obfuscation. Talk about ministerial responsibility! Have we seen it here? The minister does not know the provisions, let alone the answers to the questions that might be asked in many instances.

I understand that this is not the minister's portfolio but where the minister does deal with relevant information on a matter in a particular bill and that information is really essential for others who have to make up their minds on which way they need to vote, that information ought to be made available to all. The government talks about numbers in this place. It may have escaped people's notice but the fact is that if the opposition moves an amendment such as this, and it is supported by the Greens and me, that amendment is carried.

I am inclined at this point, because I have not been given all the information by the government and because the explanation that has been given by the minister thus far is not satisfactory, to vote for the amendment that has been put by Senator Herron. I hope it is carried. This will have the effect of sending that amendment, along with the heaps of other amendments that are being agreed to, back to the House of Representatives. Then, if the House of Representatives and the minister in that place have a basic objection to this amendment, they can detail their objections and we might be able to reconsider the matter in the light of their considered objections. But, until I have that information, I am inclined to vote for the amendment that has been proposed by Senator Herron.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Herron's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

This amendment, I understand, will not be getting the support of the committee and I am not going to press it. It is simply one that I wish to leave on the record here as a way in which we could proceed if we still have these ongoing complaints that patients are not informed of what they really are going to have to pay at the end of the day.

PARA.TAB: Basically, this legislation says that if people are not informed in writing of their liability for what the doctors are going to charge—that is, the difference between the scheduled fee and the actual costs—then they simply do not have to pay. To some extent we are being overtaken by the courts which have made a number of decisions along these lines in recent months. People who have taken their complaint to a number of different courts around this country have found that they have not had to pay because there was no real contract between them and the doctor for that additional amount.

This amendment would not have taken effect until 1 July 1998 which would have given plenty of time for greater compliance by members of the medical profession to actually let their patients have full financial information at the time of entering into an agreement with them for service. This amendment would again, I believe, help the private health industry because it would undo one of the major problems—that people have bills delivered to their home after they have left hospital which they had absolutely no warning would be coming and are then faced not only with their private health insurance but with additional gap payments of which they were not aware.

Obviously, under this legislation gap payments are still going to exist and that is fine as long as the patients know that they are going to be up for that additional amount. This amendment simply would have made sure that all patients were fully informed of all charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting this amendment because, theoretically it sounds a great idea, but again it shows a total lack of understanding of just what occurs in real life. Certainly, we advocate that there should be informed financial consent, but frequently, and in a consent form that is signed by the patients when they are admitted to a private hospital, they give consent for unexpected eventualities—they have to.

PARA.TAB: For example, with a colonoscopy—an examination of the bowel and below with a flexible instrument—a polyp may be found. Since the object of the exercise is to see if there are any polyps there, you cannot say to a patient beforehand, `I am going to find a polyp.' But it is proposed to write into the legislation a requirement to tell a patient what is going to occur. Probably the commonest day surgery event in this country is endoscopy—upper gastrointestinal and lower gastrointestinal examination. While, theoretically, this is a great idea, practically, it places an unnecessary burden on the doctor, and on the patient too, for that matter, because of the confusion that could ensue. I am sure the government took that into account in the first place—or I hope it did.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of the doctors with whom we discussed this matter assured us that they are able to let patients know that there may be additional charges. We are only asking for that to be put within a range; that the doctors give patients something in writing setting out the basic charge, adding that if there are complications they may be up for additional charges. Doctors are telling me that they are doing this already, at least verbally if not in writing. I cannot see what the problem is. If surgery is being undertaken in case there is a problem, patients would need to know the cost of dealing with that problem if that involves a stay in hospital and additional procedures.

—I accept what Senator Lees says and I support the objective. Certainly, that is something I already do in writing. But the point that seems to be in dispute is the range. This is a statutory requirement to try to cover all aspects of every private hospital admission. It is quite impractical.

—The government very much supports the sentiments of Senator Lees' proposal, which is to have as much information as possible provided to patients up-front. However, particularly in the light of the senator mentioning a start-up date of 1998, it is reasonable to suggest that we should wait and see what happens. We have this to fall back on. The only reservation the government has is that this measure is a bit premature, particularly with a starting date as far off as that. I believe that it is important to provide that sort of financial information up-front and it is an area in which the government will be interested to seek as much cooperation from the professionals as possible.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Schedule, as amended, agreed to.
Schedules 2 to 4—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 33 and 34 address the assurance that health plans covered under agreements proved by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are protected for a grandfather period up to 1 July 1996. As employers, funds and individuals have been aware of the provisions, including through the exposure given to this issue by the Esso case quite some months ago, it is considered more than generous to provide yet another period up to 1 July 1996 for employers to bring themselves into compliance with the legislation. As the underlying purpose of the compliance is to ensure that all parties contribute appropriately to community rating, any exception only imposes added burdens to the rest of the appropriately insured community. I think they might be sufficient points to make in arguing these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit concerned about this. Is the government saying that it has agreement with the unions and employer organisations about this? I am aware of a number of such funds. I, in fact, have been written to on this particular matter. Does the minister have agreement with the unions and the employers about this?

PARA.TAB: I think this is a very important matter. It goes to the essence of the constitution. I would like the minister to explain to the chamber how, under what constitutional power, the government is attempting to enact legislation which overrides the provisions of an award or an agreement made under the Industrial Relations Act. I do not want to delay the committee, because I do not know that I will get that much support for it, but I ask the minister: has the government got the agreement of all of the unions and the employers involved in such an agreement? TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to assist Senator Harradine as much as I can. The date of 1 July 1996 means that all such existing arrangements will be able to continue to that time. There will be no stoppage of any of the existing arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The High Court has ruled against employer funded or sponsored health schemes where there is an employee contributor element as being illegal. Some employers continue to offer schemes which are non-contributory whether self-funded or underwritten by a third party administrator.

The coalition is aware of the concerns held by registered health funds about employer health schemes which, because they are not registered under the Health Insurance Act 1973, are not subject to the same fiduciary and fund holding requirements as registered funds, such as compulsory contribution to the reinsurance pool in particular and the maintenance of statutory fund reserves as well.

We are also aware of the decision of the Federal Court in the Esso case in respect of contributory employer schemes and that this decision was upheld by the High Court. After consultation with the health insurance industry and with a number of the companies which operate the schemes in question, the coalition agrees with the insurance industry's basic argument that non-contributory schemes are prima facie contrary to the spirit of the existing law.

We believe that should their existence be legally challenged, that challenge would probably stand a reasonable chance of success. On balance, therefore, we believe that those non-registered schemes currently in operation should be wound up. We support the intention of the government's legislation in this regard.

Nevertheless, we believe that, in winding up these schemes without a reasonable grace period, it would result in the employees covered by these schemes being disadvantaged. This is particularly important where a scheme has been incorporated into a registered enterprise agreement. That was what Senator Harradine was referring to, I am sure—where it has been part of a registered agreement or is clearly an express or implied term of a contract of employment. As Senator Harradine mentioned, there were objections by some unions in this regard.

To recognise this, the coalition is moving amendments to the legislation. These amendments would defer the prohibition of non-registered schemes until 1 July 1996, with schemes incorporated in registered enterprise agreements allowed to continue until 1 July 1997 or until the expiry of a current agreement after 1 July 1996, whichever date is the sooner.

We have proposed this course after making it clear to the companies concerned that the coalition supports the prohibition of these schemes, bearing in mind that any legal action to compel their winding up, after the commencement of the government's current provisions, would not be final by July 1996. I say to the minister that is also a consideration. Should there be a legal challenge, as you know, it would take that time for it to occur.

The coalition accepts that its proposals will not completely satisfy either the health insurance industry, which wants an immediate cessation, or the companies operating non-registered schemes who, quite correctly in their own belief, understood that they were legal, as they had an assurance from, I think, Dr Blewett, the fourth-last health minister—there have been so many; three in three years—that they would not be constrained and they accepted that assurance. Understandably, they believed that they were operating legally, even though they were not within the legislation. We believe, however, that the longer-term interests of the employees affected must come first in resolving this situation. It is for that reason that we have moved these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be accepting these amendments. Employers have been aware of the proposed changes to such employee health benefit schemes for the past three years. The Esso case, as I have just mentioned, widely publicised the relevance of the health provisions. There is a government-Democrat amendment which allows for the continuation of such schemes which were part of an enterprise agreement as at 1 July 1995 to remain in place until 1 July 1996.

PARA.TAB: I think it is reasonable to say that there is not a good case at all for further exceptions or delays. They would not be acceptable. If all agreements have lapsed by 1 July 1996, deferring the time before they are legally extinct for another year will only give a false optimism to some of the employers or employees or maybe will just create confusion. I think that you have almost effectively argued the case yourself, Senator Herron. It is not new to the employers; they have understood over the last three years that these changes were coming. They are covered until 1 July 1996 and I am advised that that should protect most agreements. Giving them another year will only put it out for another year and create the possibility for further confusion and even false hopes.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the employer groups appeared before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee they gave evidence that they had not been consulted and that they were totally unaware of the effects of the legislation on them. By not accepting the amendments, the government is effectively penalising the employees, not the employers, because in many instances, financially, it will be better for them to get out of the schemes.

PARA.TAB: That is your decision. In moving these amendments on behalf of employees we recognise that there was no consultation—and that was clearly the evidence of the employer organisations before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee. The then minister had said—as you have said, Minister—that it had been going on for three years, but we have had three ministers in three years. Who do we trust in this game? Do we trust the assurance of the fourth minister back that it was all legal?

We have had that debate and I do not want to waste the time of the Senate in going into the question of the failure of consultation. A screed was put out by the minister in which it was said that consultations occurred. But it appeared that all the consultations occurred between the ACTU-Caucus working party and the immediate minister, former Senator Richardson. The employer organisations left us in no doubt whatsoever that there had been no consultations in this regard. So, we forcefully move our amendments in the interests of employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Herron has mentioned, the matter was canvassed before the Senate committee and it is mentioned in the committee's report that employer groups warned that the legislation would force them to be in breech of either this legislation or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and expose them to substantial penalties. To a certain extent that has been dealt with by the minister when she said that they will expire—except for one, I think. I am not sure which one that is.

PARA.TAB: I had representations on behalf of the ANZ bank, AMCOR, Woodside Petroleum, Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd, Esso Australia, Kemcor, Kraft Foods Ltd, National Australia Bank, NuFarm and Philip Morris Ltd. The provision of health care and health insurance to employees is contained in enterprise agreements, which have been encouraged by the current government. Obviously, if they go by the board there will need to be extensive renegotiation. I would not mind the job of representing the workers in those renegotiations, even though I would be starting from behind the eight ball.

I ask the Minister to reconsider the matter. I understand what she is saying: if there is a decision, that is the end of that; that is the end of the road for any such future agreements. Obviously, if that is the decision, and if it is supported by the Australian Democrats and the opposition, then who am I—I was going to say, `Who am I am to say anything about that?', but I will reserve my position on all occasions. Obviously it is going to be a fait accompli. There is something in what the Minister says: let us get it over and done with so that there are no false expectations.

I do not think there will be false expectations because Senator Herron has made the opposition's position quite clear. For the reasons that Senator Herron has mentioned, I feel that it would be desirable in all the circumstances to support his amendment. It is not going to mean any skin off the nose for the government. It is something that should be attractive to the government because, whilst it looks as though it is affecting employers, the people that it really is affecting are the employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for his support. That is the very point. These agreements have been in existence for some time. The government is going to penalise the employees. It is to their financial advantage that they have these agreements with the employers as part of the enterprise agreement situation. In essence, we are saying that, on the other hand, we agree the agreements should be phased out, but let us phase them out over a period to allow the employees not to be penalised. I thank Senator Harradine for his clear explanation of the reasons for his support.

—I want to make one thing clear. I may have put the words so that a false impression was given. I am advised that the only agreement the department knows of will expire before 1996. Having trawled through as much evidence of agreements and so on that they could, they could find evidence of only one and that will be out of existence by that date. I want to make that clear. I draw to the committee's attention that, if Senator Herron's amendments should now succeed, they will effectively contradict the amendments we have just passed. The committee might like to consider what it wants to do.
—Which amendments?

—We have just passed one setting a date of 1 July 1996. There are amendments 33, 34, 52 and 53. If Senator Herron is successful with his amendments, we will be contradicting the previous amendments successfully passed in this place.

That the amendments (Senator Herron's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (37) Schedule 2, page 26, after item 61, insert the following item:
"61A. After section 73D:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

SPEECH.PARA: `Division 5A—Removal of hospitals etc. from non-contracted benefits

PARA.TAB: `73E. In this Division, unless the contrary intention appears:

SPEECH.PARA: "determination" means a determination under section 73EA; "treatment" means:

TAB.TAB: (a)hospital treatment, and related services, provided by or on behalf of a hospital or day hospital facility; and
