PARA.EMPHASIS: Determinations relating to non-contracted benefits in respect of particular treatments at particular hospitals etc.

PARA.TAB: `73EA.(1) A registered organization, a State, a Territory or the National Health and Medical Research Council may apply in writing to the Minister for a determination relating to episodes of treatment of a particular kind provided at a hospital or day hospital facility specified in the application.

`(2) If the Minister is satisfied that the standard of treatment of that kind provided at that hospital or day hospital facility is unacceptable, the Minister may, by written notice given to the hospital or day hospital facility, determine that subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) of Schedule 1 no longer applies in respect of episodes of treatment of that kind provided at that hospital or day hospital facility.
`(3) The determination must be made in accordance with the guidelines issued under section 73EB.
`(4) The Minister must:

`(2) The guidelines may also specify matters to which the Minister must have regard in considering whether any such grounds, or particular grounds, exist.
`(3) Guidelines issued under this section are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

TAB.TAB: (a)at all times during which the episode of treatment was being provided, a determination was in force in respect of episodes of treatment of that kind; and

(c)the benefit would, but for this subsection, be a benefit of a kind referred to in subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) of Schedule 1.
`(2) Subsection (1) has effect despite:

`(2) If the Minister is satisfied that there are no longer grounds on which he or she could reasonably find, in accordance with the guidelines issued under section 73EB, that the standard of treatment of that kind provided by that hospital or day hospital facility is unacceptable, the Minister must, by written notice given to the hospital or day hospital facility, revoke the determination.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision sets out the definitions for the purposes of division 5A. The provision allows an organisation, a state or territory government, or the National Health and Medical Research Council, to apply to the minister for determination that the standard of hospital treatment provided by a non-contracted hospital or day hospital facility is unacceptable. When the minister is satisfied that the standard of care is unacceptable, the minister may issue a determination that the default benefit need not be payable. Copies of any such determination must be given to each organisation and must be published in the Gazette. Where the minister decides not to make a determination, the organisation and day hospital facility must be notified accordingly.

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 73EB requires the minister to issue guidelines for the purposes of determining whether the standard of care is unacceptable. The guidelines constitute a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Proposed section 73EC provides clarification of the effect of any determination made by the minister pursuant to proposed section 73E. Proposed section 73ED allows the relevant hospital or day hospital facility, which are the subject of a determination, to apply to the minister to revoke the determination. If the minister is satisfied that the grounds for issuing the determination no longer exist, the minister must revoke the determination and inform the hospital or day hospital accordingly.

Before revoking the determination, the minister is first required to inform organisations and to publish a notice in the Gazette of his or her decision. Proposed section 73EE clarifies that the effect date of revocation of a determination must not be a period of less than 12 months from the date in which the determination was made. This means that the benefits are payable only where the standard of care and accommodation is adequate for the treatment of patients.

The provisions ensure there is an open and practical way through a reviewable decision making process to remove the compulsion for funds to pay a default benefit when the standard of care and/or accommodation at a hospital is clearly evidenced to be inadequate for the treatment of patients. The example that we might cite would be Chelmsford hospital, or similar examples. These have highlighted the necessity to put in place measures that ensure appropriate standards of care are maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support this amendment. I have a number of questions relating to it. The minister has mentioned that guidelines will be developed and they will be disallowable instruments. Have the guidelines been drawn up? Do we know what criteria are going to be used in the determination?
—No, they have not been drawn up to this point, Senator.

—So we come back to the situation that we do not know. We are going ahead with amendments that have been added after the bill came from the House of Representatives. We are being told, `Trust us; we are from the government. We will draw up some guidelines. Admittedly, they are disallowable instruments.' I think it is vitally important to the private hospitals to know what the guidelines are, and what the criteria are that are going to be used in the determination of whether they are going to be taken out of consideration or not.

PARA.TAB: Have we got no concept, no running sheet, no idea as to what the guidelines are? We know that they will not be based on the number of beds or on the number of cases that are treated in hospitals. We know that, under the legislation, it will be casemix funded. As I understand it, we have got no idea as to what the quality control is going to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the standards would be based on the Australian council's health care standards accreditation guidelines. What they might finally be I certainly cannot say, but they would take into account the sorts of things that are covered under the Australian council's health care accreditation guidelines. They may include, for instance, standards of cleanliness, standards for meal care, approaches to treatment and the sorts of things that are covered there, but they have not been finalised in the drawing up of this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —These are amendments that the Democrats worked very hard to see in this bill. We believe that we do need quality assurance in the private sector. Most hospitals to which we have spoken have no concerns with this. The hospitals understand that there is a long time frame, firstly, of over 12 months for the drawing up of the amendments and, secondly, a further period of 12 months if any hospital is found to be in breach of the basic standard of care.

PARA.TAB: Earlier an amendment was alluded to that was passed some time ago relating to size or otherwise of hospitals. Obviously that has nothing to do with this. We are now talking about standard of care. Previously I was asked why we do not just link it to accreditation. It is not that simple: we are looking at specific standards of care. The hospitals will have plenty of opportunities to work through their associations and come to us as the minister's decision will be a disallowable instrument in both this place and the other place. It will also be subjected to review by the AAT if necessary.

So it is not, as some of the specialists have suggested, delisting private hospitals for the purposes of hospital and medical benefits on grounds privy only to the minister. It is very much a transparent process that will take a considerable length of time to determine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees, could you tell the chamber how long the Australian Council on Health Care Standards has been in existence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know the precise date. I can understand what Senator Herron is getting at. He is looking at how many hospitals have been accredited. Yes, that process is very slow. As I said, this will not be directly linked to the accreditation of hospitals. Some of the relevant issues may well come up as grounds for making a decision not to continue the default payment to a hospital, but it will not be directly linked. We chose not to do that. That was one of the options we had when we were looking at how we drew up this amendment.

—Senator Lees is quite correct. The purpose of my question was that there is an Australian Council on Health Care Standards. It has been in existence for many years. It is self-funded by the private hospitals. It goes to hospitals and accredits them. It usually takes a hospital at least three months of intensive activity to check its procedures to make sure that the hospital satisfies the criteria.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees tells me that the government is not going to accept that accreditation, that it wishes to establish yet another regulatory authority on private hospitals to detect their quality. Why, I ask the minister? There is already an accreditation procedure in existence. Why is there a need for another? On the one hand the minister said that she is going to use those standards and guidelines, yet Senator Lees said that the Democrats will not accept that, that it has to be ancillary to whatever guidelines the minister determines. But the minister cannot tell me what those guidelines are. The government and the Democrats are the ones moving the amendments; would they care to sort it out?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is anything to sort out. It is plain that these guidelines would be developed over a period of time in consultation with the relevant players and key industry groups. If a hospital is fully accredited it should have no problem. However, the option is there; it may not be a blanket provision which says, `You shall not get a default payment.' It may just be for things such as maternity.

PARA.TAB: It will not be a simple provision and that is why this determination has to come before both houses of parliament and be fully transparent and fully debatable. It may happen once in the next three or four years but I believe the option to question has to be there. I hope the type of incident which occurred at Chelmsford will never happen again. There must be a process that is open and transparent by which we can say, yes, we need to have a look at that hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I said before. I accept that it will be a disallowable instrument and will be debated. The question is why we need another body when there is already an accreditation procedure which is self-funded. Self-funding by the hospital is another cost; and who will pay for it? Is it going to be paid for by government? I presume it is, because it is coming from government. Is it another expense to the health care system in the sense that the procedures will be controlled by government?

—I know your concern for good practice. I ask you to rethink this matter because it is one of the critical points. At the moment, if a hospital were judged by the Australian Council on Health Care Standards not to be worthy of accreditation, there would be no requirement for its funding to cease and no way in which that would be done. That is a very important point.

PARA.TAB: When I first arrived in this place, I sat on a Senate committee looking at private hospitals and nursing homes. While it is quite clear that most private hospitals in this country are of very admirable and excellent quality, there was certainly evidence given to us about a few private hospitals where the quality of care was shameful and from where, on examination, all patients were removed and taken to a large public hospital, to be restored to good health and for continuing care.

I make it clear, in case anybody wants to misrepresent me yet again, that that is a very small number of private hospitals but most of us would have known of a few over the last 10 or 20 years that were a cause of grave concern. That is why the accreditation guidelines have been established; it is a recognition of the need to set guidelines for a good or acceptable standard and then, of course, regularly review it to see that hospitals maintain it.

As Senator Lees says, this process is not being rushed in. It is to be decided after discussion and with the cooperation of the players concerned. It is allowing a government or the NHMRC—not just anybody—to make an application to the minister. It is a thoughtful and considered way to say that if there are hospitals that are clearly below standard—not up to accreditation guidelines—then an application would be made to cease the minimal payment to those hospitals.

If the hospital wants to object to that it has a process to do so. As well, if the hospital changes its standards, or if its accreditation guidelines are achieved, then there is opportunity for the payment to be restarted. There are very few of these hospitals—we know that. Most hospitals are not going to have to worry but we all know that a small number have been clearly below par. I cite the evidence we took in our Senate inquiry.

The quality of hospital care in this country has changed dramatically. It is very good across the board, but we do have accreditation guidelines established to ensure that. We would not have to have accreditation guidelines and standards of care if we could be absolutely sure that all hospitals, at all times, maintained those standards.

We acknowledged the importance of that by establishing the accreditation process. At the moment, even if a hospital did not pass the accreditation guidelines, it would continue to be eligible for funding. This amendment says that is not appropriate. Down the track—it will not come in tomorrow—we would like to say that, if a hospital were so below par, it ought to be possible to revoke its basic funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be placed on the record that the Australian Council on Hospital Standards was generated by the private hospital industry itself. That industry brought it in; it had nothing to do with government. I understand Minister Crowley's explanation in relation to it. I agree that there are very few hospitals to which this may or may not apply, because by and large the standard is very high in the private hospital systems. I cannot think of any hospitals in my own state where this would be applicable.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees referred to some particular instances where a particular service may not meet those standards. This is the fear of a certain segment of the health-care industry. For example, there is a debate going on about midwifery services in one of the obstetric hospitals in Brisbane—the availability of midwifery services and the legal obligations that ensue in relation to doctors who are insured and midwives who may or may not be. What happens in terms of any legal action that might ensue as a result of a baby born with some defect?

While this may not affect a large number of hospitals, nor may it affect a large number of services in a particular hospital, it is very important. As the minister knows, and as everybody in this chamber knows, malpractice insurance is skyrocketing for doctors in this country. The number of actions that are being entered into by complainants is also increasing dramatically. While it may not be a large number, and while it may not be a large section of private hospitals that is influenced, you can understand questions relating to the guidelines that are to be used. There is a fear that this legislation may mean that some government instrumentality will determine that no default payment will be paid in that particular hospital for that particular service. It is not just a debating point; it is a very real concern.

Senator Crowley mentioned the Chelmsford situation. That was another day and another time. With the accreditation of doctors to private hospitals, it is unlikely that that could occur again because of peer review. All of us would abhor that sort of thing occurring again. I do not think that is likely at all.

I asked what criteria were going to be used. Initially it was said those accreditation guidelines required by the Australian Council on Hospital Standards, and that was enlarged upon. But the minister still cannot tell us what those criteria are. The amendment states that a body:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . may apply in writing to the Minister for a determination relating to episodes of treatment of a particular kind provided at a hospital . . . specified in the application.
How does that occur? Whether it be a registered organisation, a state, a territory or the National Health and Medical Research Council, under what criteria do they apply for that determination?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we draw up the guidelines that will become very clear, but I would imagine, Senator Herron, that they would have to make a particular case.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask Senator Herron a question. If we do have a hospital where there has been a series of successful malpractice suits for a particular type of procedure in a particular faculty, what do we do? At the moment there is no way the default payment can be stopped. Is the private insurance industry just expected to keep paying for the beds there? Do you think there should be no move at all on the part of the insurers? The message will be very clearly sent back to their clients, to say `For this particular procedure in that particular hospital we are no longer prepared to offer you coverage.' Surely that is in the best interests of their customers.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are so many procedures in place now in private hospitals, both with accreditation and medical practitioners and the Australian Council on Hospital Standards. I have attended many medical defence organisation lectures and seminars. The circumstance that Senator Lees puts forward has only occurred in relation to the Chelmsford situation. It has not occurred since because of all those controls—not so much restrictions—that have been put on the private hospitals.

PARA.TAB: The default payment penalises the patient not the hospital in that the default payment only applies if there is no purchaser provider agreement between the hospital and the insurance association or between the hospital and the doctor. So it does not apply in relation to default payment. It certainly would apply if a contract is in existence. You said that no default payment would be paid. That penalises the patient. So I do not quite see what you are getting at with the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a requirement under the legislation, Senator Herron, for the patients to be informed of their insurance status for the hospitals to be insured and if the information is withheld from the hospital you do not even get the default payment. I would imagine that under the legislation that would be a breach on behalf of both the hospital and the fund.

PARA.TAB: If as you say the private sector really does not have a problem and we do not need this legislation, that is great. That means this particular provision may never be needed to actually be used, but we are determined that it still should be there for the odd occurrence. As rare as it may be, this provision still needs to be there.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another point that I had not alluded to—that an insurance association could use this as a lever over a private hospital that it could not get a purchaser provider agreement with. They could use this to their commercial advantage. Do you not agree?
—They have to have evidence.

—Is Senator Herron suggesting that a private company would say to a hospital, `If you don't sign up with us, we'll default you'? I do not understand how you could possibly imagine that this would be used as a lever. Anyhow, it is not how it would even happen. If you understood the amendment proposed, you would know that it is quite outside of any possible contract between a private health insurance company and a hospital.

PARA.TAB: If you want, you can put creative hypotheticals of all sorts. But this amendment says that guidelines shall be drawn up against which basic hospital care standards should be assessed. If they are not reached, then a government, an organisation or the National Health and Medical Research Council—in other words, very proper people to do that—might make a claim to the minister that this hospital is not up to providing an acceptable standard of care and that a case should be made for the insurance company not to have to pay the basic default payment.

That is a long way from any insurance company using this—I am not quite sure how you could even suggest that it could be used that way—to heavy hospitals into signing an agreement. It is not possible for that to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what circumstances could a registered organisation apply for a determination?

—Only if evidence relating to the guidelines was provided to the organisation responsible for the standards might a private insurance company have it brought to its attention that a hospital, which was or was not signed on to that private fund, was below par. It might then say, `That is very distressing; we will make an application to the minister that the hospital be considered for removal from the basic table.' That is the only way it could do it.
—Extrapolating on that answer, who would make the complaint to that insurance organisation?
—Any number of people could. The industry itself might notice something and ask that the committee have a look. It could be patients, doctors, nursing staff—it could be anyone.
—In light of that reply, the minister will understand why the Private Hospitals Association is concerned about this amendment. Anybody can come out of the woodwork and make a complaint—whacko!
—No.
—You have just said that, minister.
—No, I have not. You asked me who could bring a concern to the attention of the private insurance companies. I understood you to be talking about poor standards of care.
—Whose allegations?

—They are not allegations. If there are concerns about standards of care, this amendment discusses a process by which those standards of care can be properly measured against a set of guidelines. People do not rush off and say what you are suggesting my words were meant to say. This is designed precisely to avoid mischievous bagging or denigration of any institution. That is why we have an accreditation process.

PARA.TAB: As to how these things would come to the attention of the private insurance companies, that could be in all of the ways I mentioned. I thought you were asking how an insurance company would know that a hospital was not up to scratch. A whole lot of people might draw that to the attention of an insurance company.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with theoreticals. That is what legislation is all about; we cannot control everything that occurs. So how would an insurance organisation apply to the minister, once negotiations had broken down, when it is unhappy with the quality of care given in a particular private hospital? You said that anybody could initiate a complaint in this regard.
—I did not, Senator.
—Who filters the complaints?

—We could be here forever trying to answer your hypotheticals. This amendment proposes establishing guidelines against which the standards of care of a hospital could be assessed. If they were judged to be insufficient, an application could be made to the minister for certain things to follow, such as cutting off the basic table payment of benefits.

PARA.TAB: You asked how an insurance company might know that a hospital was under investigation, or that is what I understood you to ask. This is designed to stop mischief but a whole lot of people might want to know where they can go if they are unhappy with the standards of care of a particular hospital. Instead of just bagging the hospital they could go to this organisation and put in a complaint. There will be a way for people to make a complaint if that is what they want to do. Most people will not want to do that. Things have to be pretty bad to provoke people to do that. However, your question—I do not really understand its relevance—is about whether a private health insurance organisation which is in the process of negotiating with a hospital—

TALK.START.PARA: —After negotiations have broken down.

—If it has a contract with the hospital and the hospital is then judged not to be eligible for payments, I think the private insurance company would be informed, as it says in the legislation, by the minister, who has to make available to everybody concerned the fact that this hospital is now deemed to be unsatisfactory, and private health insurance organisation would no longer pay.
—We will be opposing the amendment because it should be fairly apparent to everybody that there are too many uncertainties in this amendment. We are not prepared to give a blank cheque.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crowley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (38)Schedule 2, page 27, item 69, proposed paragraph 82G(ba), add at the end ", being information of a kind determined in writing by the Minister for the purposes of this paragraph".

This amendment allows the minister to determine the kind of hospital casemix protocol information that organisations may submit to the Private Health Insurance Administration Council, or PHIAC. Such an amendment ensures that PHIAC only receives information that is necessary in order for it to carry out its functions, including that of enabling persons to make informed choices about private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 21Schedule 2, page 27, omit item 69.
22Schedule 2, page 27, omit item 70.

These items will delete proposed new subparagraphs 82G(b) and (ba) and 82G(m) and (ma) of the National Health Act. Section 82G relates to the functions and powers of the PHIAC. These proposed paragraphs would allow the PHIAC to obtain sensitive patient data from insurers which the insurers have obtained under the hospital casemix protocol for the purpose of `evaluation modelling and research' and for public information for the making of informed choices on private health insurance. This matter is now taken up by using our proposed item 17 provisions as the basis for industry consultation and negotiation on data needs. As I say, I believe it allows them to obtain the data from insurers for the purposes that have been mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept these amendments. There certainly have been a number of claims that the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council's proposed task of collecting and disseminating data is impossible or very difficult. It certainly would suggest that consumers would find the task equally impossible or even more difficult. If it is hard for the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council, then how difficult is it for consumers? Consumers are then left relying on intuition, prejudice, inertia or something else with regard to decisions on health insurance. If we are trying to encourage people to take up health insurance, we are not going to be able to do that if we do not assist them with the best possible information.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, a person in such an environment who is not holding insurance would find it very difficult, if not impossible, to make an informed choice. That, very likely, would be an encouragement or an inducement for that person not to be bothered to take up or to move to private insurance. That, of course, is quite contrary to the intention of this legislation, which is to encourage increased insurance amongst the population.

The government believes it will be a difficult task for the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council but the council will find it a lot easier than consumers will. As the intention of this legislation is to assist consumers by giving them that information so they will be assisted in considering taking up private health insurance, anything we can do to assist consumers will be of benefit. This will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: does the letter that Senator Lees tabled previously in relation to the information that was available also cover the purpose of `evaluation modelling and research' for the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council?
—No. I am advised that they will get only the information that is necessary for them to be able to advise consumers.
—Who will determine that, the department?
—That will be determined by the minister and it will be a disallowable instrument. So, effectively, parliament can have a say.
—I missed the last sentence.
—It is a disallowable instrument so effectively that means it will be given to the parliament.

—I am still slightly amused about this, Minister. You mentioned that this legislation is aimed at encouraging people to take out private health insurance at a time when the government has increased the Medicare levy. You mentioned it, Minister, not me. I will be quite fascinated to see the outcome of this legislation. You said that, that being the intent, more information should be available to people to find out whether they should become privately insured or not; yet you are saying that you will not accept our amendment to make it easier for people to get that information. I find that difficult to follow.
—Which amendment is that?
—The amendments that I have just moved.
—The advice I have received is that your amendments will stop PHIAC being able to collect the information and provide it to consumers.

—That is not so. The purpose is to delete those paragraphs which relate to the functions and powers of PHIAC. That would still allow the information obtained under the hospital casemix protocol to go to consumers. It would appear that we agree to disagree on this.

—As I understand it, Senator Herron is removing the words `collect and disseminate information about private health insurance for the purpose of enabling people to make informed choices about private health insurance.' If those words are removed it is as clear as day that there is a reduction in the amount of information available.

—We went through this earlier. The minister told me that the material contained in the letter to Senator Lees regarding privacy considerations may or may not be applicable. Could I rephrase that? Would the material that was in the letter to Senator Lees be applicable or not?

—I am advised that the letter sets out the information that would have been provided to the department and what the department would have done with it. It makes clear that the information provided to PHIAC would only have been information to enable it to provide information sufficient to assist consumers about matters of private insurance.

—The committee passed my previous amendment in relation to privacy issues. It would seem logical for the committee to pass this amendment which is also related to privacy issues. There is a connection between the previous amendment and this amendment in relation to the dissemination of information.

—The government's logic is of course different from yours: ours is logic, yours is not. As I have just read out, this is going to restrict the information available to people. It is not principally a matter of privacy, it is a matter of concern that adequate and appropriate information is provided to consumers.
—We will obviously agree to disagree.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on two reports which are very important—one of which has been before the Senate and one of which supports the concerns raised in that Senate report. It is a report by a number of concerned people in my home state of Queensland. The report which has already been presented to the Senate is entitled Drugs, money and governments—A report by the Alcohol and other Drugs Council of Australia.

PARA.TAB: A supporting statement of concern has been prepared by the Biala and Wacol support group—a group of people who have been not only concerned but more and more deeply concerned about the cuts in funding by the Queensland government for alcohol and drug rehabilitation in Queensland. The concern is underlined by the fact that cuts have not been equal, in any sense, to a decline in alcohol and drug abuse; rather, the abuse of these drugs continues to increase. I want to remind the chamber of some of the recommendations which were made in the report by the Alcohol and other Drugs Council of Australia. I turn first of all to recommendations 1, 2 and 3, which read:

SPEECH.PARA: 1)Funding available for prevention, research, education, intervention and treatment of drug related problems should be increased and sustained.
2)Governments need to ensure that adequate treatment programs and services are available to all people experiencing drug related problems.

3)Governments must begin to involve non-government organisations, local communities and consumer groups in the process of decision making, especially in areas such as service delivery, research, policy development and planning.

These recommendations—and they are very good ones—ought to be set against a background of the reality of the cost of drug abuse in the Australian community. Again I read from the council's report. It states:

In 1992 there were an estimated 26,335 deaths in Australia due to drug use. Of these drug-caused deaths, tobacco amounted for 71.6%, alcohol for 25.9%, and other drugs 2.5%. Legal drugs have the greatest impact on the health of Australians, and this impact is becoming more noticeable in specific populations, such as youth, women, people of Aboriginal descent, offenders and those experiencing mental illness (dual disability).

The report also goes on to list the performance of the various states. I want to commend, in this regard, the performance of the Northern Territory. It has obviously addressed this problem in a very serious way. The report, in relation to the territory, states:

As part of the Living with Alcohol Program, an alcohol levy has been introduced in the Northern Territory, which has generated an additional $4,906,000 of revenue, all of which is spent directly on drug programs and services.

One State stands out in funding of drug programs per head—the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory has the smallest population, and spends the most funds per head on drug programs and services ($55.90).

I am disappointed in the performance of my own state, Queensland. I would like to put on the record just some of the results from the tables which are included in this report. Table one lists the expenditure on drug programs and services through state health departments. The funding per head in Queensland is the lowest of all the states and territories at $4.40 per head. The report goes on to say:

In most States there is no clear and direct accountability of funds. In some States, where funding is provided to regions, there appears to be no requirement for these regions to either inform where funds are actually spent or to account for funds earmarked for specific purposes. Because of this, there is no guarantee that funds allocated to drug programs and services are actually being expended in this area.

I return to the issue of revenue from alcohol and tobacco taxes. Again, my own state performs very poorly in this area. Out of the revenue returned to drug programs, the Northern Territory is again at the top, returning 24.3 per cent of the revenue to the programs. Unfortunately, my own state returned only 2.9 per cent. I am putting this on the record not simply as a criticism but in an attempt to urge my state to address this very serious problem in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The survey results overall show that in many of the categories my state is last. For example, in identifying the extent of drug problems, Queensland is seventh; in the priority of addressing drug problems, it is seventh again; in ensuring that information is available to the community, it is seventh; and, in ensuring treatment programs and services are available, it is eighth. Just to show that we do perform better in some cases, in a clear strategy to address drug problems, we come second. I might add that it is not much use having a strategy if we do not fund that strategy adequately.

I turn to the statement of concern issued by the Biala and Wacol support group. Amongst many other concerned citizens and organisations in Queensland, I am one of the signatories to this statement. The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We undersigned representatives of trade unions, community organisations and church justice groups, hereby call on the Premier Mr Goss, the Health Minister Mr Elder and State Government in the interest of community and worker health . . .

to do a number of things. In other words, this is not simply a report which is critical; rather, it is a report that puts forward positive suggestions about what ought to be done. These recommendations include increasing expenditure on alcohol and drug dependency services, reversing the cutback to the Biala centre in Brisbane, giving a firm undertaking that the remaining six triage beds at Biala will be maintained, and reopening the 60-bed Wacol rehabilitation centre.

PARA.TAB: I would like to support the report of this group. Many of the people in the group have been through drug and alcohol rehabilitation programs themselves. They know exactly the benefit of those programs to themselves, and that is why they are concerned to ensure that such programs are maintained.
Let me close this submission to the Senate by reading the conclusion of the report from the support group. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The gutting of Biala, the closure of Wacol Rehabilitation Unit, the inadequate funding of alcohol and drug dependency services, the denial of treatment to many prospective patients while the health ministry promotes the deceptive concept of underfunded community-based referral programmes, highlights what many consider to be an emerging crisis in alcohol and drug dependency services in regions in which we are familiar namely Brisbane north and south and the west Moreton region.

From speaking today to one of the authors of the original report by the Alcohol and other Drugs Council of Australia, I do understand that there is a lot of pressure being applied to the Queensland government, and there are some signs that there will be a response to this issue in the coming budget of the Queensland government. That is why, in placing on the record today the concerns that many people have, I do hope that that pressure and those concerns will result in an improvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate a communique which was issued as a result of a meeting in Canberra by the Constitutional Centenary Foundation on 6 to 8 May. Some 120 constitutional experts, eminent people and community leaders attended this convention.
—Thank you, Senator Kemp!

—Including you, Senator Woodley. Congratulations! I think it is an important convention, and it is an important communique. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that over the last 12 to 18 months there has been a fairly vigorous debate in this chamber and elsewhere about the role that parliaments should have in the consideration of international treaties. This debate has resulted from growing community concern about the way this government goes about its treaty making activity.

PARA.TAB: A number of eminent Australians have strongly endorsed the view that parliament should have a greater role in the scrutiny of treaties. I bring to the attention of the Senate two papers—one by Sir Ninian Stephen, a former Justice of the High Court and former Governor-General of Australia; and one by the Hon. Justice Michael Kirby, who is the President of the Court of Appeal in New South Wales. Both those eminent people recently made important speeches which called for the greater involvement by parliament in the treaty making process.

In the brief time available to me, I would like to quote an extract from Justice Kirby's paper, which was delivered in February, entitled `Human Rights—The International Dimension'. Justice Kirby said:

Some important treaties have been ratified with little Parliamentary or public debate. The growing body of treaty law has an increasing impact on Australian law. It therefore seems legitimate, in some way, now to involve the national Parliament in the superintendence of Executive action in respect of treaties. The old rule may have been apt for a time when international law was in its infancy. But nowadays, in economic matters as well as those relevant to human rights, the growth of international treaty law is extremely significant and growing even more important. Whilst I understand the politics of resistance to Parliamentary scrutiny and would regret a move to the United States requirement of advice and consent of the legislature, which has proved such a reinforcement of isolationism, there is surely an intermediate position. Parliamentary scrutiny is not the same as Parliamentary approval. Scrutiny could be part of the larger function of raising Australian awareness of the growing body and importance of international law.

SPEECH.PARA: Similar comments were made by Sir Ninian Stephen who pointed to the democratic deficit which was growing as a result of the large number of international treaties and instruments to which governments are adhering. I understand in recent days even Sir Anthony Mason joined the debate when he called again for greater public debate on the way treaties are affecting Australian law.

PARA.TAB: Three particular examples which have generated widespread public debate come readily to mind. The first one is the ratification of the first optional protocol which involved the UN human rights committee in our Australian legal system. I bring to the attention of the Senate comments on this matter by Anne Twomey who wrote a paper entitled Procedure and practice of entering and implementing international treaties. That paper was issued in February this year. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the treaties tabled after having already come into effect are of great importance to Australia.
In other words, the parliament was told after all the processes had gone through. She continued:

For example, the First Optional Protocol to the ICCPR was tabled on 26 November 1991 after the Government had deposited its instrument of accession on 25 September 1991. There was no other Parliamentary debate or legislative scrutiny before the First Optional Protocol was acceded to by Australia. Given the great impact that this treaty has already had on Australia, being the catalyst for the recent Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act 1994, it is extraordinary that the Government acceded to it without any public debate or even public awareness of its existence, let alone its scope and significance.

That is one of the cases which has given rise to widespread public concern. The second one, hours before the last election, was the ratification of ILO convention No. 158 on the termination of employment. That particular convention was ratified over the objections of virtually all the states—even Queensland—and over the heads of many of the business groups which were consulted, with the sole exception of the ACTU which strongly supported it. Nonetheless, it was ratified hours before the writs for the 1993 election.

PARA.TAB: The government omitted to inform not only the parliament that such a thing had happened—parliament was presumably not sitting at that time—but also omitted to inform the community. That particular action by the government, Senator Evans and Mr Brereton has given further widespread concern about the treaty-making activities as practised by the government.

The third issue which has come to recent public attention is the Teoh case. Honourable senators will be aware that the High Court decided that when the executive ratifies an international treaty, provided there are no statutory or executive indications to the contrary, a legitimate expectation is created that administrative decision makers will act in accordance with the treaty. Should the decision makers not act in such a manner, procedural fairness requires that the person affected be given the opportunity to persuade them otherwise.

Without going into the details of the Teoh case, the implications of that are seen by many people to be a matter of widespread concern. In view of the fact that there are so many treaties that Australia is now party to—some 900—the implications that this may have on the way law is administered in this country is a matter of public debate and concern.
The communique which was issued by the conference is important because it recognised that parliament should have a role in treaty-making activities. The conference communique stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: The conference expressed support for greater transparency and wider consultation in treaty making processes, particularly through the involvement of parliament. Concern was expressed at the difficulty of determining what obligations Australia had undertaken through international treaty-making. There was support for the proposition that the existing register of treaties should be amended to clarify these obligations.

Clear support was also expressed for greater involvement by the States in treaty-making processes. The conference supported the proposition that a Treaties Council should be created, associated with the Council of Australian Governments, and that prior to ratification after signing, the Federal government be required to bring treaties before the Council for agreement. However, in the event that agreement cannot be reached, the Federal government should not be prevented from proceeding to ratification.

There should be a requirement that treaties be tabled in both houses of the Federal parliament prior to ratification and after signing, together with a statement of the implications for Australia of accession. The conference expressed strong support for the establishment of a joint standing parliamentary committee on treaties, with a power to conduct hearings and take evidence from the general public.

I point out to senators: now we not only have some of the very eminent law makers in this land calling for greater involvement by parliament in the treaty making activities, we also have a conference which has issued a communique which gives strong support to that position, that parliament should have a role to scrutinise treaty making activities more effectively. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there is one person and one person alone who is opposed to this tidal wave of support from the community for this position, that parliament should have a role, and that is our very own foreign minister, Senator Evans.

PARA.TAB: I will quote what Senator Evans said to the conference. This is what Senator Evans, who portrays himself as a man greatly concerned with human rights and the democratic process, said. Senator Evans said that treaties should not be subjected to the vagaries of parliament. But I am delighted to inform the Senate that that particular position has no support. It has no support amongst some of the most eminent jurors in this land. It has no support amongst the delegates who attended the Constitutional Centenary Foundation convention in Canberra last weekend.

I remind the Senate that, as far as the coalition is concerned, the coalition has overwhelmingly and by consensus embraced the need for greater parliamentary scrutiny and consultation with regard to the treaty making process. We have put forward a variety of specific proposals which will bring that into effect including, of course, our proposal to establish a treaties council as part of the COAG process.

To conclude my comments: it has been an important debate. It is a debate which has been in this parliament and in the wider community. In my view, Senator Evans has comprehensively lost that debate and it is now time that the government recognised community sentiment, that parliament must have a role to scrutinise and to give a view on the treaty making activities of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, during this public interest discussion, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the 50th anniversary of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition to Macquarie Island will be celebrated in 1998. I make a request to the government and the scientific community that this 50th anniversary be appropriately recognised and celebrated. Apart from the Macquarie Island expedition, there were two other ANARE expeditions and operations in 1947. They were to Heard Island and the Wyatt Earp exploratory expedition to the Antarctic continent.

PARA.TAB: Macquarie Island is 33 kilometres long, five kilometres wide and lies some 1,300 kilometres south east of my home state of Tasmania. It is the last green outpost before the landscape turns to ice, although because of the climate it is treeless. It may be of interest to honourable senators to know some of the history of Macquarie Island and the reason for my request through this chamber to the government.

The first expedition to Macquarie Island left Australia on 28 February 1948. The party consisted of 13 members who travelled via Hobart for a 12-month stay in order to establish a permanent base as well as undertake scientific research. Members of the group were Alan Martin, leader, meteorologist; William Monkhouse, meteorologist; Ron Chadder, meteorologist; Geoff Mottershead, radio; Gersh Major, radio; Peter King, radio; Charles du Toit, chef; Dr Roger Bennet, medico; Ron Kenny, biologist; and Charles Scoble, who was the engineer. Unfortunately Charles died on 4 July 1948, and I will refer to that tragic incident later. Then there were Charles Leigh Speedy, known affectionately later to his many science students as Leigh Speedy, Ken Hines and Norm Laird. Leigh Speedy was not only a great academic but also a fine sportsman. He was later to become a college principal and minister of the Uniting Church.

Travelling on the HMAS Labuan, the party reached the island on 7 March and a camp was set up at Garden Cove. Heavy gear and equipment—such as a bulldozer, generators and huts—were landed by pontoon rafts. It took until 21 March to complete the unloading, with the loss of several rafts and one boat due to unpredictable currents, thick kelp, hidden rocks and strong winds.

Conditions onshore were extremely difficult with driving rain, bitter cold and deep mud to contend with. However, the first huts were completed and the party then set about establishing themselves for their 12-month stay. The work of this party was identical to that carried out on Heard Island: daily transmission of meteorological data to Australia by radio, cosmic ray studies and topographical, geographical and biological surveys of the island.

One of the members, Charles Scoble, the diesel engineer, was unfortunately drowned while skiing over a frozen plateau lake. He was buried beside the lake which is now known as Lake Scoble. Charles Scoble left a young wife, Margery, and two lovely little girls—Rosemary aged four and Heather aged two—who were too young to remember their father or understand the tragedy. A number of years later the Scoble family—his widow and two daughters—prepared a plaque for his grave and it was taken down to Macquarie Island by Doug Speedy, a nephew of the first expeditioner Charles Speedy, on his second tour of duty.

The photographer on this journey was Mr Norman Laird, the Tasmanian representative. He was one of the senior members of the Tasmanian Film Unit at the time. His colleagues described him as a brilliant still and cine photographer. He was awarded a fellowship from one of the major British societies for his photography of black-browed albatrosses on Macquarie Island.

Australia has a keen interest both strategically and territorially in this island, particularly the state of Tasmania. Since the establishment of this permanent base in 1948, Australia has undertaken scientific research on a continuous basis. About 20 expeditioners—scientists, weather observers and support staff—winter on Macquarie Island each year. A further group of people stay either for a summer or for a few days while the supply ship unloads cargo and exchanges personnel.

Surrounded by some of the richest waters on earth, the island boasts one of the largest concentrations of fauna in the world. In fact, in 1971 the island was declared a nature reserve. Macquarie Island is now administered by the National Parks and Wildlife Service in Tasmania and, in the last few years, it has had a full-time wildlife officer permanently stationed on the island.

Given the significance of this region to Australia, I would hope that appropriate recognition of this important event is given. One suggestion has been that a return visit be arranged for a small party of the original expedition members. Should this eventuate, it would indeed be an opportune time to consider making a documentary film on this area. I am sure such a film would be of great interest to many people to see the significant changes on Macquarie Island since 1948 and how well it has recovered since the sealing days of the early 1900s. Fortunately, the sealing industry was forced to abandon the island in 1919 and, in 1933, it was declared a sanctuary. From the decimated stock, wildlife populations have, over the years, returned to former levels and the island once again swarms with life.

A documentary would show the magnificence of Macquarie Island and its wildlife to a very wide audience who would not otherwise have the opportunity of seeing this area of the world. It would also pay a fitting tribute to those who established our presence permanently on Macquarie Island.

I wish to take the opportunity of stating that I was really very privileged to be taught by one of those very senior scientists from that island, Mr Charles Leigh Speedy. Mr Speedy was a scientist of great distinction and, after his time on Macquarie Island, he returned to Australia and gained a masters degree for his cosmic ray research and subsequently took up a teaching position at Scotch College in Launceston.

I think it would be fitting to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition to Macquarie Island in 1948 in some very special way. I ask the minister whether, as part of the commemoration, consideration could be given to arranging a return visit for a small representative group of those involved on that first expedition to Macquarie Island in 1948. As I said, it was during that expedition that the permanent base was established on the island. With such a large lead time required for planning, and in recognising the annual changeover, I believe that my suggestion of a 50-year celebration return party could be incorporated into the normal changeover trip to Macquarie Island. This would enable those travelling to spend a short time on the island while the supply ship unloaded cargo and personnel.

As I mentioned earlier in my address, one of the members of the original expedition, Charles Scoble, died whilst skiing over a frozen plateau lake. As I said, this lake is now known as Lake Scoble. I put it to the minister that, since Charles Scoble was buried beside the lake, it would be a particularly fine gesture to include his wife as a possible member of such a return party, to enable her to see her husband's grave and to place a memorial plaque on it.

Given that Australia has a keen interest, both territorially and strategically, because of the large amount of scientific research that has been carried out continuously since 1948, the 50th anniversary could be a significant event. I ask that members or representatives from the original party be given the opportunity of returning to the island in 1998, and that a documentary film be prepared as part of that particular celebration.

I also wish to pay tribute to the important roles in Australian society that members of that pioneering party have subsequently taken. They have continued to take a most significant role in Australian life, educating young Australians, particularly in the sciences, as well as significantly contributing to the moulding of their character.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the matters of public interest discussion to talk about last night's budget and in particular its implications for older Australians. As people in this chamber know, it has been a passion of mine, long before coming to this chamber, to champion the causes and issues relating to older Australians. Australia has 4.5 million people over 50 years of age. This represents 25.3 per cent of the population—a quarter of the population. There are now over 2 million people over 65 years of age in Australia. This represents almost 12 per cent of the population. It will increase by 20,000 in the year 2031.

PARA.TAB: Older Australians are an increasingly large group in the population. Many sections of that older group are quite vocal and quite powerful but obviously not powerful enough, given the budget last night. The budget handed down by Mr Keating last night virtually ignores older Australians. There are some welcome measures, to give credit where credit is due, but they do not go anywhere near far enough in addressing the crucial issues facing what is a rapidly aging Australian population.

In June of last year, Professor Bob Gregory reported to the government on nursing home funding arrangements and on the recurrent funding. In so doing, he discovered that there were significant problems related to capital funding in nursing homes and hostels. His report revealed that Australia's nursing home industry is facing a crisis, and that is the only word that can be used for this. He estimated that the upgrading of existing stock—that is, upgrading what we have—would cost $520 million.

Now one would think this would be an urgent priority, especially as it concerns one of the most vulnerable groups in our community, the frail aged. But what do we have from this government? A budget allocation for overcoming the problem of poor quality nursing home buildings, which amounts to only $33.4 million over four years. People do not have to be brilliant mathematicians to divide four into 33 to find out what the government is spending on nursing homes per annum. In view of the state of some of the nursing homes, that will not even touch the sides.

What we are doing is leaving a problem that is getting progressively worse; it is not going to get any better. Each year it will get significantly worse and the stock will deteriorate, yet the government is doing nothing about it. I was cynical enough to think, before the last election, that it did nothing because it thought it was going to lose and then we would wear the odium of the declining stock in nursing homes. But the government has not done much about it even now.

Professor Gregory, in a report the government commissioned, has alerted it to a serious problem facing Australia, that there is a decline in nursing home stock. In the end, the next generation will have to pay for that because there is the baby boom coming through and there will be an increased demand for nursing home stock. Some of those nursing homes are 30 years old now and those nursing homes, even with the best will in the world on the part of the directors of nursing, and with the best will in the world on the part of the staff, are operating under circumstances which are not satisfactory. That is the sort of thing that Professor Gregory found.

The other thing that I found very disturbing was that people with dementia were virtually totally ignored in this budget. I do not know what people have to do to convince this government that there is a major crisis out there in the community concerning people who require residential care. As I said, to give credit where credit is due, the government has increased funding to carers. They are the people who stay at home and care 26 hours a day or 30 hours a day because that is the sort of day it is. It is night-time, too, and sometimes the carer is up two, three and four times a night with somebody who is wandering or incontinent. Those carers put in 24 hours. They cannot go to the shop because the person for whom they are caring may light the stove or may use matches. Matches have to be hidden; electrical appliances have to be put away. They live constantly with the anxiety of the person, their loved one, who is no longer capable of behaving in a rational, predictable way.

Fortunately the government has seen fit to have an increase in funding there which, while not sufficient, at least is a response to the obvious needs of carers. But the government has not responded at all to those people who can no longer care for someone with dementia, either because it has become too difficult or because they are ill themselves. I do not know why minister after minister in the health portfolio, such as Minister Howe, Minister Richardson—I do not think he addressed it—and now Minister Lawrence bury their heads in the sand and do not accept the fact that we need dementia specific facilities for people with behavioural disturbances with dementia.

There are people with dementia who do not have severe behavioural problems, who can be integrated with older people in nursing homes. But it denies the rights of residents who do not have dementia. When there is a person with dementia who goes into someone else's room, who rifles through their drawers, who may do other things in the room—and I will not go into the details here—who is noisy, who is disruptive, who interferes with the rights of residents in the nursing home, then we have to consider the rights of the residents as well.

Whatever is the block in the department or the government, wherever it is—and the government should have the will and the wit to do something about it—nursing home after nursing home after hostel that I visit all argue that they need an area where they can segregate people with severe dementia with behavioural overlay, so that they can look after them, give them appropriate care and reduce the stress on other residents. But the government will not have a bar of it, and again the budget shows that they have not heard the plea of those in the industry who give their all to caring for people with dementia, that there is a special need for people with dementia who have behavioural disturbances and behavioural overlay.

The other thing that I found interesting in the budget was that the government has put some money aside for health promotion and illness prevention measures. But who gets left out of that? Older people. We put them on the scrap heap as far as health is concerned. There is a plethora of studies that show that older people who exercise can actually reverse the effects of osteoporosis, and that they can gain muscle strength. It is not all downhill, with exercise and with care in the prescription of drugs.

One of the other areas where we see a decline in health is in the effects of polypharmacy, where care is not taken over multiple prescription drugs being taken by older people, and the effect that that can have on their health. We can help health promotion in that area by encouraging older people and doctors to monitor the prescription drugs that these older people are taking, plus the over-the-counter drugs that they are taking—antacids or whatever else. Older people need to be educated about the interaction of those with prescribed drugs; but older people have been forgotten in the health promotion package of this budget.

Older people have also been forgotten in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Those older people who do not have a health care card, especially those who are on the cusp of being eligible for one, now find that they will have to reach a threshold of $600 before they get their pharmaceuticals at the rate of $2.60. I am sure a lot of older Australians who have made every effort to provide for themselves will find that a blow.

The other thing that they will find a blow is that they will now be required to pay an increased Medicare tax. None of this levy business: it is a tax. That is what it is, a tax. Their Medicare levy/tax has gone up, but I bet they do not see their waiting lists shortened for it. Many of them will struggle to pay their medical benefits, and they will also be paying their increased Medicare levy/tax. There is so much to go on about that I have lost my place for a moment. There is issue after issue.

Another issue that has come to light in this budget is that there will be a new pension income assessment. This is not before time. For ages, the coalition has been arguing for the repeal of the legislation which treated capital gains on shares as income for the purpose of assessing tax. I expressed my concern about this when the legislation went through the house, and we said that in government we would review it. Unfortunately for Australia and for older people we did not get into government at the last election.

To keep that promise as much as I could, I put a private member's bill in this place to have it repealed, and I argued that there should be an inquiry. We set up an inquiry into incomes and assets tests in this place through a notice of motion. The government would not agree to it. Nor would the Democrats, because the Democrats said that the government was going to have its own inquiry. So, in conjunction with the Democrats, we put a motion forward that if the government did not put down terms of reference for its inquiry into the capital gains on income being assessed for purposes of the pension, our inquiry would take place. That was a sword that we hung over the government, and it did put the inquiry into place. But, as Aged Care Australia says, it has not really responded in great detail to that inquiry. The government should not have needed to have an inquiry. That should have been done beforehand.

We have seen many pensioners concerned about the small amount of money that they have saved for emergencies: not, as people have said on the other side, many who have got heaps of money who are trying to get the pension and fiddle the books, but many who have saved over years to buy shares. They have saved to buy shares in order to have a small income and to be able to meet the difficult things that happen in life: things like the refrigerator breaking down, the gas heater blowing up, or the roof needing retiling. They have bought shares to have that bit of money for emergencies.

Some people have sold those shares now because the fluctuations in their income were so great that they could not tolerate them. Honourable members sitting here in the chamber know that when the share prices were going up we had pensioner after pensioner coming into our offices concerned about the fluctuations in their income. Since there has been a decline in the market there has not been as many people coming in, but it was just an outrageous thing that the government did and it has taken this long to do something about it. That is another way in which older people have been treated in a very shabby way.

The mature age allowance had a sunset clause on it and was to end in 1996. After this the government says in the budget there will be a modified mature age allowance. Do honourable members know why we need a mature age allowance? The answer is because there are so many older people who have been put on the scrap heap of unemployment and who have now joined the ranks of the long-term unemployed. That is why we need the mature age allowance. Many of those people do not want to be on a mature age allowance. They want to be working. The government has had to create a mature age allowance because of its economic mismanagement. This is another signal to older Australians of what the government has done to their country, the country that they worked their insides out to build up only to be squandered by the government. Many of these people are victims. They have to go onto the mature age allowance because they cannot get a job. There is an army of people with skills and abilities who are on the scrap heap.

What about older Australians who thought they were going to get tax cuts? Mr Keating promised them tax cuts. There is nothing in it for older self-funded retirees. They do not benefit from any compensation in superannuation payments. Senator Sherry, tell me what you are going to say to self-funded retirees who were given a promise by Mr Keating at the last election, `You will get tax cuts.' That promise has been broken. In this budget the government has let older Australians down abominably and it will stand condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Patterson has pointed out, there has been a fair amount of concentration on Mr Keating's broken promises, the breach of faith, the breach of trust and the breach of the basic undertakings given by Mr Keating during the 1993 election campaign when he said it would be intolerable and improper to introduce a GST that would raise $22 billion. By the way, the GST would have had many offsetting benefits like the huge 19c per litre reduction in the price of petrol which would have massively benefited people in non-metropolitan Australia, rural Australians, many of whom were struggling against the disaster of drought and who had no other basic form of transport to rely on other than their motor vehicles. That GST policy would have resulted in an enormous reduction in country costs, and particularly costs of transport.

PARA.TAB: We can all remember not only the breach of faith in Mr Keating's rejection now of his promises to reduce tax but also we remember him saying, `These tax cuts are not just promises. They are l-a-w, law.' The `l', the `a' and the `w' were simply misplaced. Juggle them around a bit and we find that the tax cuts have gone AWL, absent without leave. If we insert an `o' in that we get AWOL. The `o' is what Australians have got out of these l-a-w tax laws—they have got zilch.

While everyone has been concentrating on Mr Keating's breach of faith in winning the last election by deception, people have forgotten what he has done. I hope people realise that the $22 billion GST, which Mr Keating said was intolerable, has now been exceeded by Mr Keating's own tax rises.

Under Mr Keating, since the last election total tax collections have increased by $25 billion. What did Mr Keating say about a plan that would raise $22 billion and be mainly offset by other tax cuts? He said that it would be disgraceful to raise $22 billion, and yet, sneakily and secretly, he has added $25 billion to Australia's tax bill since the last election.That tax rise—the evidence of it is on page 4/57 of Budget Paper no. 1—shows an increase from $94 billion in the 1993-94 budget to $119.3 billion in this budget. The figures are getting to be so incredibly large that they are almost beyond normal comprehension.

It took the Fraser government seven budgets to raise its total increase in taxes by $24 billion. In other words, Mr Keating, since the last election just two years ago, has increased the tax take more than the Fraser government did over the whole of its time in office. Mr Keating is the biggest taxing Prime Minister and/or Treasurer in Australia's history, and yet he went to the people at the last election swearing not only that there would be no increased taxes but also that taxes would be cut and that it is l-a-w.

The Prime Minister said that the Opposition is disgraceful for seeking to reform the tax system to reduce many taxes and then having an offsetting GST. The Prime Minister won that election on that totally dishonest campaign which has now been demonstrated to be crooked and which has been followed by a selection of tax rises far greater than the $22 billion included in the GST and far greater than the total increase in tax revenue over the whole of the Fraser period in government. The Prime Minister could do that—this low tax and tax cuts are l-a-w Prime Minister—and he could do that in the two budgets in the two years since the March 1993 election.

We should recognise that it is a bit worse than that, because the Medicare levy is not counted as a tax. It is, in fact, a tax—a tax to pay for part of the cost of medical care—and that levy has gone up, too. I have not included that in the $25 billion. I have not included the superannuation situation, because that superannuation arrangement is, in effect, a social security tax. It is a social security tax aimed at reducing the cost of payouts of social security by the Department of Social Security in the long run. It is not a voluntary method of saving; it is an effective social security tax. I have not included that in the record $25 billion increase in tax collections under Mr Keating.

No government in Australia's history has ever increased the tax take by as much as Mr Keating has in the last two years, and yet he went to an election promising tax cuts. What level of deception is involved in that? What political dishonesty! How disgraceful that this man, having done that, promises in this budget that, ultimately, there will be further benefits to Australians: just trust him. Trust him? After this performance? Most of the so-called benefits in this budget do not take place yet; they take place in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the next election.

—As my friend interjects, after the next election. Senator O'Chee knows full well that after the next election the extraordinarily untrustworthy—in tax terms—Mr Keating will not be there to implement these promises. In other words, once again we have the same technique: these phoney promises, these nonsensical claims about what he will do, when it appears from past performance that he never had any intention of doing them.

PARA.TAB: Laura Tingle has a very perceptive article in today's Australian. She points out:
In 1992 and 1993, Paul Keating promised us around $14 billion of personal, company and other tax cuts.
After last night's Budget, he will go to the next election having introduced new taxes worth $13.4 billion over the life of the current Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to leave us about lineball but in fact it does not; it leaves us a lot worse than that. Laura Tingle continues:

PARA.TAB: This does not include about $20 billion of increased taxation, which the Government has helpfully calculated as being raised in coming years but which (thankfully for Labor) only hit in the next parliamentary term.
Oh, and the Prime Minister will have only delivered about $9 billion worth of the tax cuts he promised us.

SPEECH.PARA: So she makes this conclusion:

PARA.TAB: Rather than being $14 billion better off in terms of tax collections—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, under the l-a-w law promises of Mr Keating—
we are $18 billion worse off in terms of new taxes imposed, or tax cuts not given, on an increasingly rickety revenue system.

Instead of $14 billion better off, we are $18 billion worse off. That is a $32 billion turnaround involved in a total tax take of about $119 billion. That is an enormous proportion; it is an incredible proportion. As Laura Tingle says:

PARA.TAB: It makes you wonder, really, why Keating fought so passionately to save us from the horrors of John Hewson's $22 billion GST.

SPEECH.PARA: She goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The new tax measures announced last night will raise $2.4 billion this coming financial year and $16.7 billion over the rest of the decade. That's $16.7 billion on top of the $10.168 billion in 1996-97 flowing out of the 1993 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, there have been $27 billion in new taxes. That far exceeds the total of tax increases over the whole period of the Fraser government. Ms Tingle says that Mr Keating:
. . . is finishing this parliamentary term with the tax system looking like a dog's breakfast.

I would think it looks more like a dog's regurgitated breakfast. This is just unspeakable. But I might say that Mr Keating has returned, as one would expect—as I understand dogs do to their vomit—to the same system, the same structure, the same style of tax deception which he has not only practised as Treasurer but perfected as Prime Minister. Laura Tingle concludes:

PARA.TAB: We are in a bizarre situation where the political rhetoric says the electorate will not wear higher taxes, and we have been taxed to death in new ways for the last three years.

SPEECH.PARA: What intrigues me about this is that Laura Tingle seems to be the only political analyst who is a wake-up to it. Certainly, many of the political analysts have quite properly being dramatising the fact that Mr Keating has broken his tax promises. Mostly, they seem to say, `So what did you expect? Hasn't he always?' So it is not very exciting; it is not news that Mr Keating has broken a tax promise. It is anticipated; it is normal; it is taken for granted.

PARA.TAB: Laura Tingle's article here not only dramatises the sordid extent of Mr Keating's deception, but also indicates—when backed with these figures that are available in the budget—that Mr Keating is, by design, the biggest taxing Prime Minister in Australia's history. If he set out honestly and decently along that line to say, `Yes, I intend to increase your taxes; yes, I am honest enough to come to you to say that we think there should be a bigger tax burden,' at least we could accept that he had gone to the people on that basis. If he had been honest and said, `I am going to tax the pants off you; I am going to increase taxes by more than anyone ever has in the history of Australia,' at least people could then have made their decision at the last election, knowing that was what his policy was.

But his policy was exactly the opposite. His policy was to oppose tax reform. His policy was to object to a system used in almost every other industrialised country in the world and to oppose it on a dishonest basis in such a way that one was given the clear impression by Mr Keating that, not only would he not introduce such a tax system, but he had tax cuts waiting for us because they were l-a-w law. I must say that it is not simply the company taxes which are going up. That has, of course, caused an immense furore in the company ranks because, after all, he had said during the last election that the reason company tax was to be cut was to make Australian companies more competitive with Asia. Of course, that has now been cancelled. We do not have to be competitive with Asia any more, apparently.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has bypassed us.
