—That is right, Asia has bypassed us. So Mr Keating has reversed that undertaking given oh, so recently. So here we have a dog's breakfast—a dog's regurgitated breakfast—of a tax system. We have been, as Laura Tingle says, taxed to death in new ways for the last three years. I hope that the Australian people recognise what Mr Keating has done to them when they have the opportunity to express their opinion of his honesty, particularly on tax matters, at the polls at the next election.

—In this debate on matters of public interest, I wish to raise just a couple of matters that have come to my attention in my role as the coalition's spokesman on regional development and infrastructure matters. I might say, just by way of a preliminary remark, that last night's budget again does nothing for regional Australia—it completely ignores regional Australia. The taxes that have been imposed, which will affect every Australian, do impact more heavily on those of us who live in that part of Australia remote from the capital cities.

PARA.TAB: It is a budget that really is a fraud. As my colleague Senator Michael Baume and others before me have said, it is a fudge-it budget, one that attempts to use mirrors and smokescreens to try to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian electorate. Certainly as far as regional Australians go, it will be pay, pay, pay and no benefit whatsoever. The joke is that the Medicare levy goes up yet again, so regional Australians pay more for a health service which is very secondary and the government does nothing about it.

In my role as the shadow minister for infrastructure, I am disturbed that the Labor Party has sold capital assets to balance this year's current budget, has done nothing to retire long-term debt and has done nothing to reinvest some of those proceeds from the sale of capital assets back into capital assets which will bring a return to the nation. So certainly as far as regional Australia is concerned, this budget gets the very deliberate thumbs down.

I raise a few other matters that have come to my attention as the shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure and in my role as chairman of the coalition's regional task force. Very briefly, the first one I want to mention is the drought in Victoria. For some reason, Victorian farmers who are really very severely hit by the drought have been ignored by this government. A few weeks ago, a RASAC committee inspected the effects of the drought in the central Victorian region near Seymour. I was fortunate enough—although it was very distressing—to do the same tour and I looked at the same properties as the RASAC committee.

Although the area looks a little green, it is clearly in a drought situation. There is absolutely no feed and the farmers have some very distressing tales. These people on the land have had to put up with drought and with four or five years of negative income. So far this government has turned its back. I particularly congratulate and thank Mrs Fran Bailey for arranging my visit to the area and for pointing out the plight of these people to me, so that we could raise the matter. I certainly urge the government to do something to include those people in these grazing lands in central Victoria in the ambit of the drought relief.

Another quite separate matter that I wish briefly to touch upon is the cost of accessing electronic information, particularly by people in regional Australia. I claim to have no expertise whatsoever in the electronic dissemination of information and this will probably become fairly obvious as I continue to speak. It has been told to me by users in regional Australia that they are getting a very bad deal from the Commonwealth government. As I understand it, not all information from Commonwealth government departments is available through the information technology. Where it is available, it is available through different agencies. I understand that ABS and the Bureau of Statistics are on Ausline, which is a contract of the federal government, whereas CSIRO and the Australian Securities Commission are available from other information providers and not from Ausline.

The cost of accessing federal government information is very high, particularly for regional people compared with other available services. It has been pointed out to me that the Queensland government—and I express some surprise at this—has an information provider called CITEC which is very good. All Queensland government information is available through CITEC and some Commonwealth information is available through CITEC. But the Commonwealth information available through CITEC is cheaper than it is through the Commonwealth government's preferred information dissemination agency. For people in regional Australia, particularly people who do not often access these information systems, the Commonwealth system is very discriminatory. I am told that a joining fee has to be paid of $145. Then there is a monthly service fee of $240; there are dial-up access charges; and there is a search service. The total cost of a single inquiry or just a couple of inquiries is very high. In one instance, as much as $413 was quoted to me. That is because the joining fee and the monthly service fee have to be paid whether the service is used 100 times or just once.

The Queensland system, by comparison, is simply made available on a charge basis when people dial it up. They get a 008 number to get to the service, so it does not matter whether they are ringing from Brisbane, Sydney or Canberra, or from the far-flung regions of Queensland: the cost of accessing the information is exactly the same, so it is fair to people from regional Australia who want to access it. But the Commonwealth service is on a system where the further they are from the database, the more expensive it is, because they pay more or less the cost of a trunk line telephone call. The Queensland system, which uses a Freecall access device, is much fairer for regional Australia, so I would urge the federal government to have a look at that. I have had some correspondence with Senator Cook and Mr Lee about it. I might say that the responses I have had, which I have referred to people who know what they are talking about in this area, have not been well received. It has been suggested to me that the Commonwealth government is, as usual, being its inefficient self in this very important area.

Madam Acting Deputy President, the last thing I want to raise again relates to regional Australians. It is a matter that I have raised in estimates committees and had some correspondence with the government about, and it relates to the little town of Cardwell, near Hinchinbrook Island, on the North Queensland coast. Cardwell is a town that has had a pretty rough trot of it all the way through. Senators would be aware of the government's insensitive and quite stupid role in stopping work on the Port Hinchinbrook development site. That project would have provided hundreds and hundreds of jobs for that little community, which is in a very high unemployment area. I was in the area last Friday night. I am told that the development is not proceeding, in spite of Senator Faulkner yelling at me across the chamber that it is all going ahead. I understand that nothing has happened since last November-December, when Senator Faulkner stopped that work and cost all those jobs.

I understand that the local council has approved it. I might say that it is a council chaired by a Labor chairman: a good fellow, Councillor Tip Byrne. He is a Labor man, but you should hear what he has to say about it! Perhaps I had better not put him into the brine so much, but he is certainly not very pleased with his counterparts in the Labor Party and the role that they have played in this, because he knows what the project would mean to his shire just as everyone else does.

But that is not really the point that I want to make—although, as I say, Cardwell seems to do pretty poorly at the hands of the federal government. Not only is there that issue, there is the issue of the Battle of the Coral Sea Memorial Park. The people of Cardwell—just a group of very ordinary Australians—got together a few years ago without any government assistance and built a magnificent park on the mainland overlooking the Coral Sea athe point nearest to where the Battle of the Coral Sea took place over 50 years ago. They have got out and made a magnificent park with a lot of individual memorials and many dedicated trees have been planted by descendants of the people who were involved in that battle.

They have never sought much from the government, but what they do ask for every year is that the Commonwealth government might allow some of the defence services—the army, the navy or the air force—to march in their parade. They had been granted that in previous years. They applied again this year, but this year they had no response. I tried to get in touch with the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, to get him to authorise it, but I did not even get a response to my letters.

The thing that I really wanted to talk about in relation to Cardwell and Hinchinbrook Island is a matter of public safety: in fact, in many instances, a matter of life and death. There have been instances in which lives have been lost along the Australian coast because there were not sufficient radiophone and seaphone facilities. There was recently an incident near Eden on the New South Wales coast where lives were lost because the environmental agencies of the Commonwealth government had refused to allow transmitters to be installed. That was fixed by the Commonwealth government. We have a similar situation on the coast near Hinchinbrook Island, where there was recently a search which had a lot of trouble because of the absence of a radio communication facility. I am not going to have enough time left to me to go into it in detail because it is almost Question Time, but I do urge the government to take some immediate action to ensure that a radiotelephone transmitter can be installed in that area to protect lives of Australians.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister that before the last election Paul Keating promised not to put up tax. After the massive fuel and sales tax slugs in the 1993-94 budget, I ask: why are you now imposing a 12 per cent sales tax on home building materials; increasing sales tax on cars by five per cent, adding a thousand dollars to the cost of an average car; increasing the company tax rate by three per cent; increasing tobacco excise by 10 per cent, adding 30c to the cost of a packet of cigarettes; ditching the l-a-w tax cuts; increasing the Medicare levy yet again; abolishing the sales tax exemption on recycled paper, and increasing migrant application fees by 40 per cent? How do you justify compounding the electoral fraud of past budgets? Why should the voters not punish Labor for its lies? Why should the community ever again believe Paul Keating?

—Mr President, Senator Hill's question is based as usual on a totally false premise which was that we made a promise not to make any tax increases at all. It will be remembered, as the Prime Minister said in parliament last December, that what he said in 1992—and you are welcome to go back and check the record—was that the government will be keeping tax within the tax to GDP ratio of the previous few years. It is the case that between 1989-90 and 1991-92 the tax to GDP ratio wobbled about between the range of 22.7 and 24.7. The budget estimates last night were that in 1995-96 tax revenue to GDP will be 24.2 per cent. That will increase to 24.6 per cent next year, still within that parameter, and then it will decline. The government is accordingly meeting that undertaking.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that a number of the revenue measures that have been introduced, particularly the one on cars, for example, were simply a matter of restoring a tax rate that had been reduced as an anti-recession measure to generate and encourage more spending in that particular area. It was not the expectation of anyone in the industry, or of anyone in the community, that that particular tax cut could be perpetually sustained. It is the case, of course, that the l-a-w tax cut, as you refer to it, will in fact be delivered as it was promised to be delivered.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be delivered in a different form, and it will be delivered as to an even greater amount in the form, of course, of the government contribution to superannuation. It will be delivered in a far more constructive form so far as the overall state of the economy is concerned because it will be so spectacularly adding to the nation's saving performance and in a far more equitable form because that tax cut will now be delivered as a government superannuation contribution in a way that specifically benefits low income earners.
—Why didn't you say so at the time?

—The reason you are shouting and bellowing over there is obviously because none of you are going to benefit from that particular tax cut delivered to you in that form, as a superannuation contribution. Your incomes are going to be beyond the range at which you can benefit. You are squealing, and you do not like it because this is an equitable measure. It is an equitable measure and an immensely socially and economically responsible measure.

PARA.TAB: The final thing to be said about all this is that it needs to be understood that the Australian levels of tax that are imposed and the Australian level of revenue collection are dramatically low by international standards. It just is the case that in OECD terms we have the second lowest national revenue base as a source of revenue in the world with only the United States below us. We know what the public sector in the United States is like in terms of its capacity to deliver effective infrastructure and social justice to all the people in that particular country. We would not as a nation want to have our revenues reduced to that level. We are the second lowest taxing country in the OECD, the industrialised world, the traditional standard of comparison. We are also the second lowest country in terms of the proportion of outlays to GDP.

You have not asked me about expenditure; no doubt you will be too embarrassed to do so because the question is now on you, in the light of this budget: what would you do in the future; what you do any differently; and where would you make the outlays reductions if you are to take this process any further? The point is you are denuded of any capacity to respond intelligently on this matter because you have had every one of your clothes stolen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up the question that has just been asked. My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Last night the government announced its historic and audacious budget in terms of the turnaround in the deficit and a national savings plan. I ask the minister: what is the government's response to market and community responses to these announcements? What is the government's view of the implications for the future wellbeing of workers and companies as a result of these changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a widespread consensus in Australia before the bringing down of the budget that it was necessary, if possible, to bring the budget into surplus, to address the problem of national savings and to continue what this government has achieved: strong economic growth with low inflation. The budget has delivered on all those things, thus meeting the expectation hurdles that were set up before the budget was brought down last night.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will know that it delivers a surplus of $718 million in this budgetary year which is, significantly, the largest ever turnaround in the deficit, bringing the budget into surplus three years faster than was originally forecast. While much has been made of the fact that there is a substantial asset sales program included in this budget, the point is that the budget will be in surplus next financial year by $3.4 billion net of asset sales.

There has also been a significant structural tightening—significant by any measure—with the turnaround from deficit to surplus being a change of $12.8 billion. The strong fiscal discipline that was exercised in this budget will ease pressure on interest rates and on inflation as well. That is the best possible macro-economic setting for business to operate in.

Understandably, there has been some criticism from the business sector of the increase in corporate tax. Any interest sector affected by budgetary change will criticise that change. But the overall macro-setting is strongly supported by industry. In private discussions I have heard with many of Australia's business leaders, what has come through quite clearly is that, while people do not want further tax changes to affect them, if there were a choice they would prefer it to go this way than to have what many of them see as pressure being put on interest rates, with a possibility of further interest rate rises down the track. Let some of Australia's leading businessmen speak for themselves. As Paul Simons, Chairman of Woolworths, said today:

ANSWER.PARA: We have only had the 33 per cent rate for a couple of years but now it is back into the middle ground which is where, perhaps, it should have been all along.
Adding to the public sectors savings achievements, the new superannuation—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said at the last election.

—That is a direct quote from what he said. Dr Vince Fitzgerald, the author of the 1993 report on national savings and who recommended compulsory employee superannuation contributions in it, has welcomed the contribution of workers' superannuation payments and the government's contribution to it. Today he said:

ANSWER.PARA: It means that most people would get a much better retirement income as a really good level of retirement income half their working life income in super and for many people much higher than that after their full working career.
Let me turn to the financial market reaction to the budget—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The level of interjection is far too loud. Senator Cook has the call.

—Financial markets have rallied strongly in recent weeks in expectation of a significant fiscal tightening in the budget and interest rates have fallen further since the delivery of the budget, which has more than validated the market expectations. Long bond rates have fallen from over 10 percentage points at the end of March to 8 3/4 per cent, including a fall of three-quarters of one percentage point over the past week. The all ordinaries index has risen 1 1/2 per cent in the past week.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude with this quote. Paul Robertson of Macquarie Bank was interviewed this morning and summarised the market reaction stating:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . generally the trend this morning has been pretty positive. The market's had a chance to stop and look and read all the fine print, and basically it's a thumbs up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I would like to ask the question that Senator Carr really wanted to ask but was not able to. During the heat of the last election campaign, Paul Keating gave a solemn promise to the Australian electorate: `We remain committed to maintaining a majority stake in the Commonwealth Bank.' Last night, in what must rank as the lamest excuse ever put forward to justify electoral treachery, the Treasurer said the decision was made because `it was psychologically necessary to go into surplus.' Why was cabinet not consulted, let alone caucus? Why has there not been even a whimper from the so-called Left? Has the Labor Party sunk so low that it is now forced to sell off Ben Chifley's silver to pay for Paul Keating's economic mismanagement? When will you get yourself a leader who knows the meaning of honesty?
—There has not been a whimper from the Left, and there has not been a whimper from the community.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not count as a whimper. The Left within the Labor Party, being the responsible economic managers they are and having the keen understanding they do of economic realities and economic disciplines, completely understand that this was a rational and sensitive policy choice to make. The truth of the matter is, as Martin Ferguson said last night, whatever status the Commonwealth Bank might have had as a people's bank in yesteryear, it certainly has not had that status for the last 10 years or so. For all practical purposes, the Commonwealth Bank has been operating as an ordinary commercial bank.

PARA.TAB: We have been generating a couple of hundred million dollars of revenue from it annually, but the contribution that it has been making to our public debt interest obligations has exceeded that. We can make a much more substantial contribution to economic management, to improving the public sector savings position, by selling it. We made the decision to sell it for that reason. It is a decision that has been perfectly well understood within the Labor movement. It is a position that has been perfectly well understood by the bank board itself that has cooperated actively in this process because it has seen the advantages for it.

It has been perfectly well understood in the media, where it has hardly attracted a blink of an eyelid of attention, and it has been perfectly well understood in the community. The only people who do not understand it are those in the opposition. The reason they do not understand it is that they are either too stupid to understand the economic significance of what I am saying or they are getting upset that they have now lost their last bit of independent capacity to make a difference to their own budget activities if they ever get the chance to do so. The only couple of billion dollars that you had left in your policy locker was flogging off the Commonwealth Bank. Now we have stolen those clothes from you too, and it is no wonder that you are the ones whimpering about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I applaud the government's new maternity allowance, which is a highlight of the agenda for families. Can the minister inform the Senate of the government's commitment to families outlined in the agenda?

—I take this opportunity to welcome Senator Jacinta Collins to the Senate and thank her for this very important question. As the agenda for the family shows, this government did what it set out to do in the International Year of the Family. It listened to families and it has responded to their concerns, especially the concerns expressed during that year. One of the things that people told us was that families were the most important factor in all of their lives. They also made it clear—and we recognise this—that families provide care as no government or any other agency can. The best thing governments can do is support families in the role that they play.

PARA.TAB: As the Prime Minister said in the agenda, the greatest help government can give to families is a strong economy and the jobs and opportunities that go with it. The agenda contains initiatives that directly affect the needs of families. As Senator Collins alluded to, high on that list of benefits to families is the maternity allowance that will give women greater financial support particularly at the time of the birth of a baby. It is equivalent to six weeks of the parenting allowance that is currently worth $816.

Along with that major initiative there are major increases to assist families in juggling work and family responsibilities. To help them do that the government has continued the growth in child care, particularly in freeing up 31,000 child-care places by better targeting child-care funding to working families and ensuring at the same time that families with a parent at home have access to significant occasional care. For many families that will be a significant increase in their occasional care.

Families in rural and remote areas will benefit from $7.5 million for 500 innovative child-care places. I have to say, Mr President, my office has already been rung today by the Women in Agriculture organisation with a very loud thank you for that commitment to child care.

We will be boosting our assistance to children with special needs. There will be something like $17 million over four years through the support of the SUPS program to child care to assist families with children with a disability and children from non-English speaking backgrounds. And we are going to be fast tracking more flexible child-care places while we continue to build our community based child care, targeting of course those places to the areas of highest needs.

Our continuing commitment to child care will mean 12,000 new family day care places, 8,000 new places in community based centres and 40,000 new outside school hour places to be achieved by 1999. All these measures help parents balance their dual roles in work and caring for families.

Unlike the opposition, we have not just discovered families. Our achievements in this budget build on our commitment to families over the last 10 years. We now spend over $12 billion in direct assistance to families. We have services like Medicare and education. All of those things that you know well about but do not want to accept, we have put on the record.

In this budget we directly continue and extend achievements for families and a commitment in the agenda well beyond this year. It is an extraordinary record for families. You should be, as the government certainly is, very proud of those achievements for families, and I thank the senator for her question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Minister for Industry, Science and Technology representing the Treasurer. Minister, leaving aside all that sort of smooth tongue rationalisation about the Commonwealth Bank, how can you explain the difference between the $718 million surplus on page 1 of your budget paper and the $8.2 billion deficit on page 401 of the document—the figure which is used by the ABS, the Reserve Bank and the national fiscal outlook? Why the difference? Did you not think we would read to page 401?

—We presented all of the papers so that you would read all of the papers and so that all of the figuring in the budget is transparent, open and accessible to the public and placed on the public record. We did that quite deliberately, as is the tradition of this government, so that allegations of the sorts that have arisen overnight from people trying to confuse the electorate about the meaning of the deficit can be, in fact, properly and intelligently explained.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I should say about this is that the way in which we have calculated the deficit—or, in this case, the surplus of $718 million—is consistent with the conventions and criteria laid down by the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations for calculating these figures. That is the absolute truth, Senator. It is the same method by which we calculated the budget deficit last year—a deficit, as you will recall, of $12.8 billion. It puts us into a surplus this year of $718 million and a surplus the following year, 1996-97, of $3.4 billion, which is the largest turnaround in the budget in the history of Australia.

I might say this was done with revenue two per cent lower than when the budget was last in surplus. But the true difference here, in differentiating between the figures that you have given us and the figure of $718 million surplus, is that people take the budget deficit or the budget surplus to be what call on financial markets the Commonwealth will make. That is the important criterion. The answer to that is that we are not making a call on the financial markets because we are in surplus this financial year.

I have here Budget Paper No. 1, statement no. 7. You will see on page 7.3 a table—`Table 2, Adjusted ABS Deficit'. It refers to a figure of $8 billion for 1995-96, but you ought to read the introduction to this to get an understanding of what the adjusted underlying deficit is. The important thing here though is that if you compare the year 1994-95 with the forthcoming budget year of 1995-96, what we have set out to achieve structurally—a significant fiscal tightening to take pressure off interest rates and to keep inflation low—is achieved. These figures report a $7 billion turnaround or a $7 billion reduction in that deficit.

I come back to the central point which differentiates all of these figures: what does the common citizen believe the deficit to be and what is the debate about the deficit? The common citizen, in my understanding, believes the deficit to be the call on financial markets the Commonwealth will make. That is the figure that we have given in both the budget speech and in the budget papers, and it is a proper and accurate reflection under all the international conventions for the compilation of budgets. That is the figure the public is entitled to believe; that is the one it should believe. That is the true figure, in the common layman's understanding of budget deficits—the call on the financial markets.
There are two other points that I should make and they go to the issue of asset sales. Asset sales do reduce the Commonwealth's call on financial markets. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What does the common citizen think about the accuracy and professionalism of the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations compared with the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Treasury and the Reserve Bank, which actually used the other figure in their calculations? Minister, do you not think the budget should be presented in a way that does not allow governments to distort things away from the professionally accepted outcome because your bottom line is hidden, is it not, and you know it?

—Mr President, the bottom line is not hidden. The bottom line is open and transparent. The fact that these figures are here is proof of it. But one has to differentiate between what the figures mean. People might want to abuse the figures for political advantage but the facts are true. The IMF and the United Nations set down the criteria. We have followed them. We have always followed them. They are the right criteria.

PARA.TAB: What the ABS is reporting is a different calculation entirely from the common understanding by lay people of what the budget deficit is. Their understanding is, as the table says, an adjusted ABS budget deficit. The explanation, which is too long to read into Hansard, is on page 7.2 of that document. I suggest that it be examined by honourable senators in this chamber so there is no confusion.

The fundamental of all of this debate, short of every political sally and argument, is that what we have said about a surplus is the proper and accurate presentation. The budget papers do not fudge on any points like that. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. In recent times there has been considerable discussion about the benefits brought to the environment by the government.
—A lot of debate—a lot all right!

—May I say, that it is a very good contribution under a very good minister and I am glad to see that the other side is acknowledging that. In any event, the question is: can the minister define what real

QUESTION.PARA: contribution to Australia his portfolio will presently be making?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth will provide more than $220 million in 1995 to fund a range of programs in the environment portfolio. This represents an increase of 21 per cent on last year's funding for the environment. By any measure, that is an excellent budget outcome for the environment. The budget includes extra funding for a range of carefully targeted, carefully integrated new programs to protect some of our most precious natural assets. I can assure the Senate that this increase in funding will provide some very real benefits for the Australian environment.

PARA.TAB: For example, the new funding will provide a package to improve the management of Australia's coasts. It will provide a new program to assist in the phased implementation of the national strategy for the conservation of Australia's biological diversity. It will provide a program to identify and assist in conserving Australia's wilderness and wild rivers. There are also initiatives to encourage the collection and recycling of high-grade wastepaper, including a major effort to increase paper recycling from government offices. It will provide improved conservation and management for Australia's wetlands. It will provide extra research and monitoring to look after the Great Barrier Reef, which is, of course, under significant increased pressure from tourism. It will provide significant funding to see the implementation of the national forest policy statement.

Importantly, the budget also enables the Commonwealth to continue its strong support for its environmental agencies and programs. The $220 million includes ongoing funding for a range of core activities. There is an increase in base funding and ongoing and additional funding has been provided for very important programs like the environment resources information network, the National Environment Protection Council, air quality management, environment industry initiatives, identification and conservation of the national estate, and the management of protected areas.

In what I think is an extremely disciplined and responsible budget it is very gratifying to see the significant recognition that the government has given and the importance that the government places on the environment. This substantial funding will ensure that the federal government can play a central role, as it has in the past, in the protection of Australia's precious environment. In this country, where our environment is so much a part of the Australian way of life, this Labor government has again shown its strong and absolute commitment to green issues.

Anyone who cares about the environment, anyone who is interested in the future of this country—and, again, it can be rammed home—can see the difference between the level of commitment from this government and the absolute sell-out of environment policies from the opposition. There is no commitment, of course, from the opposition to Australia's environment. It remains hell-bent and dedicated to destroying it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the small business survivors of the government's monetary massacre—those who were not among last year's 14,000 bankrupts and the 70,000 bankrupts of the past four years—and ask: can the government explain why it has again hit the remaining small business survivors with a provisional tax uplift factor of eight per cent, which is double the growth rate and double the headline inflation rate? For small business to meet its provisional tax obligations, surely the uplift factor should be levied at the inflation rate of four per cent. Is this not just another budget fudging revenue grab at the expense of small business?

—Before we brought down this budget, we had from the coalition cries that this budget had to be a strong budget, it had to be in surplus and we had to have a national savings plan. We also had complaints that there ought to be more expenditure across a range of social programs and education and health issues. We had all of that. We had cries about less expenditure and more cutting, but also about more expenditure for our favourite programs.

PARA.TAB: No-one approached this budget in a cavalier fashion. No-one approached this budget without the recognition that it was going to be a tough budget to frame. The important issue for the government in framing it was to make sure that the ordinary Australian is provided with a secure future in this country, because economic growth will continue on a long-term sustainable basis with low inflation. We would also address the issue of national savings. That is what we have done. The macro outcome that we have achieved offers a growth factor for the Australian economy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I thank the minister for his lesson in economics. But I asked about small business and the provisional uplift factor. He is two minutes into his answer. Could he use his remaining two minutes to address the question I asked.
—There is no point of order.

—My answer is entirely ensemble. It is right to the point. The most effective thing a government can deliver for small business—the interests of the small business community are to the fore in the government's mind—is a strong macro-economic outcome and an outcome of sustainable growth. We have had to make adjustments to the taxing regime in the business area. I also point out that all of our small business support programs that go to skilling and helping business to be more competitive and giving better market intelligence are intact and providing a dividend in making small business more competitive. But no-one is saying that when one deals with issues to correct the national macro-economic setting there will not be some areas in which there is some pain.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the uplift factor has been altered, but not in a way that, in our view, will militate against the further growth and development of small business. As I have said, the creation of AusIndustry, the continuance of all our business support programs and, through Austrade, our international network to support export and market development overseas create the right environment. That is not to mention the full tax imputation provisions, which remain intact for small business. They enable small business to effectively absorb some of the taxing costs that are occurring in this budget. All those things still create an environment for long-term sustainable growth of which small business will be a major part.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. He will be aware that there have been ongoing efforts by Queensland government members and senators to gain a more equitable share of allocated tertiary places to match Queensland's population growth. Both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training have made commitments to boost higher education opportunities in Queensland. Will he indicate what measures have been taken to deliver on those commitments.

—I certainly acknowledge the interest of Senator Reynolds, a Queensland senator, and other government senators in this issue. The budget will deliver the federal government's commitment to the people of Queensland. It provides 4,200 new tertiary places over three years—1,750 in 1996 followed by a further 1,500 in 1997 and 950 in 1998. With the flow-on effects of these places, there will be 12,335 additional funded places in Queensland universities by the year 2001. This honours the federal government's commitment to boost Queensland tertiary places in line with the significant population growth in that state, particularly in the 17- to 34-year-old age group. The government recently made a down payment on this commitment in deciding to fund 500 growth places in 1995.

PARA.TAB: As a total package, the government's commitment will ensure that the higher education participation rate in Queensland equals the national average by the end of the decade. This means that Queenslanders will enjoy the same access to higher education as other Australians. The maintenance of access to higher education for Queenslanders will not be achieved at the cost of a loss of opportunities elsewhere in Australia. Over the 1996-98 triennium the new places will cost a total of $129 million yet there will be no redistribution of existing places from other states. There will be no increases in HECS and, of course, no introduction of tuition fees.

This is a very important outcome from what, of course, has been a tough fiscal budget. In order to support the growth in student numbers, Queensland institutions will also receive significant funding for capital infrastructure. This includes an extra capital grant component included in their general operating grants, which have a value of just over $1 million in 1996 rising to $6.89 million annually from 2001.

In addition, $42.8 million will be provided from the capital development pool over three years to support new campus developments. Queensland institutions can expect to receive a significant proportion of the funds available through the capital development pool over the period 1999-2001. Institutional allocations will be announced shortly, following discussions with the Queensland government and universities in that state. The government is very proud to be able to announce this decision which is a significant improvement for tertiary education for Queensland, with its high growth rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. After 12 years of a Labor government and 13 budgets, is it true that Australians are facing over the next 12 months increasing prices for their goods and services; increasing foreign debt; at least 800,000 of their fellow workers out of jobs; increased charges for health care, new cars and even the hardware they use to maintain their homes; the loss of their legislated l-a-w tax cuts, together with an even greater amount of tax being sucked from their pockets through indirect taxation; and a horrific current account deficit of historic proportions? What has the Australian nation to show for the 12 wasted years of this tired and deceitful Labor government?

—What Australia basically has to show is growth that is running at a sustainable level now of close to four per cent, which is higher than was ever achievable on any sustained basis at any time in the distant past. Also, that growth is occurring at the same time as underlying inflation is running at about two per cent and it is expected to be maintained at not much more than that for the foreseeable future.

PARA.TAB: Australians are living in a country in which there has been a massive increase in the work force since 1983, such that, if we had the same participation rate now as was the case in 1983, unemployment would be running at just over four per cent. There has been a massive increase in the work force; nonetheless, unemployment is coming down. We are targeting eight per cent this year, and are expecting to get to five per cent in the not too distant extended future after that, which is a rate that is far better than is being achieved in any comparable country in the world. One has only to look at what is being achieved in the United States, Europe and elsewhere to know that, as difficult as the unemployment situation is, we are doing better than most other countries.

We have an investment regime in place which is delivering increased investment of over 20 per cent in the current year. That is expected to be maintained at very significant levels in the future. That is in the context of an economy which has become infinitely more competitive and capable of delivering ongoing standard of living increases to the Australian people than was ever the case in the protected, cosseted, inefficient economy that the opposition used to manage more than 12 years ago.

We have an interest rate regime applying at the moment which is delivering mortgage interest rates lower than was the case at any stage through the 1980s and which can reasonably be expected to be sustained at this kind of level for the foreseeable future as a result of this particular budget, with all its responsibility, taking so much pressure off interest rates and adding, as it does so spectacularly, to our savings capacity both in the short and long term.

We have an economy which is firing on all cylinders and which can reasonably be expected to maintain that condition for the indefinitely foreseeable future. We have an economy that is immensely structurally sound as a result of all the micro-economic changes that have been made, all the productivity bargaining, all the wage bargaining, and all the responsibility of the trade union movement that has been poured into producing the kind of economy that we now have. We have achieved all this at the same time as, in terms of international comparisons again, we have a lower proportion of outlays to GDP than any other industrialised country but one on our calculations—but two on the OECD calculations—maybe the United States and Japan, whichever way we choose to calculate it. But we are right down there at the very low end of the outlays spectrum.

In terms of total revenue—not just the Commonwealth, but the states and everything else—as a proportion of GDP, Australia is the second lowest revenue raising country in the world. This is an economy which is in remarkably good shape on all the particular fronts I have mentioned. The Australian community recognises the necessity for this kind of budget to be put in place at this stage in a way that will sustain it for the future.

The opposition's response to the budget, as nakedly revealed by all the questions that we have had, is that those opposite have completely run out of alternative options. They have no idea what they would do were they ever to be in the unhappy position of being in government. The opposition does not want to increase any taxes. Those opposite say we should be doing more on outlays, but they will not identify what those outlays are. The opposition is just hopeless in terms of its capacity to articulate any credible vision for the kind of economy that this country is capable of sustaining. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. In budget paper No. 1.2.25 we have a forecast that earnings growth will barely exceed inflation in 1995-96. As a consequence of bracket creep, tax increases and indirect taxes—not to mention the compulsory superannuation levy payment—will disposable earnings fall behind inflation after these matters are taken into account? Will that mean that families will either have to work harder to pay the bills or more spouses will be forced into the paid work force? Will increased labour force pressure mean that more unemployed—particularly the inexperienced, the unskilled and the youth—will face greater difficulty in gaining a job?

—I will need to check the figures as to precisely what the projections are for disposable earnings as distinct from average weekly earnings in the comparison with the projected inflation rate. I do not want to give Senator Harradine a misleading answer in that respect. However, I make the point—as he would be acutely aware—that it is not only disposable earnings that are important when we are calculating individual and family welfare. We obviously need to put it in the context of the total available resources being made available to individuals through family payments, through medical support, and through all the rest of the mechanisms that are applicable and that do deliver the accompanying social wage.

PARA.TAB: How those particular figures fall out and what the total bottom line is in that respect I will take on notice and give Senator Harradine a more considered answer at am appropriate time. In this environment of taking into account how the superannuation contribution system will work, we are delivering much more confidence about their retirement incomes so far as the vast mass of ordinary wage and salary earners are concerned. They will be able to look forward now to a future which will not just be based on the pension, as has always been the case effectively in the past, but to look forward to the kinds of returns—either in a lump sum or spread out over years of the order of magnitude that we are talking about—which constitute a dramatic change of circumstances for ordinary Australians. I am sure they are prepared, under those circumstances, to sacrifice some of the immediate short-term dollars in the hand by way of tax cuts and so on in order to achieve that result. I will be happy to give you a more considered answer on your very specific questions when I have taken that on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I will be interested to hear that, particularly if he does so for incomes of $19,000, $29,000 and $39,000. The answer has elicited this further question in regard to compulsory superannuation. When a skilled tradesperson now aged 55 is required to pay a percentage of that worker's income in compulsory superannuation levy, could the minister advise the Senate whether or not the result will be a greater retirement benefit than is so currently the case for the aged pension?
—I certainly assume so, but I will need to take that question on notice in order to give you a precise answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 21 June 1994, I asked you whether you could give the parliament an assurance that no deals had been done by ASIS and Afghan security agents who may have been involved in war crimes or terrorist activities in exchanging intelligence for Australian residency. You replied:

QUESTION.PARA: Certainly, it is my own clear view that no Australian security agency ever has or ever would knowingly assist the entry to Australia of any individual who had been involved in terrorist or war crime activity of this kind.

Is it a fact that a senior officer of KHAD, the Afghan secret service, serving in the Afghan embassy in Delhi, was clandestinely moved from Delhi to Australia, granted refugee status and later permanent residency under the patronage of ASIS? Is it a fact that at least one ASIS officer knew that this person was involved in activities which fell within the category of war crimes? When did you first become informed of this arrangement?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known that we do not comment on matters of security in any detail in the context of any particular case. I am determined to maintain that neither-confirm-nor-deny principle. I still hold by the answer which I gave on very clear advice and with full regard to all the circumstances that we have never knowingly assisted the entry to Australia of anyone guilty of war crimes or terrorist activity. It may well be the case in a number of different contexts over the years that we may have assisted the patriation or the entry into Australia of people who have had some secret service associations. I do not deny the possibility of that, without confirming that in this particular case.

PARA.TAB: But certainly it remains absolutely the case that we would never knowingly go down the path of admitting anyone with those kinds of associations. I do not recall all the circumstances of the particular situation to which you may or may not be referring, but I can remember the issue arising previously at the time I gave that assurance and having in front of me a great deal of advice on this matter and giving a considered response accordingly, not a top-of-the-head one. I will consider further what you have said and see whether there is any necessary change to that response, but I do not believe so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from that, that you will take this question and carefully have it considered by your ASIS advisers, come back to the parliament and give an unequivocal yes or no on this particular case?
—I said that I will give it further consideration in the light of your question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Minister, yesterday you mentioned our involvement in and the benefits flowing from the Uruguay Round, the Cairns Group—all of which are aimed at increasing market access for our products and encouraging businesses to export. Given the importance of improving our trade performance, what has the government done in this year's budget to enhance export activity and, in particular, to assist small- and medium-sized businesses?

—In shorthand, the government has made three changes in the export assistance area as it relates to my portfolio. Firstly, there was the announcement of continued funding of the export access program, which I have to say has been very well received by business associations and the business community. Secondly, we have introduced an export pre-qualification test for new export market development grant claimants. Thirdly, we have reduced the maximum grant under EMDG from $250,000 to $200,000.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Childs says, support for business in its export activities, particularly small to medium enterprises, is very important and the EMDG program is a key element of that. When you get the need for fiscal restraint imposed upon you, it requires all programs to come under review and consideration. The last thing we needed to do was have another review of EMDG in the formal sense; it has been reviewed to death over the years. So we set out to examine the options developed by those various reviews and see how we could ensure that we were getting maximum value for money out of the taxpayers' dollar and make sure the program is being focused on its principal objectives.

The review certainly made it clear in the past that we were getting big export dollars in return for outlays. As I recall, in the report that I outlined to the Senate last year, the ratio was something like 25 to 1—$25 of exports for every dollar spent on EMDG. But we always need to keep these things under review. The government will continue to give substantial support to SMEs through the EMDG scheme. We expect the payouts to increase from $215 million this financial year, 1994-95, to $292 million in 1998-99.

However, there was a concern in some of the reviews—notwithstanding that the overall program was successful—that some of the money was not achieving the export objectives intended because the companies which received the money failed. There is no way one can guarantee 100 per cent success in any program like this—banks, with all their scrutinies, still lend to customers who do not succeed—but we do need to lift the efficiency of our performance in that regard. So we have decided that all companies seeking their first EMDG grant will be required to register with Austrade in the year prior to lodging their first EMDG claim—that is, the first year in which they incur the costs for which an EMDG claim might be made.

However, after 1 July 1996 registered first time claimants will be required to demonstrate a basic export readiness. This is not entirely new. There has always been a requirement for an export plan but we are trying to place an obligation on Austrade to consider the quality of those plans to help ensure that we are spending the taxpayers' dollars efficiently.

The other thing that we did was reduce the maximum grant from $250,000 to $200,000. This maintains the small to medium enterprise focus of the program. Nobody who spends less than $415,000 a year on export promotion will be affected by this change. So there will be no change for the 93 per cent of claimants below the biggest companies making the biggest claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is that going to save you?

—It is in the budget papers—a lot of money. In terms of the priorities of a tight budget, when we had to look at how we could focus more effectively, these were considered to be the two most effective measures we could take. The export readiness test and the reduction of the maximum grant from $250,000 to $200,000 indicate continuing support for an important scheme within the context of necessary fiscal restraint.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last night his government abolished the tax cuts it promised before the last election. It promised instead to give the money back to the workers as a contribution to their superannuation after the next election—assuming, of course, that that promise is not broken as well. Why did the government decide to neglect the self-funded retirees who have now lost the tax cut and are long past caring about contributing to superannuation? Will the Leader of the Government apologise for deceiving these people at the last election? Will he also apologise for deceiving the pensioners and the part-pensioners whom his government promised to take out of the tax system by 1995 at the latest—another broken promise?

—The government is not inclined to apologise for introducing still greater degrees of equity into the Australian system, not least so far as retirement incomes are concerned. We are certainly not inclined to apologise for doing things that are economically totally responsible. It is the case that the new superannuation proposal is one of the most responsible policy initiatives that has ever been taken in this country. We have notoriously had a very low savings ratio in this country. We have notoriously needed to make some major policy changes to increase that ratio. You lot have talked about that often enough, but we have actually delivered.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question that the minister was asked was about self-funded retirees, not about workers in the work force getting superannuation. I ask that you ask him to address the question about self-funded retirees and the fact that they are not getting their tax cuts.
—I am explaining that the reason why the second tranche of those tax cuts are not going out in that particular form is that the government sees that there are more—
—You are speaking to the point of order, are you?
—No.
—I do not think there is a point of order because he is developing his case.

—I was treating that as an interjection, which is a more proper characterisation, I think, of the nature of it. The reason we are going down this particular path and not spending the second tranche of the tax cuts in that way but rather diverting that government payout in other directions is that, taking into account all the needs of the Australian economy and needs of individual Australians, those point towards going down this particular path. Obviously it would be desirable, from the point of view of self-funded retirees, to be able to deliver them tax cuts. But there are lots of things that are desirable that are simply not attainable and not achievable. There are more immediate priorities in terms of the economic needs of this nation and in terms of the needs of other retirees in this country who have hitherto had to simply rely on pensions and who badly needed some form of supplementation of this particular kind.

PARA.TAB: It will be remembered that this is the government that actually brought forward the first round of the One Nation tax cuts and, together with the additional rebate for low income earners that we delivered in the 1993-94 budget, actually delivered substantially more to taxpayers—all taxpayers, including self-funded retirees—from the first round of tax cuts than was in fact promised before the 1993 election. That has conveniently dropped out of your rhetoric, Senator O'Chee, but that is the truth of the matter. We delivered more in that first round and this other measure than was the case in the promise before the 1993 election.

Deferring the second tranche of the tax cuts was extremely widely understood and accepted by the Australian community because it took place against the background of an immensely difficult task of fiscal consolidation that we faced. It was stated in the 1993-94 budget that those cuts would be deferred until fiscal conditions permitted, probably in 1998. I do not think there were too many people who were looking with absolute certainty to the achievement of those cuts in 1998. Certainly, Senator O'Chee's rhetoric before this budget suggests that it was inevitable that those would disappear completely off the horizon. They have not disappeared completely; they have just been rediverted down a different channel, a channel which is far more economically responsible and a tremendously significant response to the needs of the Australian national economy at this particular point of time.

This will enhance, rather than detract from, national savings. If you are going to bounce to your feet again and say that this is irresponsible, or something or other, it is about time you offered some positive suggestions as to what you lot would do to enhance national savings, to reduce the impact of all of that on the current account deficit, and to reduce the interest rates pressure that is involved in going down that path. You know—or you ought to know—that that is the reason we are introducing this particular policy. None of you has said a word about some alternative method by which you would be able to deliver all these plates of pie to every constituency that you have been sucking up to, for as long as any of us have noticed, without any sense of overall responsibility as to how you are going to pay for it. You are full of rhetoric about payouts here and payouts there and tax concessions somewhere else. You are full of rhetoric also about—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that Senator Evans's statement that this was all just sucking up to people and these were impossible promises is an admission of guilt that the promises to cut taxes were in fact dishonest and lies to the electorate. My supplementary question is this: if Senator Evans thinks that taking these tax cuts away from self-funded retirees and failing to take pensioners and part pensioners out of the taxation system is for the good of the nation, does he accept the fact that he is producing, and his government is producing, a nation of Old Mother Hubbards in this country? When they go to the cupboard, the cupboard is bare because the government has taken all their income.
—What I want to know from the opposition, what the Australian community is entitled to know, is how you afford tax cuts, paid in that particular way, at the same time as you can afford—

—I take a point of order, Mr President? The supplementary question was absolutely and patently clear. It was for the minister to respond. It was not within the province of the question for him to seek to canvass opposition policies. He has to direct his answer and not canvass opposition policies.
—I must say it would be better if you did not answer the question with a question, Senator, so could you get on with the answer?
—It is an admissible rhetorical device, Mr President.
—I recognise that.

—I do not propose to dissuade. The truth of the matter is this: you cannot go around offering tax cuts of the kind that you are suggesting should be paid and sustaining that particular offer if at the same time you are not willing to go down the path of outlay reductions across a massively wide spectrum in order to compensate for that. It is not the case that you can offer things of the kind that you are insisting that you would offer.

—Are you going to reinforce that promise? Are you going to get up in public and now offer that again? If you are going to do it you have to match it with expenditure cuts right across the entire spectrum. You are not willing to identify the expenditure cuts in social welfare, in housing, in Aboriginal affairs, in Defence or anywhere else. You are just irresponsible. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. I draw the minister's attention to recommendation 4 of the draft report of the Industry Commission inquiry into charities which proposes that community social welfare organisations should compete with one another by tendering for government funding. Is the minister aware of serious objections to this proposal being raised by the Uniting Church, St Vincent de Paul, the Anglican Church and the Salvation Army amongst others? Does the minister agree that the community social welfare sector operates from a different motivation to the business sector and therefore the application of market principles to the community social welfare sector is inappropriate? Will the minister assure the community social welfare sector that the government will not remove the current taxation exemptions, including fringe benefits tax—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Be quiet over there!
—If you can lie your way into office, I don't see why I can't shout a little bit about it.
—Order! Senator Vanstone.
—which are critical to the operation and financial support of that sector?

—Mr President, this question deals with a draft report of the Industry Commission. Senators will be aware that the procedure for dealing with draft reports is to allow a period of public comment from all of the organisations or entities in the field covered by the report and, based on those public comments, the Industry Commission then prepares a final report which goes to government, and government then responds. My understanding is, and I think the question in fact bolsters this understanding, that the Industry Commission has delivered of itself a draft report and therefore it is putting its tentative conclusions out for public comment and for public alternative strategies other than the ones that it suggests.

PARA.TAB: This question asks me am I aware of the report. Yes, I am. It asks me am I aware of the criticisms of the draft findings that have been made by many welfare groups. Yes; it would be difficult to miss those. They are reputable groups, and their criticisms are bound to be respected and have heed paid to them.

Then the question goes on and asks me what will the government's view be. I have to say, Senator Woodley, through you, Mr President, that I am not in a position to give a view given the procedure that I have outlined before. The draft commentary period should conclude, the Industry Commission should then finalise its recommendations and, upon the finalisation of those recommendations, the government will respond.

But I certainly do encourage you, Senator Woodley, or any other concerned member of the community who disagrees with or has an alternative view of the Industry Commission's recommendations to put those views forthrightly and directly to the Industry Commission so that will assist the commission in framing its final report and obviously, therefore, help in terms of the quality of the government's response as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, a moment ago you called out my name. I was sitting here quietly talking to Senator Newman. I really find it bewildering that you called my name out. Maybe you are short-sighted or could not see, but I was not interjecting at that point.
—If you were listening carefully you would know that I did not call out your name; I called out Senator Vanstone's name.
—It was me and I was interjecting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the level of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am intrigued to note that Senator Gareth Evans has tried to justify the Labor Party's deception on tax. It promised no tax rises. In fact, it promised l-a-w tax cuts on the phoney grounds that Senator Evans presented; that some range of tax to GDP was not only implied but clearly stated at the time of the election. When the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said there would be no increase in tax he meant no increase in the range of tax in proportion to GDP that had existed over some vague period. That is not only bunkum, that is disgraceful bunkum; and no wonder Senator Evans looked so embarrassed in question time today.

PARA.TAB: Let me assure him he is wrong. Just as tax l-a-w has turned into tax A-W-L, absent without leave, his tax statements are w-r-o-n-g. The proportion of tax to GDP—that is, total tax revenues—in 1993, at the time of the dishonest election campaign the Labor Party ran when it said it would reduce taxes, was 22.1 per cent. That is evidenced on page 4/61 of the budget papers. That amount in this budget is now up to 24.2 per cent, a very substantial rise, despite the assurance and word of honour—I use the word loosely—of the Prime Minister that there would be no increase in tax.

Senator Evans, if you want to say, `We meant it only as a proportion of GDP,' let me underline to you that that proportion was 22.1 per cent. You have now increased it massively to 24.2 per cent. It is not just a tax on companies or somebody else, it also hits the ordinary PAYE taxpayers who have contributed almost half the increase in those taxes. The statement by the Prime Minister at that election campaign was dishonest. No kind of fudge-it budget or weasel words by Senator Evans can avoid the fact that at the last election, this government and Prime Minister went to the polls promising no increased tax; and the tax cuts were l-a-w law.

Let me tell you, Senator Evans, that in the last two budgets alone you have brought about an increase in tax revenues of $25 billion, the biggest rise over two years in Australian history. It is more than the total tax rise over the whole period of the Fraser government. In the last two budgets you have brought in a bigger tax rise than you said—in your phoney claims on the GST—the GST would impose on the Australian people. You claimed—and you stood by your Prime Minister when he claimed—that the total cost of the GST would be $22 billion. That is forgetting the offsets, lower taxes and huge reduction in petrol taxes, for example, that would have taken place.

In just the last two budgets you and your government—and you have supported it, Senator Evans—have increased Australian taxes from $94 billion to $119 billion—$25 billion extra. That has been your secret GST and the symbol of your political dishonesty. You have hit the Australian people for a bigger tax rise in the last two budgets than would have taken place, under your calculations, under the GST. This is the measure of this government's dishonesty. This is the measure this budget reveals so dramatically. In these back pages the statistics show what a crooked and dishonest government we have and how we simply cannot believe any undertaking given by any member of this government in relation to tax. There is no doubt that the public knows this only too well. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the latest fulmination from Senator Baume. I will say again to the Senate what I said in question time about that particular issue and the question of the commitments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What he said in parliament last December—and he was referring to what he said in 1992—was that the government would be keeping tax within the tax to GDP ratio of the previous few years. The truth of the matter is that you do not take just one individual year but a series of years. Between 1989-90 and 1991-92, the tax to GDP ratio was between 22.7 and 24.7.

PARA.TAB: The budget estimates of the current tax revenue for 1995-96 will be 24.2, as Senator Baume said, increasing to 24.6 in 1996-97 but declining thereafter. It might also be useful to remind Senator Baume that total revenue and tax revenue as shares of GDP—26.4 per cent and 24.4 per cent respectively—were significantly higher on average over the whole of the 1980s than has been forecast for 1995-96. It was not ever a matter of referring to the tax to GDP ratio or proportion in any particular year and saying that there will be no increase. It was a matter of saying we will be maintaining it at roughly the same ratio or the kind of ratio that has been averaging or applicable over the last few years.

That was the point of the Prime Minister's statement in 1992 and on all subsequent occasions that I can recall. We have stuck to that. We have kept within that band. It is worth making the point yet again that that kind of performance for Australian tax raising and for revenue raising puts us just about at the top of the pops in terms of the OECD countries with which we have traditionally compared ourselves. The 1995 outlays figure for Australia on our own Treasury estimates is 35.9 per cent of GDP, and the OECD estimate is a little larger at 36.6. The comparison is with the United States, which at 33.6 per cent is the only one below us. On the OECD figure, Japan is also lower at 36 per cent. Thereafter for other countries it ranges from Germany, on 48.6 per cent, all the way up to Sweden, on 67.3 per cent, as a proportion of GDP to outlays. The story is exactly the same on the revenue side. It is this that puts into context the claims that Senator Baume is trying to make.

The Treasury estimate for revenue in 1995 is 32.7 per cent. The OECD estimate was 33.6 per cent. Both of those figures are below every other country except the United States, which is on 31.9 per cent as a percentage of revenue of GDP. Thereafter you move up from Japan, on 34.1 per cent, through to

SPEECH.PARA: Sweden—incredibly high—and Denmark on 57 and 58 respectively. Most other countries are well into the 40s. This is the comparison that is entirely appropriate if you are trying to put into context and understand the nature of the taxation burden, the revenue burden—

TALK.START.PARA: —And add state governments when you are making that kind of comparison.
—I am including state governments. The figures I am using are from a briefing table. I am happy to incorporate it into Hansard.
