TALK.START.PARA: —The briefing table shows general government sector—that is, Commonwealth, state and local government—outlays, revenues and balances as a proportion of GDP for OECD countries. It is a very instructive table, because it makes the point—however much Senator Baume fulminates and jumps up and down—that in terms of our revenue raising capacity and in terms of our outlays we are right at the bottom or at the top, whichever way you like to express the table, of those international tables in terms of a very low proportion of revenue to GDP and a very low proportion of outlays.

PARA.TAB: I have one final point. There has been a lot of talk about a tax increase over the last year—in particular, the personal income tax having grown by 13.6 per cent in 1995-96. It should be appreciated that that is not the result of any government decision making but simply much stronger than expected growth in wage and salary employment and in average weekly earnings, at 3 1/4 per cent and 4 per cent respectively.

Other than the Medicare levy increase there have been no major discretionary changes to personal income tax changes, of course, in this budget. The continued strong growth that we are expecting to get in revenue from this source in 1995-96 basically reflects the sustained pace of economic activity.

So all these figures and huff and puff that you can carry on about do not alter those fundamental realities. And those international comparisons are very important indeed in placing this on the total landscape and demonstrating the policy responsibility this government is showing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response we have just heard from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) is typical of the Labor government. Basically, the message to the people of Australia is: you have never had it so good. The simple fact is the people of Australia no longer will swallow that line—they do not believe you. And the numerous questions that were asked today by the Australian Democrats, the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party and, indeed, Senator Harradine, all pointed to the fact of how people in this country will be substantially worse off as a result of this government's budget.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party, clearly, has sold out its traditional constituency. I will look with great interest at the response provided by Senator Evans to the question from Senator Harradine as to how the $19,000, $29,000 and $39,000 per annum income families will get on under this budget.

The simple fact is Labor has once again lived up to its undisputed reputation as the big taxing party within the Australian political arena. But the problem with them is that they seek to deceive the electorate by saying that they are going to deliver tax cuts, get re-elected on that promise saying, `There is legislation, it is l-a-w, it is going to happen, trust us, re-elect us.' And, of course, the people of Australia unfortunately did re-elect them, only to find out that once again the l-a-w was the big l-i-e and there was never any responsible intention to deliver on the promises made.

It was simply a bid by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to gain votes. Indeed, that has now been exposed by the Four Corners program and by revelations today as to how these budgets from the Labor Party are put together. They are not considered documents by Treasury. They are documents with the filthy fingerprints of the Prime Minister all over them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order. `Filthy fingerprints of the Prime Minister' is a little out of order even for this particular senator who is notorious for his squalid references in this place.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—It is a point of debate, Minister; it is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on, `filthy fingerprints' is not a term that is acceptable in parliamentary discourse in referring to a member of another chamber and I ask him to withdraw.

—I will withdraw. I will say that the documents have his fingerprints all over them and the political stunts that the Prime Minister has tried to play with these budget figures have left the people of Australia in no doubt that he has manipulated figures, manipulated the expectations and generally manipulated the whole budgetary process for political purpose only—to gain the Labor Party electoral success.

PARA.TAB: You can fool the people some of the time, but you will not fool them all the time. I can assure Senator Evans, who is so very sensitive about my comments, that the people of Australia will get one good thing out of this budget. The only good thing about this budget is that it will surely be Labor's last budget because they will no longer trust the Australian Labor Party to deal in the manner they have.

What did Dr Carmen Lawrence tell the people of Australia about the Medicare levy? Silence from the Australian Labor Party, but we know what she promised. No increase in the Medicare levy was necessary and of course it has gone up—another broken promise.

We were told during the last federal election campaign, in a very smart move by the Prime Minister, that sales tax on cars would be decreased. That was to match Liberal Party policy. As soon as that election was over, what did the government do? It increased the sales tax on cars yet again. It now has sales tax on the home building industry, which will make the great Australian dream so much more expensive—about an extra $2,000 per home.

TALK.START.PARA: —A thousand dollars, according to the HIA.

—Even if it were $1,000, are you proud of that? Are you saying that is a good thing, to make houses $1,000 more expensive for the average worker, whom you are supposed to represent? You have sold out your constituency.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the only good thing about this budget is that it is surely Labor's last. The first Costello budget will once again bring Australia into a proper economic environment wherein the people of Australia will surely benefit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that the day after the budget is brought down we should have this sort of debate—the tyro senators and the old guard senators in this place, joining forces on the back bench, not attacking the economics of the budget but smearing the credibility of the government.

PARA.TAB: If you cannot play the ball you play the man, and here we have seen an exercise in playing the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), attacking him and trying to smear his reputation rather than dealing with the issues of the budget. That just goes to prove that if you have nothing to say, try to muddy the waters. Senator Gareth Evans, in an earlier answer, gave a considered dissertation on what the taxing situation is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you call it?

—Yes, it was a quite considered, detailed and statistically accurate presentation of the tax arrangements and how the tax changes have occurred. The opposition has studiously avoided reference to the major aims of the budget. While the opposition was part of a chorus of voices before budget day calling for a surplus, it is now part of a minority chorus trying to attack the level of the surplus. The reason is that this is the biggest turnaround from deficit to surplus in one budget in the history of this country.

PARA.TAB: As I said in answer to a question today from Senator Kernot, what the individual in the street regards as a deficit is the Commonwealth's call on financial markets. The figures set out in our budget papers show that we are in surplus in this budgetary year to the tune of $718 million. Those figures are calculated according to the criteria and conventions laid down by the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations. There is no rubber there. There is strict adherence to international calculations for the preparation of these sorts of statistics, and you cannot get away from that.

The achievement of a surplus—something that has rightly surprised the markets and something that has gained currency in the markets as trading today has progressed—is an outstanding achievement by this government. The opposition will want to tear that down. Success does not suit the opposition. Failure or inability to deliver is what the opposition craves. Agony and pain for ordinary Australians is what the opposition craves because it believes that is the basis upon which it might be re-elected. Unfortunately for the opposition, but fortunately for the rest of us, that will not occur.

The other major achievement of this budget is that we now have a medium-term national savings plan. We have heard precious little from the opposition about superannuation arrangements, and part of the reason for that is that these superannuation arrangements recognise the earlier promise of tax cuts delivered by the Prime Minister but come in the form of matching grants to workers' superannuation to ensure that there is a decent and respectable retirement income for ordinary Australians.

Last night, when delivering the budget speech on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), I pointed out that before Labor came to office only 35 or 40 per cent of Australians had superannuation at all. They were people in white-collar jobs; they were certainly not people in blue-collar jobs. The workers of this country did not have superannuation. One of the great reforms of this government is that now 90 per cent of male workers and 85 per cent of female workers in this country have superannuation coverage.

This government is now ensuring that when those people in their mid-30s eventually retire they will have their pension plus 75 per cent of their pension as a superannuation benefit. To achieve that 75 per cent, the tax cuts referred to earlier by the Prime Minister will be rediverted as matching grants to workers' contributions to superannuation, beginning year 1997. That will be an outstanding turnaround in terms of the ability of people in retirement to live at a dignified level. But in terms of the national pool of savings, it will generate something like tenfold the current $186 billion tied up in workers superannuation in Australia. So a huge pool of investment through national savings is being generated and addressing the most outstanding issue in our current account and our economic structure. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point at issue in this debate is whether the government lied its way back into government in 1993, with the lies flowing through in the budget decisions that have been taken since then. That is what this issue is all about. The government went to the 1993 election with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) himself putting his own personal imprimatur on it all, promising $14 billion of tax cuts. That is what won him the 1993 election. People stupidly thought that he might deliver on his promises.

PARA.TAB: What has happened since the 1993 election is that, instead of $14 billion of tax cuts, we have seen $18 billion of tax increases. That is the thrust of the opposition's concern about the morality of last night's budget. We should set aside the economics of it—which are rotten economics. The simple fact, and I repeat it, is that the government lied to the Australian people before the 1993 election about what it was going to do with taxes. It claimed it was going to massively decrease taxes. It has even more massively increased them. It did not just happen last night. It has happened in each of the budgets since the 1993 election.

You might remember, Mr Temporary Chairman, that in 1993, just a few months after that federal election, the Dawkins budget increased sales tax, despite a promise to the contrary; deferred the much vaunted personal income tax cuts that had been promised; and massively raised the petrol excise. Over four years those extra imposts imposed following the 1993 election will result in increased tax revenue of over $11 billion.

The government has done it again this year. The Prime Minister has broken his promise on company tax. He was to lower company tax to 33 per cent. He did so for a year or so. Now it has gone up by almost 10 per cent in this budget to a rate of 36 per cent. He has broken his promise not to increase the Medicare levy. It went up last night. He has broken his promise to pay the second tranche of the l-a-w, law, personal income tax cuts. First of all, a couple of budgets ago the government deferred the tax cuts from 1996 to 1998. It did that in the 1993 budget. Now it has abandoned them altogether.

The Prime Minister has broken his promise to not increase indirect taxes. The government increased sales tax by two per cent in the 1993 budget. Last night, it put an extra five per cent on cars. It will now cost an extra $1,000 per car. It has broken its promise to not expand the indirect tax base. What did we get last night? Building materials will be taxed at 12 1/2 per cent, which will add something like $2,000 or more to the price of a house. All those decisions last night and in the 1993 budget are the absolute opposite of what was promised by the government before the 1993 election.

The government is trying to convince the Australian public that the deficit figure for this year is not really a deficit but a surplus of $700 million. We all know what a fraud that is. Take the underlying budget. The government is very keen on using the word `underlying'. It does it in relation to the inflation rate. Hidden away at the back of the budget papers is a figure showing an $8.3 billion deficit for this year. It is not a surplus. That is what this debate today has been about. That is what the opposition was asking about in question time.

How on earth can one believe for anything else a government that promises tax cuts of $14 billion across the board but which, in the space of two years, wipes them all out and substitutes them with tax increases of $18 billion? There is no way that the Australian community will ever again believe anything that this deceitful government promises. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woodley this day, relating to an Industry Commission draft report into charities.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it was a remarkable answer, given the fact that I do not know how the minister heard the question, which was given without notice. I place on record the fact that I have been contacted by many groups in connection with their concerns about the Industry Commission inquiry into charities. I hear the minister's answer that eventually the government will respond to the Industry Commission's inquiry. But I remind the minister that, while we wait for those answers, the apprehension of these charities continues.

PARA.TAB: Let me place on record a few things that they have told me. Leaders of the Salvation Army in Western Australia have pointed out that they are very happy with the demand for accountability and better management which the inquiry had thrown up; they have no problem with that. However, they are concerned that many of the recommendations and the work of the inquiry are really about governmental control of their work. The emphasis on management and inspection really means that they will become a department of the government. They have said to me that they would rather work with their own resources and completely eschew government funding if that were to be the result. As far as they are concerned, the community sector is responsive to community needs. In the end, that is their motivation.

Community Services Australia, the national body for community services in the Uniting Church, spoke of these concerns in a recent media release. Its media release, which is headed `Government at risk of eroding the work of charities', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The application of economic rationalist ideals to human service delivery and the removal of tax exemptions will significantly erode the level of care charities currently provide.

. . . the community sector by its very nature must be responsive to the needs of people and cannot be driven by market forces alone. There is concern that the final report of the Commission will put forward the answer that the way to improved efficiency is by applying the economic rationalist's approach.
Government must be careful not to risk the ongoing work of the sector through the erosion of much of this vital financial support.
The Society of St Vincent de Paul National Council of Australia, in its response to the Industry Commission, said:

The Society rejects this recommendation, as the tendering model is based on a profit-oriented paradigm. This process will inevitably lead to one community service organisation being played off against another, with the client being the loser. As previously stated to the Industry Commission "It is unlikely that the Society would tender for projects in competition with other organisations"

The majority of Australian CSWOs operate from a Christian welfare and community service paradigm and seek to work co-operatively, not competitively, for the benefit of the people they serve. Major considerations when dealing with the vulnerable and marginalised people demand that emphasis should be placed on effectiveness and highest quality of care, rather than on lowest `cost'.
Therefore, the Society strongly objects to tendering for family/community based service delivery based exclusively on `cost'.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—The President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

—Last night's budget is one of the greatest increased tax grabs in Australia's history, which adds to the unparalleled list of broken promises of this deceitful Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That deceit is compounded by the government's portrayal of the budget as yielding a surplus of $700 million when the underlying situation is a deficit of well in excess of $8 billion.

PARA.TAB: The budget completely fails to tackle the essential restructuring of the government's finances. It reduces the living standards of virtually every Australian. It makes no inroads at all into Australia's huge deficit in its external accounts. It puts off into the distant future, into the never-never, some of it as far away as 30 years, any potential benefits. Of course, we all know what that means—they will never be delivered. Furthermore, and most disturbingly, the budget hit business badly, thereby endangering investment, demand, jobs and future growth.

Within the business sector, small business, the lifeblood of our economy, will be hit particularly hard. I say to you, Madam Deputy President—it is a great pleasure to have my first opportunity to call you that—that small business plays an enormously important role in this respect in the Australian economy. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has estimated that there are over 850,000 small businesses in Australia. That is 95 per cent of all businesses. Together, they employ over 2.8 million Australians; around 40 per cent of the total work force.

The budget has absolutely nothing to offer these people. On the contrary, it contains a number of highly regressive measures which damage small business. Small business already, of course, has been decimated in many areas by the policies of this government over many years. Indeed, in the last four years alone, there have been 70,000 small business bankruptcies. As my colleague Senator Campbell pointed out last night following the budget, the damaging impact of the budget measures on small business will throttle the opportunity for employment by the most employment-creating sector, the small business sector of the economy, at a time when youth unemployment in Australia is still at tragically high levels.

In my portfolio of immigration and ethnic affairs many Australians of overseas origin—particularly those from non-English speaking backgrounds—are small business people and they will be very severely damaged by these budget measures. Let us have a look at some of them. First of all, the company tax rate rises from 33 per cent to 36 per cent—an increase of almost 10 per cent. That will have a very adverse impact on all Australian companies. It will damage their cashflow and reduce their scope for investment, thereby limiting employment and growth prospects.

Some 40 per cent of all small businesses are incorporated; thus over 300,000 small businesses will be hit by this measure. The government has been totally duplicitous in its actions in this area. It has reversed one of the few election promises it delivered after the 1993 election. That was a promise to reduce the company tax rate to 33 per cent. That rate of 33 per cent was going to continue into the distant future, but two years later it is put back to 36 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —To match our policy.

—As Senator Knowles said, the government only did it to try to match our policy. The government, unlike the opposition, did it in a totally unfunded way. We said at the time that the government's reduction was not sustainable. It was another fraud because it was paid for by businesses out of brought-forward tax instalments. It was never going to be a sustainable measure. That was another lie by this government.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the Business Council of Australia is not a representative of small business, it has described the increase in company tax as `an attack on jobs which will reduce the funds available for investment and job creation. This comes at a time when there is a slowdown in business activity, especially in the small and medium sectors'. So, just when the small firms need the money from past profits, it will be taken away by this measure.

Secondly, higher corporate regulation scheme fees will also hit incorporated small businesses. Those 300,000-plus small businesses will have to pay their fair share of the $51 million to be raised over four years from this increase. Thirdly, the six per cent increase in sales tax on motor vehicles—which is going to produce almost $1.5 billion in additional tax over four years, provided car sales do not collapse again; there is every prospect that they will as a result of this measure—will also hit small business very hard. It is another Labor election deception. It will add $1,000 to the price of a Falcon or a Commodore. Small firms that require the use of a car for their very survival will have no chance of upgrading their cars. This will add a further cost to business. As the Taxation Institute has said, this measure will `be an unwarranted blow against the struggling motor vehicle industry, including the thousands of small manufacturers that make components'.

Fourthly, the new 12 per cent sales tax on building materials will hit small business very heavily. Small businesses are the backbone of the building industry; an industry that is already under very severe pressure due to the government's economic policies, particularly the surge in interest rates over the last few months. Those interest rates are once again amongst the highest real levels of interest rates in the western world. This measure will be an added blow. It will cost prospective buyers and renovators between $1,000 and $3,000 for each home. It is nothing less than an attack on that great Australian dream that once was a realisable dream but no longer is under this government—that is, the family home.

Fifthly, the budget assaults subcontractors by forcing them into the PAYE system. This measure is of course an ACTU-ALP deal. It is a specialty. They both hate subcontractors. They have attacked them through the industrial relations system. With the might of the tax office, they are going to whack them again. Whilst no estimate of the cost of that measure is included in the budget—probably because it is not a revenue initiative but rather an ideological assault—it will, nonetheless, have a significant impact. The increased compliance revenue, the lowering of the threshold for early PAYE remittances and the banking licences and supervision fees which will add to the cost of banking and the cost of business for small businesses will also have a significant impact.

This budget continues the long established Keating practice of electoral deceit and fraud, particularly in the area of taxation. It is the fudge-it budget of the high tax king and the prince of broken promises, as John Howard so eloquently said last night. It will do nothing whatsoever to meet Australia's needs. On the contrary, it will harm all Australians through its massive tax hikes and broken promises. None will suffer more than small business. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I congratulate you on your election. I understand that this is the first time you have been in the chair since your election yesterday. I hope I will get a good go from you. I am sure I will. I wish you well as the first woman Deputy President of the Senate. Your election to this position is a great honour for you and raises the role of women in Australian politics.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out to the opposition that I have been Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction for nearly two years and three months and that during that time the Liberal Party in the Senate has asked only one question on small business matters. This is the first time in two years and three months that it has actually put an MPI or an urgency motion and created a debate on this matter. It is rather rich for the Liberal Party to be in here screaming about—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Liberal Party and the National Party have talked numerous times about the plight of the rural sector, which is small business as well. It has been talked about a lot from this side. That side has taken no notice of it.
—There is no point of order.

—I am reminded by Senator Brownhill of one member of the National Party to whom I have given credit before and I will do so again today. The only member of the coalition who has ever raised a small business issue of any substance has been Senator Boswell. The Liberal Party frontbench has never shown any interest at all. In one sense I welcome the fact that finally Senator Short and other Liberal senators opposite have found the issue of small business. At least maybe they will now learn a few things and show some interest.

PARA.TAB: They have shown no interest in the major forum for small business in Australia, the Small Business Forum, which is made up of 31 organisations representing small business across Australia. The opposition has shown no interest in what is on the forum's agenda and no interest about the issues that it specifically raises.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a blatant lie.

—That is absolutely true. When the opposition's present shadow minister for small business, Judi Moylan, took on the job, her first statement was that the first thing she wanted to do was to give small business a voice in government. All the members of the Small Business Forum—the 31 organisations—made it very clear to her that she did not know what she was talking about. There is a structured arrangement in which they participate and put their views to the government. It showed that the small business community in this country, through its organisations, has been basically ignored by the Liberal Party. Now we get to this issue of this budget. We have just heard Senator Short outline how this budget is detrimental to the interests of small business.

PARA.TAB: My office tells me today that over the last six months I have spoken to or visited 140-odd small business organisations, meetings and factories all over Australia. Apparently, the audience attendance was around 4,000 people at these meetings. During all those discussions leading up to the budget last night, the number one issue by far was interest rates. They consistently said, `We want the deficit reduced; we want the pressure off interest rates because that is the number one issue.'

It is interesting to note that even Mr Rob Bastian, the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia—not a person noted for his support for the Labor Party—issued a statement in early April which said:

SPEECH.PARA: In a straight choice between interest rate rises and a two per cent corporate tax rise it is obvious that small firms would prefer the latter, because only 18 per cent of business tax returns are from companies. Further, interest on borrowings is an input cost, whereas company tax is only on profits.

That is what Rob Bastian, head of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, said in early April. That is what he was lobbying this government for, and he was not Robinson Crusoe in the Council of Small Business Organisations. It is quite clear that the opposition never listens to a word—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President. It seems to me—and I seek your guidance and perhaps the minister's guidance—that it is very damaging to say that an important business sector representative was lobbying the government for an increase in company tax.
—Order! There is no point of order, Senator Short, and you are intruding into Senator Schacht's speaking time.
—I hope Senator Schacht will make it clear that that is not what he was saying.

—Of course they all said, `We don't want any tax increase.' But if they have to make a choice between a tax increase and stable interest rates, they would rather have stable interest rates. They would rather have no further increase in interest rates—which is helped by reducing the budget deficit to a surplus—with some tax increases on the revenue side, including a company tax increase, to achieve lower, stable interest rates. Rob Bastian was not the only small business person who said that to me. He put out a statement on 4 April. All those other organisations made that very clear.

PARA.TAB: Of course no-one wants an increase in tax, but in the situation they were faced with they quite responsibly indicated that, on the balance of probability—which, I suppose, was the lesser of two evils for them—an increase in company tax rates is better than an increase in interest rates, as I just quoted. That was the consistent message given to me.

In my part in the budget discussions, I consistently emphasised the point that I supported a substantial reduction in the deficit—in the whole range of measures, both on the revenue side and on the expenditure side—to get that outcome of stable rates. In this case, to your extraordinary chagrin, Senator Short, we actually changed this budget deficit into a surplus. Over the next three budgets the structural surplus will be there, irrespective of asset sales. If you can actually work out what a structural surplus is, you will see that we have that locked in over the next three years.

This budget is a grave disappointment to the opposition because it shows that we have been able to achieve a reduction of the deficit into a surplus. We have been able to achieve this with a well balanced mixture of revenue measures and expenditure cuts. But the big issue is that overnight the opposition's shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, has said that the opposition will support no increases in revenue whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you promised there wouldn't be any tax increases.

—The opposition promised that it would support no increases in revenue, but you do not tell us what your expenditure cuts would be to get the budget into surplus. You are not game to indicate what the $8 billion to $10 billion worth of expenditure cuts would be to achieve a budget surplus as outlined by Mr Costello.

PARA.TAB: In the last 24 hours some of your people have been jumping up and down about the impact of some of the expenditure cuts that we have outlined. I have a statement, issued today by Senator Chapman, complaining about the review of the space program, saying that this could lead to expenditure cuts. He issued a statement in South Australia saying how terrible this is. That is a matter of $4 million or $5 million. It is the same all over the place with the Liberal Party. You want to run the old line. You want to reduce taxes, increase expenditure and balance the budget. That is basically what Mr Costello has said. That is certainly not going to help small business. Your policy is an absolute fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have a policy.

—The only policies you have are no tax increases and no revenue increases. You still say you want to get a budget surplus, but you do not tell us where the $8 billion or $10 billion worth of expenditure cuts would fall. You leave it silent. You may get away with that this week or next week, but I have to tell you, Senator Short, that between now and whenever the next election is, we are going to put the spotlight on you on this issue. By the time people go into the polling booth some time in the next 10 to 11 months, you will not be able to escape from saying where those expenditure cuts will come from.

PARA.TAB: The range you are talking about—$8 billion to $10 billion—will not just require a little bit of extra improvement and efficiency in the public sector; you will be talking about cutting billions out of education. Senator Tierney will go troppo over the idea of having big expenditure cuts in higher education, given his performance at recent estimates committee hearings where he whinges and whines all the time about not enough money being given to education. It will require big cuts in health, big cuts in social welfare and big cuts in programs to assist industry in this country. All of them help small business by having a more productive economy. We want to hear from the opposition what it is going to offer in expenditure cuts. There will be a lot of small businesses jumping up and down when they see your list, if you are game to produce it. We will put the acid on you coming up to the next election.

We have the shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in a policy free zone at the moment, making some vague comments. The only thing I hear from the opposition is that Mr Howard may do something about industrial relations—it is a bit unclear, but I suspect that if he gets into government it will be pretty draconian. Then he says, `I am interested in helping small business,' but there is not one policy item to help small business other than his saying that his industrial relations policy would help small business. There are no actual proposals.

In recent times through the Small Business Forum, the small business coalition has proposed changes to the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the unconscionable conduct provisions of the act that would help small business. Most of the small business organisations have sent me letters in the last month saying that they support that proposal. I want to know whether the Liberal Party will support changes to the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the unconscionable conduct provisions. Or, as has always been the case when interests of small business and big business are dealt with, will it cave in to the pressure from the Business Council of Australia and not support the strengthening of legislation that helps small business, such as the unconscionable conduct provisions?

What is the opposition's stated policy towards the recent Gardini report on improving the arrangements for the franchising industry in this country—an industry with a turnover of $40 billion a year, overwhelmingly comprised of small business? There has been not one word from the opposition about that area of absolute importance to the small business community. What is the policy on changes to the oil code? The Industry Commission has recommended there should be now a voluntary agreement between the petrol companies and the petrol retailers about petrol marketing arrangements.

I have been involved in very detailed discussions with both sides of that argument, but I have not heard one word from the opposition about its policy in that area. All of this is a policy-free zone for the opposition. It has no policy and no ideas. When we hear this hypocritical approach today to the effect that this budget has not helped small business, I am amazed that at least some opposition members have not got to their feet to outline some specific initiatives that they would take.

In the macro-economic settings we have one objective—namely, to keep inflation and interest rates down. That was what the small business community was demanding of this government in discussions during the six months before the budget. This government has delivered a budget surplus, it has delivered long term low inflation, and therefore we will be able to keep interest rates to a reasonable level in order to encourage investment. The opposition has never been able to deliver on that score.

Mr Howard, as Treasurer many years ago, never delivered a budget surplus. He always had inflation at 10 per cent or thereabouts and unemployment at even worse levels. Mr Howard's performance is awful in this area. When he was Treasurer in the 1981-82 recession he put many small businesses out of action, so what he now talks about is absolutely hypocritical. This matter of public importance is hypocritical and of absolutely no consequence.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in no way a reflection on the way in which Senator West, as Acting Deputy President, is now handling the chair, when I say that I regret that the Deputy President, Senator Reid, has just left the chair. Nevertheless, in her absence I wish to take the opportunity to congratulate Senator Reid on her accession to the high office to which the Senate has elected her.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Spindler, I am in no way offended and I shall pass on your best wishes to Senator Reid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Certainly it is a matter of great satisfaction that a senator of such distinction has been elected by the Senate to the office of Deputy President. Also, I am particularly pleased that a woman has been elected to that position. I add my congratulations to those that have already been expressed and believe that the office is in good hands.

PARA.TAB: The Senate is considering the motion of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.

Indeed, this is a matter of great importance. In Australia 700,000 small businesses employ half the work force—a total of 3.5 million people. Yet it as though such people in that sector do not exist. This budget hardly mentions small business, and the budget might never have happened in terms of anything that it does for that sector. People in small business and people in regional communities are once again forgotten.

PARA.TAB: Company tax was reduced from 39 per cent to 33 per cent with a trade-off of a massive carry forward of tax payment instalments. Instalments now often fall due even before the money is earned. The tax is going up to 36 per cent and it will fall on small businesses as much as on big businesses, but the instalments are still early. Certainly it is not a fair deal for small business and the budget will be a major impost. The Australian Democrats will be looking carefully at these measures to see what can be done to relieve small business from this new load.

I turn to PAYE collection. Currently, small business is not required to pay its tax instalments fortnightly because the threshold for this very costly and time consuming remittance is a salary bill of $5 million. That is being reduced to $1 million, as a one-off revenue gain. Clearly, that new low threshold will dramatically increase compliance costs for many small businesses, despite the fact that the government concedes that tax compliance costs for small business are already five to 10 times higher than for big business.

Let me turn to finance for small business. In 1993, the government agreed to pay the banks $160 million in interest on statutory deposits on the proviso that it was used for small business lending. The Reserve Bank's annual report last year showed that small business is still being treated unfavourably by the banks, facing interest rates up to three or four per cent higher than those of big business as well as higher security requirements. Despite this finding and the fact that surveys show that over 30 per cent of small businesses are constrained by lack of finance, the money is being taken back.It is highly likely that the banks will pass that $160 million on to small business consumers by even higher margins than they are suffering now—yet another slug on small business.

Sales tax is another topic that is a sore point for small business. Small business in the building and motor trades faces new sales tax slugs tonight. In the motor trades, the price of a new vehicle will go up by about $1,500, breaking an election commitment from Mr Keating that cars would be cheaper under him than under Fightback. I think we can expect to see a slump in car purchases, going into a free fall. I wonder what the management of Ford now says about its continuing presence in Australia. Volumes, after all, go towards viability.

TALK.START.PARA: —They say a lot Sid; they say a lot.

—If you can assure us, on the basis of the Ford company's authority, that it can absorb this slug without a fall in volume and therefore without a reconsideration of its forward policies, I am sure the Australian community, Australian industries and the Senate would be very pleased to hear that. In the building industry, another election commitment was broken with some building materials now being taxable. This will increase the price of an average home by between $1,000 and $1,500, possibly more when the tax office finally clarifies what it means by saying it will be taxing items such as kitchen cupboards. Some materials will be tax exempt; some wholesalers will have to divide up building costs into taxable and non-taxable components, adding once again to compliance costs. This slug on building is on top of the three per cent rise in interest rates and the reduction of funding for public housing commencements.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn to provisional tax. The uplift factor is still at eight per cent, despite efforts by the Australian Democrats to reduce it to five per cent. Unfortunately, these efforts were not supported by the opposition parties. I wonder what Senator Short will say now that the government has not taken any action to support small business. This budget slugs small business. Small business has been the key generator of jobs and is the key sector pushing innovation and change. By nobbling small business, we are nobbling our future. This budget can and should be made fairer for the small business sector. The Australian Democrats are exploring ways to achieve this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Short in this matter of public importance but I am very sad that we need to debate, as a matter of public importance, something so important to Australia as:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.

There are approximately 800,000 small businesses in Australia, employing over five million people. They are the backbone of the Australian economy. As Senator Boswell said in question time today, there were something like 14,000 bankruptcies in small businesses last year. There have been 70,000-odd bankruptcies in the last four years. This has been a neglected area.

PARA.TAB: This fraudulent, fudgy, fanciful, figured budget has done nothing at all for the small business sector. The Treasurer said that the government wanted to strengthen the tax base, but this has been at a cost to business. You people in government have to realise what company taxes do. Many small businesses are compromised. You have to realise how wholesale taxes impact on people in small business, both in carting goods into their shops and in taking them away. You have really slugged them in the last 10 years by raising wholesale taxes in that time.

My concern is with rural small businesses. Country towns thrive on their small businesses. Also, farming is a small business, although Senator Schacht does not seem to understand that. They have all continued to suffer from the flow-on effects of drought. People in the towns—if you prefer—have continued to suffer the effects of low commodity prices, the drought, the recent recession and the government's slow response to delivering assistance to primary producers. While assistance has gone to some primary producers, nothing has been provided for rural small businesses. You have done nothing for them. Applications for assistance have fallen on deaf ears.

You assume that the trickle-down effect will ultimately be of benefit to country people. In the meantime, small businesses are closing up. A survey by the Yellow Pages at the end of 1994 showed that 70 per cent of rural small businesses reported significantly lower sales levels. Credit and unpaid accounts had increased by nearly 40 per cent. Some 52 per cent of small businesses agreed they were struggling—and there will be more after this budget. Some 71 per cent were dissatisfied with the government—and that was before this budget. I can assure you that if you ask them next week you will find a lot more dissatisfied with you. There were 52 per cent who were dissatisfied with state governments—and there will be more after this budget. Nearly 50 per cent are dissatisfied with the support being shown by banks and other financial institutions. There will be higher costs put on banks and financial institutions, so they will be even tougher now.A quarter of all small businesses surveyed said they had cut staff numberers. There is nothing in this budget to help the employment rate or to make sure that people keep staff on. Some 19 per cent have put staff on reduced hours.

My electorate office is located in Tamworth, a rural city with a population of 31,500. It is one of the largest retail centres in New South Wales. The region has been in drought for several years; and it is still in drought. Notwithstanding the fact that it is the centre of one of the largest and most prosperous grain growing areas, there has been a significant downturn in business throughout the region. Many people in country businesses are putting staff off.

This has a multiplier effect on families, on wives with second incomes, on people wanting bigger homes, on school fees, and on extensions. There will be no bigger homes or extensions because now you will slug people who want them. If they want to go down the street and buy a tin of paint they will be slugged for wanting to brighten up their houses. Don't let people brighten up their day! Those in government have not looked at the multiplier effect on these sorts of things.

There will be reduced opportunities for school leavers because companies are no longer putting juniors on; they are sacking them. Builders and plumbers are not taking on apprentices—there is not enough work to justify them. There is a problem for TAFE colleges. They will be forced to reduce course options and staff because of lack of patronage. There will be more of those problems after the fanciful, fudgy budget the government brought on last night.

The budget will impact on the larger shops and supermarkets because of less spending. There will be less money, in the end, in the pockets of the people who have invested in some of the big companies that will be knocked with the higher tax. The head of a large retailer in Tamworth told me today that the retail industry is having a very bad time and is at a very low ebb. The retail boom that you people opposite talked about last year is a figment of Fagin Keating's fantasy. He had the fantasy last year of telling everyone that there was a real upsurge in retail turnover. That was absolutely—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! The use of the word `Fagin' in that sense is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `Fagin' is not unparliamentary, I suggest. Haven't you read—
—You are also not referring correctly to the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister, with his figment of fantasy, brought out fraudulent, fudgy figures last night. Take that rather than Fagin if you do not like Fagin. Do a bit of reading, and you might find out a bit about Fagin.

PARA.TAB: My friend in Tamworth said that sales came from three different sectors—roughly a third from rural areas, another third from the tertiary sector, schools, hospitals and government departments, and the other third from the townies. When you take into account the direct decline in sales from the rural sector in the other areas, you will find there will be even worse times this year.

One might have expected some mention in the budget last night about small business. There was not a bit. Senator Schacht must have no power and no ability to make anyone put something about his portfolio into the budget. There was not one bit in the budget about small business. I quote what was said in the budget:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia has had one of the best performing economies among industrialised countries . . . fastest growing industrialised countries . . .

There was not one bit about small business. So don't have a crack about this side for talking about small business. You cannot get amongst your colleagues enough to get them to put in a bit about small business.

PARA.TAB: There was no recognition of the impact of drought in the budget papers last night. We were promised tax cuts, and we got tax increases. At the Press Club on 9 February 1993, relating to Investing in the Nation, Mr Keating stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . let me tell you something that I thought you might have known—they've been legislated. They were not a promise, they are law—l-a-w.
Is he a liar?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Does he not tell the truth?
—No.
—Is he fudging with the figures?
—Yes.
—Yes.
—Yes.
—Is he actually trying to take the Australian people down?
—Yes.
—Yes.
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Only one person is supposed to be speaking. The other interjections are unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is yours an interjection, Madam Acting Deputy President? You have now interjected a couple of times during my speech.
—Mine is a ruling from the chair.
—I am just asking questions.
—Your time has expired, Senator Brownhill.
—Maybe yours will shortly.
—I take that to be a reflection upon the chair. Was that a reflection upon the chair?
—The meaning behind my words is that your party allows you to take the attitude that you will not be in power very shortly because of the way you have treated the Australian community.
—Thank you, Senator Brownhill. You have clarified the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today after being asked to make a contribution to this debate. I was somewhat surprised that I was asked.
—Why did they ask you, Chris?

—Because essentially it is a B team debate. I admit that is why I am in the debate. We thought the opposition would launch a major attack on the fundamental issues contained in the budget. I thought we would see our ministers defending themselves against a serious attack from your frontbench on the fundamentals of the budget. Unfortunately, we have a real B team effort. Rather than attacking assumptions about employment growth, falling unemployment and a rise in living standards, or the attempts in the budget to reduce interest rates, inflation and the current account, we have this rather absurd matter of public importance submitted by the opposition. The MPI states:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.

That is what the opposition has to offer on the day after the budget, at its first chance to get stuck into the government and to put its alternative propositions for the future economic directions of this country.

PARA.TAB: In reply to Senator Brownhill's contribution, I refer him to an article in the West Australian of today's date headed `Explosion in birth of small businesses.' It is interesting to note that the article in the West Australian tends to contradict some of Senator Brownhill's evidence. The article mentions a study by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu which refers to the large growth in small business in the last couple of years in Australia.

I would like to concentrate on some of the larger issues in the economic debate. I think the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are to be congratulated for making sure that the budget did address those major issues. What the opposition has failed to understand is that the major problem confronting small businesses is the cost of their inputs. The biggest problem most of the small businesses I talked to have is servicing their debt. What this budget is about is taking the pressure off interest rates for both businesses and families so that they can service that debt, borrow and allow their businesses to grow and therefore employ more people.

The budget is targeted very much at reducing any pressure on interest rate rises that exist in the economy. The opposition has been talking about this issue for some time. I am very surprised that it has failed to acknowledge the importance of that thrust within the budget. As I said, small businesses face real pressure from any rise in interest rates. I think it has been conceded that the budget does a great deal to reduce pressure on interest rates. That will prove to be a key to business success and to its ability to generate employ ment.

The other input of vital importance to small business is wages policy and the cost of wages. I am pleased to say that, as part of this budget process, the government will be negotiating with the ACTU accord mark 8, which will manage growth in the economy and wages outcomes to keep sustainable economic growth. This budget is about continuing sustainable economic growth and rising employment, and keeping inflation under control. The accord mark 8 will be a boon to businesses because the two major input costs that they face—interest rates and wages policy—will be managed and will relieve pressure on small business.

They will then be able to deal better with one of the imposts that arise from the budget on which the opposition has concentrated, and that is the rise in company tax. Company tax is a tax on their profits at the end of the process and has much less effect, as Senator Schacht pointed out, than imposts on their inputs. The company tax increase will have some impact, but it is part of a package. The package has reduced the imposts on small business. I think overall it is a good result for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —How has it reduced the imposts on small business?

—Because it will help to reduce interest rates. I point out that the last company tax rate before you left office in 1981-82 was 46 per cent. When we are talking about relative company tax rates, we ought to bear that in mind. What we have done is reduce company tax rates to 36 per cent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate today is focusing on:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.
I have just checked the parliamentary handbook, and the three contributors from the Labor Party here today have not one day's business experience amongst them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you had?

—I used to be the general manager of a privately owned office equipment company. I used to run my own business. Do you want any other credentials on Senator Brownhill, for example? The reason we are having this debate today is that these people here are all unionists. They do not understand the reality and the problems associated with small business. As I say, there is not one day's experience amongst the three of them. This is the problem that the small business associations have with a minister who does not understand business. This is why they have called repeatedly for him to be sacked.
—Why don't you ask a question then? You haven't asked a question for two and a half years, Senator Knowles.

—He wonders why we do not ask questions. There is a very simple answer to that question. It is because he simply cannot answer the questions. Everything that he has touched he has messed up. Small business is a classic example of that. In last night's budget, there was not one incentive for small business. The sales tax and company tax increases contained in this budget are the last smack in the mouth that small business needs. This government does not worry about small business. This government subjected small business to the worst recession in 60 years. Who was engineer of the worst recession in 60 years? The Prime Minister—Paul Keating. He was the one who did that.

PARA.TAB: As my colleague Senator Short has said, so many small businesses have gone broke over the 13 years of Labor government. Many of them have struggled to survive, have seen five minutes of sunshine and have been hit with further increases in sales tax and further increases in company tax. Senator Chris Evans just said, `But company tax is only paid on profit. It does not matter.' What he does not understand, because he has never run a business and has never had to understand it, is that the way in which people employ and stay in business is by making a profit.

Unless they make a profit they go broke but you do not understand that. You do not understand the basics. Along with the record levels of bankruptcy, of course, there were record levels of unemployment because small business, given the right circumstances, is Australia's largest employer. But does that matter to this government with this budget? No! All they have done is increase taxes on small business.

Prior to the last election, this cheating and lying government sought to match our policies to provide the tax cuts now known as the l-a-w or l-i-e tax cuts by reducing company tax and the tax on cars. All that was done purely and simply to match Fightback. The government had no intention whatsoever of keeping those tax cut promises or the reduction in other taxes.

Since the aborting of the l-a-w or l-i-e tax cuts, we now see the increases in company tax and the tax on motor vehicles, which will of course affect company cars and the motor vehicle industry. And the motor vehicle industry has always been in a fairly delicate position in this country. Does it matter to this government? No! Overnight they just whack a tax on new cars.

What will that do to the manufacturing and retailing motor vehicle industry? The retail industry is a large employer as well and there will now be many more people who cannot afford to buy a new car, to say nothing of the companies which have fleet cars and which will not be able to pay the extra sales tax that this government has just thrown at their door today. For example, those industries will be very badly affected.

But let us look at another significant employer and small business industry. The building industry has been struggling for years. Senator Murphy looks terribly puzzled. I can understand his bewilderment because he does not understand the business. The building industry is a very large employer. The building industry started to see a bit of an increase in home construction.

However, since the interest rates have gone up and now that there is further uncertainty as to where interest rates are going—because, let us face it, you guys do not know; you do not have the faintest idea of where interest rates are going—there has already been a decline in home building. What did the government do last night? It put a sales tax on previously exempt building products that will add $2,500 to the cost of a $100,000 home.

There are not too many places around Australia where you can buy a $100,000 home. It should be noted, for those who might read this debate at a later date or who might be listening to it at the moment, that Senator Murphy is roaring with laughter at that prospect. He obviously does not care one iota about all the young people who are desperately trying to get their foot on the first rung of the ladder to buy a home.

Young people cannot even manage to save the 20 per cent deposit, purely and simply because the under-25s are the ones that these people opposite have put into unemployment limbo. The under-25s are suffering the highest record of unemployment—and there is so much job uncertainty. Those poor young people whom we should be encouraging to buy homes have been hit again because the government has just widened the gap further.

The government has widened the gap on the cost of the home and widened the gap on the deposit they need to get by increasing bank charges. The increase in bank charges will hit them as well but that does not matter to the government—it does not seem to care.

Look at fuel excise, which has taken off in the 13 years of this government. Prior to the last election the government promised that we would not have any increases in tax. It is worth reminding the Senate that at the time of the last election fuel tax was 26.2c a litre; by February 1994 it was 30.75c a litre, or 31.75c a litre for leaded petrol; and by February this year and now it is 32.5c or 34.57c a litre.

You do not understand that that adds to the cost of everything that is transported in a commercial and private sense. But that does not matter to you. It is absolutely scandalous that this government has neglected small business yet again, does not understand the problems that it is facing and seems to care not about those who can and should be employed by the small business sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the issue of Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity.

PARA.TAB: We all know that small business is the major employer in this country. The majority of employment growth in the last year or two has been in small and medium enterprises. A lot of the economic upturn has been from gross domestic product generated in small business. We also know of the problems with taxation compliance that small business faces. We know about the emphasis on big business, big projects, which are assisted while small business is left to fend for itself in a system stacked against it.

When we talk about slowing down the economy, or cooling it off, we mean mainly we must sock it to small business. These are the people who get hit first and hardest with declines in consumer confidence and by increased interest rates. These are people, often ordinary couples, who have managed to scrape enough together to get a business going. They generally try to start these during good times, since even established small business suffers during recessions.

Established businesses also take an upturn as a good chance to buy stock and equipment that was run down over the hard times, or to expand. Much of this is financed through loans and so small business is heavily affected by increased interest rates, both through declines in consumer spending and through increased demands on what profits they make.

The tax regime also has a heavy impact on small business. It is not so much the rate of tax, although there are equity issues here, since small business often has far less opportunity to take advantage of tax minimisation schemes, while big corporations can employ several tax experts just to work out ways to do so. What is more important is the cost, often in time and effort, of compliance.

We have seen the tax regime moving increasingly towards self-assessment to reduce government expenses and employment. We now expect each small business to comprehend and act with perfect assumption of knowledge in regard to the mess that is our tax legislation. If they fail, or make a mistake, they are held entirely responsible. This budget estimates the ATO will make the government an extra $150 million this year in compliance improvement.

While no-one wants to excuse or tolerate tax cheats, we have the situation where big business has the opportunity to minimise tax, while small business is expected to be a tax expert and is ruthlessly pursued and treated as a cheat if it makes a mistake. Not only does small business spend eight, 10 or more hours a week at the book, it lives in terror of a tax audit, although it may be trying to do everything properly.

There is also little doubt that if the federal government were serious about enabling regional and rural communities to seek out viable solutions to their economic problems, it would not be cutting back spending on local employment and training initiatives. It would realise that the cargo cult mentality of paring down costs and standards to the bone to attract international investment from overseas in capital intensive resource extracting industry is not likely to solve these problems.

The least any federal government should do is to acknowledge local initiatives that are working to create economic diversity and new employment opportunities even if they are breaking the rules by producing for the local market.

Without this realisation, the current big business, commodity export orientation—as we see in Western Australia—will see us continuing to dig up or chop down everything in sight, requiring more and more export volumes to pay for imports of basic consumer goods, that is, to run faster and faster just to stand in the same spot. This is neither economically nor ecologically sustainable.

Small and medium community-based enterprises, whether for export or the local market, have an important role to play if we are really interested in solving the problems faced by regions. It is time that this role was recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Chris Evans, I was somewhat amazed to read this matter of public importance by Senator Short referring to `Labor's failure to understand the critical importance of small business to jobs and economic prosperity'.

PARA.TAB: All the way through our term in office in the performance of our duties since we took over from the ridiculous situation that you left this country in back in 1983 we have restructured industry and implemented programs along the way that have actually allowed a vast majority of this country's businesses not only to improve their position but also to look outside this country at the very much enhanced opportunities for export industries.

More recently, we have introduced the Ausindustry program, which is an umbrella operation covering various services to much of the small and medium sized enterprises in this country. Through the National Industry Extension Service we provide direct-to-business services for things such as strategic planning, financial planning, and strategic design. We have an industry R&D board. We provide a 150 per cent tax concession for R&D programs.

Then we have the competitive grants program for companies not making a profit. We have concessional loans for early commercialisation of products that businesses are seeking to develop. We have the business network program, which is helping businesses get together to market particular products in particular markets. We have agrifood quality programs and technology access programs, helping small and medium sized businesses not only to get into the use of technology but also to use that technology correctly.

I would like to address a remark made by Senator Brownhill relating to business confidence in this government. One measure of confidence is the fact that in 1994—this is not something we have made up—the level of business investment was at a record high. That is forecast to increase by 18 per cent, in year average terms, during the remainder of 1994-95 and by 13 per cent in 1995-96. If that is not a measure of the vote of confidence in this government I will take another called the election measure.

It just so happens that we on this side of the chamber represent more country and small business seats than the National Party and the Liberal Party do. That is another measure of the confidence that people in the country have in this government and is demonstrated by the amount of rural activity.

But it is even more important to look at the opposition's policy. I know what the policy of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is. The keeper of the genie slipped the cork momentarily and allowed the old GST genie to get out. Industry and small business did not buy the GST before and do not want to buy it now. The Leader of the Opposition has managed to get the cork back in but we know that sooner or later he will let that cork out again. (Time expired)
