TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of a visit by an Australian parliamentary consultative delegation to Vietnam from 5 to 12 April 1995, entitled Australia-Vietnam Dialogue : The Currents of Change. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report looks unambiguously to the future of Australian-Vietnamese relations. It endeavours in all respects to be constructive, deliberate and purposeful. It seeks to influence policy, not only in this country but in Vietnam, on a range of issues—political, economic, social and cultural, particularly in respect of human rights—and it seeks to carry opinion, not only within the legislature but beyond, to the broad Australian community, having particular regard to the Australian Vietnamese community.

PARA.TAB: It is a privilege to have led the delegation. It is a very great privilege to deliver this report this afternoon, particularly in respect of the fact that I know there is much interest in it here and beyond, but also because the report is a unanimous document. It represents a consensus view arrived at by the delegation, which itself reflected all shades of opinion within the Australian parliament and within the community beyond. It was a very able delegation and it was a pleasure to lead it.

The initiative to send an Australian delegation to Vietnam to obtain a balanced and objective picture of developments in that country and, in particular, to initiate a substantial dialogue on human rights issues, stemmed from a meeting on 27 May 1993 between the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Vietnamese Prime Minister, Mr Vo Van Kiet. While an earlier planned visit was unfortunately cancelled due to circumstances at the time and as a result of major changes to the itinerary originally planned for the delegation, negotiations were able to be resumed and the 1995 delegation was the result.

The Australian parliamentary consultative delegation to Vietnam was the first of its kind. It has succeeded in opening a dialogue between the two countries on matters of common interest and concern. The delegation was a framework delegation, exploring a range of political, economic and cultural issues, especially human rights, in an effort not only to outline Australian perspectives but also to make a realistic contribution to the development of ties, institutional and otherwise, between Australia and Vietnam.

It should be noted that our hosts were at pains to make sure that we had access, at senior levels, to official channels through which to pursue those matters which we wished to discuss. This enabled our delegation to raise a range of issues across the broad spectrum of concerns, interests and aspirations. From time to time exchanges were robust but discussions were always valuable. No issue was regarded as too difficult, either by the delegation or by our interlocutors.

Lest anyone think that we were confined to official channels, our delegation was able to make contact with a wide range of people, well beyond official structures and who were independent of government channels. In that respect I would like to thank my fellow delegates but I pay particular tribute to the Vietnamese members of the Australian delegation—Professor Trang Thomas, Ms Mai Ho, and Mr Phong Bui—who were outstanding in broadening contact. In respect of the contact we had with the dissident family in Ho Chi Minh City, Ms Mai Ho and Professor Trang Thomas were again instrumental.

As people may conclude, we were able to discuss issues with critics, intellectual and otherwise, of some aspects of Vietnamese government policy. Our delegation also found it possible to mix with representatives of international agencies—for example, UNHCR and UNICEF—with the Australian business community, particularly in Ho Chi Minh City, and with the diplomatic corps.

This wide range of contact has enabled the delegation to make a comprehensive assessment of the changes which are occurring in Vietnam and just what those changes mean for the future, not only for our bilateral relationship but also for the region. It has also allowed the delegation to focus on Australia's approach and the role which we should continue to undertake.

The full program of the delegation is attached to the report which I am tabling this afternoon, but I will just give the Senate some idea of the range of discussions. There were discussions with the ministries of foreign affairs, interior, justice, labour; the Supreme People's Court; the Chief Procurator of Ho Chi Minh City; government committees for religious affairs, children and ethnic minorities; the General Confederation of Labour; and the Women's Union.

The delegation visited a prison at Phu Son, talked with prison officials and, perhaps more significantly, with a number of prisoners. The delegation also met with representatives of the Catholic and Buddhist churches, private lawyers, intellectuals and political critics. Importantly, as I have mentioned, Vietnamese-Australian members of the delegation were able to move freely without escort and to meet and talk with ordinary Vietnamese citizens in all walks of life. We were also able, of course, to talk with expatriate Australians in Vietnam.

The structure of the report is as outlined. It looks at an overview of the objectives and at the historical, political, legal and economic context, which is essential for an understanding of the current situation. It looks then at specific issues. We then move to particulars, with the visit to the Phu Son prison. We look then, in great detail, at the circumstances of returned asylum seekers—the delegation having spent a day in Dong Nai looking at those particular situations. Again, I mention the contact that we were able to have with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

In terms of the conclusions which we were able to draw as a result of our experiences, contact and discussions, there is no doubt that the war years remain a significant feature of Vietnamese political culture. In everything from expression, by way of the contact with the national assembly through to the literature. It has resulted in a strong sense of independence and national pride and a reserve in respect of any suggestion of dictation by outsiders. But, having said that, there is no question either that Vietnam is very much a country in transition. Since the initiation of the doi moi economic reform program, there have been major changes in Vietnam's approach to economic management. The doctrines of Marxism and Leninism, as they apply in terms of the economic future of Vietnam, are in the past.

It is true that there has been some relaxation of political control over private behaviour, but there is a very long way to go in terms of a number of human rights issues, and we deal with those in detail in the report. We focus, in particular, on the consequences of the international instruments to which Australia and Vietnam are both signatories—and I am thinking in terms of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and that which applies to economic, social and cultural rights and the ILO conventions—and also in respect of international instruments which Vietnam has not yet signed and which appear to be under some degree of consideration within Vietnamese government circles at the moment. In particular, I draw attention to the convention on torture.

There is a general belief that, in so far as the transitional circumstances are concerned, economic reform is irreversible. There is an expectation that social and political changes will also continue to take place. The specifics did not always emerge but the general trend was very clear. It appeared to my mind that the Vietnamese government and those in leading positions in political and economic offices had looked very carefully at the collapse of the Soviet bloc and had looked even more carefully at other experiences in Asia. In expressing the personal view, as distinct from the view of the delegation—although Senator Bourne might agree—I think that the Vietnamese government appears to have embraced something akin to a Taiwanese model for future economic development and political circumstances. There appears to be a degree of tolerance in respect of private expression of political or other views, but there seems to be little tolerance of public or organised dissent. The cases of imprisonment, for example, a degree of harassment of which the delegation was made aware, demonstrate that fact beyond satisfaction.

In respect of the legal system overall though, there is no doubt that there is a great deal of change occurring and Australia will play a role in overhauling the code that applies to investment, the labour code and other aspects of future legal circumstances. We argue in our conclusions for a future cooperating for justice program. We argue that very specifically. We believe that is a very purposeful role that we can play. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

It is important for Vietnamese-Australians to be involved in the future development of the bilateral relationship between Australia and Vietnam. The linkages between the Vietnamese-Australian community and Vietnam, whether through family, investment, education, trade or cultural development between the two countries, have the potential to improve the enjoyment by the Vietnamese people of various forms of human rights. The delegation members concluded that there was considerable scope to expand contact between Vietnamese-Australians and state and non-state agencies within Vietnam actively involved in development, social issues, welfare and civil rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendations

PARA.TAB: Arising from the visit, the Delegation made a number of recommendations (which are set out in chapter 10 of the report) including the following:

Australia should reaffirm its invitation to Vietnam to send a delegation to visit Australia to improve further the bilateral relationship. The Australian Government should encourage further exchanges similar to this delegation to continue the bilateral dialogue.

Australia should continue to use political, diplomatic and other channels to encourage improvements in the observance of human rights in Vietnam, including its implementation of international obligations. In particular, Australia should encourage Vietnam to consider developing a national human rights action plan, in accordance with the Vienna Human Rights Declaration, to adhere to the Convention Against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman and Degrading Treatment or Punishment and the First and Second Optional Protocols to the ICCPR, and to provide more detailed and comprehensive responses to requests for information on political prisoners. Australia should also encourage Vietnam to develop further its relations with international non-government organisations.

Australia should promote more exchanges of visits on issues such as comparative legal processes, industrial relations and trade unionism, resettlement of asylum seekers, improve relations between Vietnam and overseas Vietnamese, education, health and the operation of national and international mechanisms for the promotion of human rights.

Australia should encourage Vietnam to continue and accelerate its program of legal reform. Australian assistance should be under a "co-operation for justice" package, which should include legal reform and the operation of the justice system.
Australia should encourage Vietnam to permit the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention to visit all Vietnamese prisons.
Relevant parties should facilitate greater involvement of Vietnamese-Australians in the process of strengthening relations between the two countries.
The report should be translated into Vietnamese and widely circulated, in the hope of promoting widespread community discussion and response.

On behalf of the Delegation, I would like to place on record my thanks to the host of the delegation, H E Mr Hoang Bich Son, Chair of the External Relations Committee of the National Assembly,, to his staff, officers of the Vietnamese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and to the provincial administrations in Hue and in Ho Chi Minh City and to all others who helped make the visit a success. I would like also to thank the Australian Ambassador to Vietnam, Ms Sue Boyd, and her staff, and the Vietnamese Ambassador to Australia, Mr Nguyen Thanh Chau, and his staff for the preparatory work which made the visit possible.
I should also like to thank my fellow delegates for an outstanding job, accomplished thoughtfully in good spirit.
In terms of the future, Vietnam will be more significant in the region and will prove to be a more active participant in regional affairs.
The current relationship between our two countries is both substantial and growing. It will assume an increasing importance for the future.
This Report aims to play in shaping that future for the better, in the interests of our two countries and our two peoples, who share much by way of common aspiration.
This Report looks unambiguously and confidently to the future. It is unanimous. It is a purposeful and balanced document.
I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Loosley's motion. I, too, was on the delegation, and I must say I found a very different Vietnam to the one that I found when I was there about three years ago. The differences I found in Vietnam—and I must say I am not an expert on Vietnam, and please nobody listening take me as such—are that in those three years Vietnam seems to have become far more bustling, more open, particularly in the south as we were coming from the airport into Ho Chi Minh City, or Saigon, as almost everybody still calls it. They say it because it is shorter than Ho Chi Minh City. As we were coming in, we saw Telecom phone boxes which had been put there by Telstra Australia and which took phone cards, and that was something completely different from what I expected, having been there three years ago.

PARA.TAB: The economic liberalisation that began with the introduction of doi moi in 1986 has led inexorably to a different Vietnam. Along with Chris Sidoti, one of the other members of this delegation, I was a member of the two Australian human rights delegations to China, which took place, I think, in 1991 and 1992. The differences between our reception in Vietnam and our reception in China on the first instance were very marked. In Vietnam, for instance, on this side the Vietnamese accepted that what we were doing was appro-

SPEECH.PARA: priate. They accepted that, when we mentioned human rights, that was a legitimate matter for discussion. It was part of the bilateral relationship and, in fact, much of the program, as Senator Loosley has said, did focus on human rights. By comparison, when we went to China, the first time in particular, at almost every meeting we were told right at the beginning for a considerable length of time why we really should not be there and why what we were doing was totally inappropriate. If we heard that speech once, we must have heard it 20 times. That did not happen on this visit, and I was very pleased about that.

PARA.TAB: But, even though there have been rapid and dramatic economic changes, there are still, of course, basic problems in Vietnam, and we address them, I think, probably most succinctly in conclusion No. 9.6, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: While there appears to be no repression of the private expression of political or other views at variance with those of the regime—

As Senator Loosley has said, and I really want to agree with him on this, views were expressed in many places. I do not want to get our Vietnamese-Australian members of the delegation into trouble for saying this, but they were instrumental in going out and talking to people on the streets and in shops. They included dissidents and a lot of people that we otherwise would not have been able to have contact with. They were able to speak with these people, and I hope I am reporting them accurately when I say that they found people in the majority were willing to speak about political differences in private. But when you look at what happens with public expression of dissenting views, there are very harsh penalties. There are gaol sentences. Amnesty International tells us that there are still at least 60 prisoners of conscience and possible prisoners of conscience being held in Vietnam. These people are in gaol in Vietnam because they disagree with the views put forward by the communist party of Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: The legal system treats dissidents very harshly. Penal provisions are broadly worded, so in many cases people are not quite sure whether they are going against the law. The judicial system gives little scope for acquittal. Once people are in court, in 99.9 per cent of cases they will be convicted. When they are convicted, the gaol terms are really quite lengthy.

The churches form the other area that we looked at most considerably. Basically, people must strictly adhere to a religious faith. For example, it is fine for people to go to mass in the Catholic Church as long as it is a really traditional mass. That is of great comfort to many people in Vietnam, and so it should be. It is also fine for those who want to follow the religious faith of Buddhism quietly to do so in the proper Buddhist church. Those who go across the line could get into very big trouble, and many people do. Religious observance is one area where many people get into trouble in Vietnam.

I will not take too much longer. I will say a few things about the people on the delegation. Senator Loosley led our delegation extremely well. I have always found him to be very good on human rights. I felt that he was very good on this delegation. I must admit that before I went I really was not quite sure what I would find, but I was very impressed by the way that Mr Downer also led the delegation. Both men were sensible, conciliatory and reasonable at all times. We all got on very well.

Professor Nancy Viviani was also on the delegation. I think I can say the same of her; she was sensible. Nobody went beyond the line. Everybody on that delegation knew exactly where the line was. They pushed it occasionally, but they never went beyond it. Mr Chris Sidoti and I are the only two people who had been to both China and Vietnam on similar delegations. He is an asset to any human rights undertaking. Senator Loosley will agree with me when I say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without question.
—Yes. We placed a great deal of responsibility on his shoulders on a couple of occasions. He was never anything less than what we would have expected.

PARA.TAB: I believe that our two Vietnamese-Australian members outside the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade were under a lot of pressure in Australia before they went. It did not make it easy for them. When they went to Vietnam, they behaved absolutely impeccably. In a couple of cases, I would even say that they behaved heroically. They said things that they did not think would be treated comfortably by our hosts. In a couple of cases, people were surprised at their forthrightness. But they never went beyond the line. They were always very strong in what they were asking and in requiring an answer. In the end, they got the answers. I was very proud to be on the delegation with them. It was probably more difficult for them than for the rest of us. They were a real asset.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade people that we had with us were, as usual, very good. I know that I say this every time, but it is true. I believe that we have one of the best departments of foreign affairs in the world. It is under-resourced. We do not give it enough credit for exactly how well it does, which is very well. It is excellent and deserves more of everything. The officers who were on the delegation with us were very good.

I will finish by saying that Vietnam is changing for the better. But I believe that it will take a long time. As economic changes take place, inevitably other changes will follow. But something that both the Vietnamese and Australians have to look at very closely is how fast those political changes occur. I still recommend to the Vietnamese government that it look very closely at those prisoners of conscience and the amnesties that are coming up on 7 September. It should consider very strongly whether prisoners of conscious should be included en masse in those amnesties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I was not a member of the delegation, I seek the indulgence of the Senate to say a few words on the delegation's report, which I have had an opportunity to look at only very briefly. I congratulate the delegation on its report. It seems to be very comprehensive and draws some very sensible recommendations and conclusions. I would like to raise a couple of things that are of some concern to me. Over all, I certainly welcome it.

PARA.TAB: This is probably Senator Loosley's last major contribution in the Senate before he leaves for other better, probably more lucrative, climes. As the chairman of the delegation, I congratulate him on this and all the work that he has done in this area during his time in the Senate.

As Senator Loosley and Senator Bourne have said, the delegation was a very good one. I pay particular credit, as they have, to the two members of the Vietnamese-Australian community who were on the delegation. Both Professor Trang Thomas and Ms Ho Mai are well known to me. They are leading members of the Vietnamese-Australian community in Australia, and certainly in my state of Victoria. As Senator Bourne said, without doubt they had the most difficult role of all. They went with a great deal of pressure on them from the Vietnamese community in Australia. There was a great deal of expectation from the community as to how they would perform.

As I am sure Senator Loosley and Senator Bourne are aware, some concern has been expressed within sections of the Vietnamese community in Australia that the delegation did not achieve all that it would like it to have, particularly in the area of human rights. I was very pleased to hear Senator Bourne point out the firmness with which Trang Thomas and Ho Mai approached their task. That is a very valuable point to have on the record.

Senator Loosley said that this was the first delegation of its kind to Vietnam. I guess that is right when one takes into account the overall composition of the delegation and the fact that it included more than just politicians. I was a member of a small parliamentary delegation to Vietnam in October 1993. We did many of the same things that this delegation did. In some respects, we had some greater success in the human rights area than this one did, although it has obviously had success in other aspects.

I regret that this delegation was prevented from meeting any political or religious prisoners of conscious. The October 1993 delegation, through some considerable persistence on our part—we probably did not endear ourselves to officialdom there—managed to have a meeting with one of the leading religious prisoners, the most venerable Thich Quang Do. It was not a terribly satisfactory meeting, but at least it broke some considerable ground. I note the recommendation in the report that it ought to be a high priority of any future delegation to Vietnam that there be the opportunity to meet people such as him. It is very important. If that does not happen, it is not possible to come back and say with as much confidence as one would like that it covered the field to the extent to which it did. I am sure that both senators would agree with that comment.

I am also sorry that the delegation appears to have not met with representatives of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam. There are two Buddhist churches in Vietnam. The Vietnam Buddhist Church is the official government church. There is also the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam, the members of which have been persecuted and imprisoned over many years now, including Thich Quang Do and many others. It was unfortunate that the delegation was apparently not able, for one reason or another, to meet representatives of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam whilst they were there.

I am unable to comment on how the delegation went in relation to the meeting with representatives of the Catholic church. Two months ago in Parliament House we had a seminar on Australia-Vietnam relations conducted by the International Committee for a Free Vietnam of which I am one of the three Australian co-presidents, along with my colleagues Philip Ruddock and Ted Grace from the House of Representatives. So both sides of the main political spectrum are represented.

At that seminar, which was held in the Main Committee Room on 24 February, one of the speakers was the chairman of the Vietnamese Catholic community in Sydney, Mr Joachim Nguyen Van Thine. In a submission to that seminar, he spoke of the ongoing restrictions and persecutions in Vietnam in relation to the Catholic church. In particular, he mentioned, and had tabled, lists of priests and seminarians who are still being imprisoned by the Vietnamese government. We might have occasion for further debate on this subject in this place in the future. That is something that I would certainly like to hear take place.

Last week in Washington I attended an international conference on Vietnam which was convened by the International Committee For a Free Vietnam. It has chapters in the United States, Canada, Australia and in some countries in Europe which we are trying to develop further. We are concerned about doing what we can as an international community to further, by all peaceful means, the democratisation of Vietnam. There is no doubt that whilst there have been important economic reforms and that the policy of doi moi that has been pursued since 1986 really has worked in many economic aspects, I remind the Senate that Vietnam remains one of the poorest nations on earth.

It should be pointed out that before the communists came to power in 1975 in Vietnam as a whole, Vietnam was one of the more affluent nations in the South-East Asian region. The fact is that the communist regime absolutely devastated the Vietnamese economy. It subjected countless millions of its 70 million people to grinding, abject poverty which should never have arisen. It is a fact that there is no way that Vietnam is going to meet its full economic potential, international community potential and the rightful place it should take in the councils of the world unless it moves, in political terms, along the same lines as it is moving economically.

There will never be a full development of the Vietnamese economy whilst Vietnam remains a totalitarian, one-party state. The process of economic reform will inevitably lead to political reform. We have to be very careful that we do all that we possibly can to ensure that that happens rather than see economic reform stalling because of the continuation of a totalitarian political regime.

There are many other things I would have liked an opportunity to say but time has beaten me. I welcome the report. I congratulate the delegation and I hope that we can collectively build on it in the future because there is much more that still needs to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only just received a copy of the report; therefore, I am not really in a position to comment on it, although, just with a casual look at it, it appears to me that there are a couple of matters which have not been thoroughly examined. It also appears that the delegation was not provided with information which is on the public record in respect of those matters.

PARA.TAB: I will examine this report. I think the idea of a human rights delegation to Vietnam was a good one. As Senator Short said, this is an area which should really be built upon. But it is also very important for the parliament and the public, in a report such as this, to be able to look at not only what has been told to the delegation but also—
