DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE COMPLAINTS LEVY BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—The committee is considering Senator Herron's amendments No. 21 and 22 moved on behalf of the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the reporting of progress on this matter, we were discussing the amendments that I had moved. In reply, the minister said that, by moving these amendments, I would negate the opportunity for information to be disseminated to patients. That is incorrect in so far as we have already passed an amendment to allow the data agency information to be collected and disseminated, so that it can go to consumers. The question I ask is: why does the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council need data material which is hospital identified and which financially identifies individual patients?

—It is not patient identified information that would be available. As I understand it, the information is to allow PHIAC to undertake its role of providing information to potential users or takers-up of private health insurance.
—Would you care to tell me the composition of PHIAC?
—I am advised that it has a commissioner and it consists of representatives from the private health insurance industry.
—And it is funded also by the private health insurance industry, is it not?
—Yes.

—So, in essence, the private health insurance industry is collecting the data and is funding the committee and you are empowering it to negotiate with the private hospitals on its own behalf. Don't you think that that puts the private health insurance industry in a very powerful position to negotiate contracts with private hospitals? Where is the equity?

—I am advised that the private health insurance organisations have any amount of data that will assist them in any of the negotiations. We are talking about aggregated data provided to PHIAC that will enable it to inform consumers about the products of health insurance.

—Surely it puts them in an enormously powerful position to negotiate contracts? We cannot say that it is just there and they will confine it in terms of knowledge. It cannot just be confined to allowing consumers to have information when it is the very same people who are negotiating contracts. Could you explain to me how they are separated one from the other?

—I think the first point is that PHIAC will have no role in negotiating any contracts between an insurance organisation and a hospital. I suppose what Senator Herron is alluding to is that the private insurance organisation may be able to get access to PHIAC data that would assist it. Is that what Senator Herron is saying?

—In your previous response you told us that they were the same people. I asked you what was the composition of PHIAC and you told me that insurance association representatives make up the membership. It is funded by the insurance association membership. It is not good enough to say that it is just here to allow information to be provided to consumers. These are the very same people. I see somebody is nodding. It may not be the same individuals, but it is certainly the same industry.

—I am advised that the data that PHIAC will get will be determined by the minister and the data that will be provided to PHIAC will not be the sort that would assist individuals in negotiations for contracts.
—Once again we have the minister's assurance, and that is what we are relying on.
—I am advised that the information under consideration will be dealt with in the next amendment and it will be a disallowable instrument.
—I want to bring to the minister's attention the point that it is linked to the previous amendment that was accepted by the Senate.
—I think at this stage I will have to ask Senator Herron to ask me the question again.

—The previous amendment aggregated the data and provided, we believe, for an added privacy provision. This amendment that I am now moving is connected with that in the sense that we are asking why they should not be put together. It has to go back for a consideration as to privacy. The government needs to consider that matter. In those circumstances, why does the Private Health Insurance Advisory Committee need to have that information? I do not think that has been satisfactorily answered.
—I am advised that the government believes that the functions of PHIAC and the provision of data to consumers are still valid, despite your suggestions.
—How do you mean `still valid'?
—That they are appropriate, particularly in terms of information to be provided to consumers to assist them to be able to make decisions about private health insurance.

—That is not under debate. The amendment that was passed previously allowed the data collection. I am debating the necessity for this information to go from the data agency to PHIAC. I do not think that has been resolved.
—I think we are at the point where we will just have to agree to disagree. The government has made its point clear and you are of a different perspective.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Herron's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chairman, I take the opportunity to congratulate you. I believe this is the first time I have been in the chamber when you have been in the chair. Congratulations on your success in that important role. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (39)Schedule 2, page 27, after item 69, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "69A. Section 82G:
Add at the end:
`(2) Determinations under paragraph (l)(ba) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment provides that the ministerial determination referred to in amendment 38 shall constitute a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The amendments bring the determination under the purview of the federal parliament. That point was fairly much alluded to in the last debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chairman, I, too, would like to congratulate you on your ascension to the chair. We certainly have no problem with the amendment proposed by the minister.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (41)Schedule 2, page 30, item 91, proposed subsection 82ZQ(1) insert the following definition:

PARA.TAB: "`medical practitioner' includes:

TAB.TAB: (a)an accredited dental practitioner; and
(b)a dental practitioner approved by the Minister for the purposes of the definition of `professional service' in subsection 3(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973; and

(c)a person on whose behalf a medical practitioner (within the meaning of subsection 3(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973), or a dental practitioner of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), renders a professional service;".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a consequential amendment only. The amendment reflects the same definition as elsewhere in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister clear up the confusion that obviously occurred last time as to the definition of a dental practitioner. At one stage we were told that it was a dental surgeon and then it was a dental practitioner. I then asked whether it was a reply to dentists in public hospitals or dentists in private hospitals. Let us clarify it once and for all.
—I am advised that this amendment allows those currently entitled to claim to continue to do so.
—Does it refer to the dental practitioners who are recognised for the purposes of medical benefits refunds under the act?
—Yes, Senator.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23)Schedule 2, page 30, item 91, omit proposed paragraph 82ZQ(1)(b), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(b) a hospital purchaser-provider agreement, a proposed hospital purchaser-provider agreement or an agreement that amends or otherwise modifies, whether in specified circumstances or not, a hospital purchaser-provider agreement;".

SPEECH.PARA: (24)Schedule 2, page 30, item 91, omit proposed paragraph 82ZQ(1)(c), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(c) a medical purchaser-provider agreement, a proposed medical purchaser-provider agreement or an agreement that amends or otherwise modifies, whether in specified circumstances or not, a medical purchaser-provider agreement;".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are being taken together because one relates to the hospital purchaser-provider agreement and the other to the medical purchaser-provider agreement. Obviously, the minister would be aware that we continue to oppose the Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill 1994 because it is an impost on insurers and contributors and, in essence, a new tax. There has been debate about that in the past—that you will hear the industry asking, as a result thereof, the contributors, to pay for complaints that come in. It is a most extraordinary position but there it is, the government has gone ahead with that and, in essence, it is another tax. We will continue to oppose the Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, these amendments propose that paragraph 82ZQ(1)(b) should be changed to read:

SPEECH.PARA: a hospital purchaser-provider agreement, a proposed hospital purchaser-provider agreement or an agreement that amends or otherwise modifies, whether in specified circumstances or not, a hospital purchaser-provider agreement.

It widens the scope of a potential inquiry under the circumstances to an agreement as well as the negotiated agreement itself. In other words, it enables the complaint commissioner to inquire into the agreement. That is consistent with the introduction of the complaints commissioner into the pre-agreement processes as provided in sections 73B and 73D.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 24 is similar to that but relates to medical purchaser-provider agreements in sections 73B, 73D and 73A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the Liberal amendments that we did look at closely. However, the legislation already gives the commissioner the power to investigate `any matter arising out of or connected with a private health insurance agreement.' We believe that is far-reaching enough and does cover what this amendment is aiming to do. So we really do not believe that this amendment is necessary.

—The government is not prepared to accept opposition amendment No. 23. The item unacceptably widens the definition of an agreement to include proposals that have not yet been agreed—this is for the purposes of review by the complaints commissioner under the opposition amendments. The aim seems to have been to have the complaints commissioner overlap with the trade practices commissioner in looking at reasons why funds do not enter into agreements.

PARA.TAB: Similar points could be made about amendment No. 24, although I would add that agreements between the hospital and an insurance company would be of a commercial nature. It is not appropriate that responsibility for reviewing agreements lies with the commissioner. If the agreements are in some way unlawful or breach legislation—for example, the Trade Practices Act—the parties have remedies which they can take.If we put together the points raised by Senator Lees and the points that I have put, we are not persuaded by Senator Herron's case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is true that they widen the scope—that is the object of the amendments—to enable an approach to the complaints commissioner in the process of setting up the purchaser-provider agreements. Surely that would be to the benefit of all rather than waiting until something occurs that necessitates something going to the trade practices commissioner or, alternatively, has to be referred to the complaints commissioner.

PARA.TAB: Certainly these amendments do widen the scope. It would seem—although the government and, as Senator Lees said, the Democrats, have looked at it closely and on balance have decided otherwise—that it is to the advantage of all in this process, hospitals and medical purchaser-provider agreements, that they can be referred in the process of establishing agreement. That would obviate the necessity to go to the complaints commissioner if ultimately the agreements did not turn out to be satisfactory to either negotiator.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (40)Schedule 2, page 30, item 91, proposed subsection 82ZQ(1), after paragraph (b) of the definition of "private health insurance arrangement", insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(ba) a practitioner agreement;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment extends the scope of investigations by the complaints commissioner to include complaints about practitioner agreements. The amendment includes in the proposed definition of `private health insurance arrangement', practitioner agreements for the purposes of proposed subsection 73BDAA, amendment 16.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have no objection to that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 25 seeks to give the complaints commissioner the ability to look at the activities of appointed agents of hospitals and practitioners. As we have lost amendments Nos. 23 and 24, I withdraw this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (42)Schedule 2, page 31, item 91 proposed paragraph 82ZRC(d), after "recommendations to" insert "the Minister or".
This amendment provides that recommendations by the complaints commissioner about regulatory or industry practices may be made to the minister.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27)Schedule 2, page 31, item 91, proposed paragraph 82ZRC(d) omit "Department", substitute "Minister".

This amendment seeks to omit some words and substitute others. If this process is going to work, it is the minister who has to have overall responsibility, especially given that the minister will have extensive powers of determination which may or may not be delegated to officials. Therefore, it is consistent to ensure that the complaints commissioner makes his or her recommendations to the minister and not the department. That is the reason behind moving that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of that amendment being negatived, I suggest to the minister that recommendations to the department are copied to the minister for information.

—Senator, as I understand it, your concern is that this may allow matters from the complaints commissioner to go to the department and never hit the minister's desk. The understanding that we have on this side is that it is able to go to the minister and the department.
—That would satisfy us.
—I believe that that is the intent of the previous amendment.
—We will now move to government/Democrat amendment No.43.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (43)Schedule 2, page 31, item 91 after proposed paragraph 82ZRC(d), insert the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(da)to make copies of the Private Patients' Hospital Charter issued under section 73F available to members of the public on request at every office of the Complaints Commissioner accessible to the public;
(db)where appropriate, to publicise the existence and availability of the Charter in its brochures and other documents, concerning health insurance, made available to the public;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment requires the complaints commissioner to make copies of the private patients' hospital charter available to members of the public at every office to which the public has access—I presume offices of relevance to bodies like hospitals—and to publicise, where appropriate, the existence and availability of the private patients' hospital charter and any brochure or other documents available to the public. The clear intention of this is to facilitate community access to the charter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw your attention to your amendment 42, schedule 2, page 31, item 91. Proposed paragraph 82ZRC(d) says: `after "recommendations to" insert "the Minister or"' the department, not `the minister and the department'.

—I am sorry if that has confused you, Senator. It is the choice of the complaints commissioner to determine whether to send complaints to the department or to the minister, but I think complaints going to the department will certainly be provided to the minister, or the minister would be informed about them. That is what I was hoping I was explaining to you. It is not the minister and the department. It is for the commissioner to choose whether he or she makes complaints known to the department or to the minister. If they go to the department, they will certainly be brought to the minister's attention.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Schedule 2, page 31, item 91, after proposed paragraph 82ZRC(d) insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(da) to inquire into the processes surrounding the negotiation of purchaser-provider agreements including, where negotiations have broken down irretrievably or where a registered organisation, a hospital or a medical practitioner has refused to negotiate, the processes relevant to that matter;".

SPEECH.PARA: This item extends the described functions of the complaints commissioner to look into negotiations where there has been an irretrievable breakdown in the negotiating process or a refusal to negotiate. This corresponds to amendments to sections 73BD and 73BDA which we lost earlier. We believe that the need to cover pre-contract processes remains.

PARA.TAB: This amendment would therefore provide a review mechanism to ensure that the paramount interests of the patients are not jeopardised by the unreasonable conduct of any of the parties in the contracting process, including the providers and funds. I commend that amendment to the committee, certainly to the Democrats, because I presume it is not accepted by the government. In the light of the loss of the previous amendments, it would seem logical that we allow a review mechanism in the bill. That is all that this amendment does.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept this amendment. It effectively tries to have the complaints commissioner usurp the jurisdiction of the trade practices commissioner. I further note that your opposition amendment No. 32 is intended to remove the requirement for insurers to pay a levy to meet the operational costs of the complaints commissioner. That would then require the Commonwealth to be obliged to a pay for a vastly expanded complaints commissioner function which would be duplicating the functions of the trade practices commissioner. So for those reasons, as you rightly predicted, the government will not be supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another one of the Liberal amendments that the Democrats looked at very closely. I think we may have to come back to this area as this legislation is implemented, but I doubt whether some of the concerns that Senator Herron has suggested previously are going to arise. At this point in time, we are not going to support this amendment. We believe that in the end it could be detrimental to the bill in terms of not allowing free negotiation to take place. It is something that we will all have to watch very closely. We already have the amendment where the Senate committee will be watching this legislation. At this time we are not prepared to support this amendment.

—We had evidence from the trade practices commissioner that he felt there was not enough jurisdictional opportunity for him in the legislation. I would dispute the minister's interpretation that we would allow this to go through to the Trade Practices Commission if a dispute arose. That is the idea of the review process and the purpose of this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I certainly do support what the minister said in that we are opposing the funding of the complaints commissioner. Yes, it does put an impost on government, of necessity. As the government has already passed that amendment, a position of private health insurance complaints commissioner will be established. As we are opposing it, it follows that we believe that position should be paid for by government—that is, the taxpayer—for the reasons that I stated previously. I accept the reality of numbers. I also accept the assurance from Senator Lees, on behalf of the Democrats, that they will closely look at that matter. There will later be the opportunity in amendments to speak about the place of the trade practices commissioner, and I will reserve my comments on that until we come to that amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (28)Schedule 2, page 32, item 91, at the end of proposed subsection 82ZSB(2) add:

PARA.TAB: "and, if the Complaints Commissioner investigates the complaint and the complaint is one in relation to section 82ZQ, the Complaints Commissioner may recommend that existing payment arrangements between a hospital or a medical practitioner and a registered organisation remain in place until the investigation has been completed and a report submitted".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment adds a new paragraph to proposed section 82ZSB(2). It provides that, if the commissioner refers a complaint to a fund for investigation, and a report to him or her, the agreement between a hospital or practitioner in the fund remains in place until a decision is taken on the investigation report. The purpose of this is that it should obviate the need for affected parties to seek temporary remedies, such as an injunction, pending the outcome of the decision. It would also prevent a patient from being out of pocket because of an investigation. Essentially, it allows the continuation of the status quo until a report from the commission, and that would seem a logical thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept this amendment. The amendment flows from the opposition's amendments to allow the complaints commissioner to intervene—I stress `intervene'—in purchaser-provider agreements. That is not supported by the govern ment.

—I ask the minister: what is the government's argument against the purpose of this amendment which, while awaiting the decision on a report, is purely to allow the status quo to continue? It is not totally consequent on the previous lost amendment.

—The principal concern the government has is what I have said, that there will be an intervention by the complaints commissioner into a negotiating process. I am also advised that it is highly likely that most contracts or arrangements will continue as is during such a negotiating period. The principal concern for the government is that we do not want that intervention.
—I am advised that it could relate to a contract that had already been negotiated and that is coming up for review by the commissioner. Is that covered by the minister's previous statement?
—If Senator Herron is concerned about payments continuing, yes, that is covered.
—So the payments would continue even if the parties were disaffected and took out injunctions one against the other pending the outcome of the decision?

—What people do in terms of those contracts or in taking out injunctions and so on will be a matter for courts to decide. I could not give an assurance about arrangements if people proceeded in that kind of way. I am giving Senator Herron the advice that is provided to me in responding to what we understand to be the intention of his amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move amendment No. 44:

SPEECH.PARA: (44)Schedule 2, page 32, item 91, after proposed section 82ZSB, insert the following new section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Complaints Commissioner may refer matters to the Trade Practices Commission

PARA.TAB: "`82ZSBA.(1) If, in the Complaints Commissioner's opinion, a complaint raises a matter that could be dealt with more effectively or conveniently by the Trade Practices Commission, the Complaints Commissioner must, subject to subsection (2), refer the matter to the Trade Practices Commission.
`(2) The Complaints Commissioner must not refer the matter to the Trade Practices Commission unless the complainant agrees to the referral.
`(3) If the Complaints Commissioner refers the matter to the Trade Practices Commission, he or she must:

TAB.TAB: (a)give written notice to the complainant stating that the matter has been so referred; and
(b)give to the Trade Practices Commission any information or documents that relate to the complaint and that are in the Complaints Commissioner's possession or under his or her control.

PARA.TAB: `(4) The Trade Practices Commission may hold an investigation into the matter and, if it decides to do so, it must, within 30 working days after the referral, report to the Complaints Commissioner on:

TAB.TAB: (a)the conduct of the investigation; and
(b)any findings that it has made as a result of the investigation.

PARA.TAB: `(5) If the Trade Practices Commission decides not to hold an investigation into the matter, it must, within 30 working days after the referral, give to the Complaints Commissioner a written notice informing the Complaints Commissioner of its decision and of the reasons for its decision.
`(6) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "working day" means a day that is not a Saturday or Sunday or a public holiday in any State or Territory.'.".

This amendment enables the complaints commissioner, subject to agreement of the complainant, to refer to the Trade Practices Commission complaints that it believes could be dealt with more effectively or conveniently by that authority, and for the TPC to determine whether or not to conduct an investigation into the complaint and to inform the complaints commissioner within 30 days of the conduct of an investigation or, if there is no investigation, its reason for not proceeding.

PARA.TAB: The amendments are to expressly clarify in legislation that complaints be referred to the TPC where considered appropriate by the complaints commissioner.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee will now deal with opposition amendment No. 29.

—My proposed amendment No. 29 seeks to add a new paragraph (c) to the proposed sub-section 82ZSD to enable the commissioner to recommend that the minister can direct a registered fund to enter into an agreement with the specific hospital or practitioner, plus the same for medical agreements. Obviously, since the opposition lost the earlier amendments regarding purchaser-provider agreements, the proposed amendment is not now relevant.
—We will now move to opposition amendment No. 30.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 30Schedule 2, page 35, item 91, after proposed section 82ZTB insert the following new sections:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Complaints Commissioner free to consult Purchaser-Provider Panel

PARA.TAB: " `82ZTBA. The Complaints Commissioner may in the course of investigating complaints and preparing reports or recommendations for the Minister, consult with the Purchaser-Provider Panel.' ".

TAB.EMPHASIS: Complaints Commissioner to consult with Trade Practices Commission

PARA.TAB: `82ZTBB. Where, in the opinion of the Complaints Commissioner, there is prima facie evidence of conduct of the nature of a restrictive trade practice within the meaning of the Trade Practices Act 1974, the Complaints Commissioner must consult with the Trade Practices Commission and have regard to the advice of the Trade Practices Commission on the matter before reporting on it'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition amendment No. 30 relates to the proposed new section 82ZTBA which allows the complaints commissioner to seek the advice of the purchaser-provider panel on matters before him. The recommendation he makes, however, remains his own responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The proposed new section 82ZTBB obliges the complaints commissioner, if a matter before him involves a prima facie restrictive trade practice, such as a de facto cartel, emerging in the negotiating process, to seek the advice of the Trade Practices Commission and to give close consideration to the advice of the commission in preparing his recommendation.

We believe that this mechanism will ensure that in terms of unfair competitive practices on the part of any party to an agreement or negotiation—certainly not just the funds—the behaviour or complaint can be referred to the TPC for assessment consistent with the principles of the Trade Practices Act. I am sure the minister will be in agreement with that.

The commissioner would be obliged to take restrictive practices into account if that were within the scope of the complaint under investigation by him. So far as possible, it would send the message that these contracts are not beyond the general principles of the trade practices law.

I would be interested to know what is the Democrats approach to this matter. I understand that they, too, have considered the matter closely. It seems a logical argument that I have put forward to the committee. Surely if there is a prima facie restrictive trade practice, then this amendment should be agreed to in order to cover that eventuality.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Although we think that largely what Senator Herron is trying to do in this amendment has already been done by our amendment No. 44, we will be supporting this amendment as an additional safeguard to enable that consultation to take place with the purchaser-provider panel and the Trade Practices Commission as well as with the commissioner.
—There are arguments that could be put against this amendment, but the government will accept it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move amendment No. 31:

SPEECH.PARA: 31Schedule 2, page 38, item 91, after proposed section 82ZVA insert the following new section:

PARA.TAB: " `82ZVAA. Nothing in this Act shall prevent the activities, decisions and recommendations of the Complaints Commissioner (and the Purchaser-Provider Panel in relation to an activity concerning the work of the Complaints Commissioner) from being subject to any appropriate provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982.' ".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would ensure that the Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner's activities and findings are subject to external review under established mechanisms. The lack of such provision is a coalition concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting this amendment. The amendment is seen as superfluous as the Complaints Commission is already subject to the ADJR and FOI review. As the commissioner is intended in the near future to have deliberative powers, it is not seen as appropriate for the AAT to review decisions over which it would have no jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move opposition amendment No. 32:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2, page 38, item 91, omit proposed section 82ZVC.

This amendment seeks to omit all references to the complaints levy in schedule 2. It is consistent with our opposing the Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill, which we have foreshadowed previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I made clear earlier, the government will not be accepting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move government/Democrat amendment No. 45:

SPEECH.PARA: (45)Schedule 2, page 38, after item 91, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "91A. After subsection 105AB(4A):
Insert:
`(4B) An application may be made to the Tribunal for review of:

TAB.TAB: (a)a decision of the Minister to make, or not to make, a determination under section 73EA; or
(b)a decision of the Minister to revoke, or not to revoke, such a determination under section 73ED.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment allows for the determinations by the minister under proposed section 73EA and section 73ED relating to amendment No. 37, to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where the minister makes a determination to remove a benefit under sub-paragraph (bf)11 of schedule 1 of the National Health Act.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move government/Democrat amendment No. 46:

SPEECH.PARA: (46)Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, before proposed paragraph (bf), insert the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "`(bea)Each applicable benefits arrangement of the organisation must provide for benefits to be payable in respect of all kinds of hospital treatment that are one or more of the following:

TAB.TAB: (i)palliative care;
(ii)rehabilitation;
(iii)psychiatric care.

PARA.TAB: (beb)Subject to the condition set out in paragraph (d), the levels of benefits payable in respect of those kinds of hospital treatment must equal or exceed the respective levels of benefits determined for the purposes of paragraph (bga) in respect of those kinds of hospital treatment.".

SPEECH.PARA: This requires that organisations must include the provision of benefits in all applicable benefits arrangements for hospital treatment related to palliative rehabilitation and psychiatric care.

PARA.TAB: The government has accepted the view that without this amendment there is a risk that products may be offered without such benefits and that, for example, many young people might be unaware of the risk of their requiring rehabilitation or palliative care. I do not think we need to single out young people, but it is felt necessary that health insurance funds not be able to avoid obligations on behalf of people in need of psychiatric, palliative and rehabilitative care.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We pushed very hard to ensure that this amendment appeared in this legislation. The funds were already moving to exclude psychiatric care from their tables. We believe that in particular young people and indeed the general community are involved in this area. We felt that we had to leave people who require these services to be covered in the private sector. I believe that leaving the matter in that category will encourage the funds to develop, with hospitals, some far more innovative packages than they have been prepared to develop so far.

PARA.TAB: I have had some constructive discussions in the past couple of weeks in my home state where plans have been set out to use the community nursing service for a range of post acute care programs. Hospitals are actively looking at a range of far more appropriate packages in this area. I believe this amendment will encourage the development of better options for people who are privately insured. Many people would far prefer to be treated in their own homes, if possible, or at least in a day situation where they move in and out of private hospitals without having to spend time in a bed. This is a very important amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Lees and the government know, the opposition pushed very strongly for the inclusion of palliative care, rehabilitation and psychiatric care. In that regard, I welcome the amendment. However, Minister, you have not stated what benefits will be payable. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: Each applicable benefits arrangement of the organization must provide for benefits—
Does that mean the current benefits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided with words that make quite clear the level of benefit payable. Amendment 46, paragraph (beb) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to the condition set out in paragraph (d), the levels of benefits payable in respect of those kinds of hospital treatment must equal or exceed the respective levels of benefits determined for the purposes of paragraph (bga) in respect of those kinds of hospital treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we have that in English? I am sure that has been provided by your advisers and I have no doubt they know what that means; but I would be very interested to know.
—It must be at least the default benefit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask for further clarification? It is my understanding that if a person selects one of the tables that has full contracts—in other words, the contracts are arranged so there is no gap payment—that person will be fully covered. That might be top rate hospital care. I want to make sure, Minister, that we are not talking only about the default benefit but that for people on full cover, there will be full cover for psychiatric, rehabilitative and palliative care.
—Your understanding is correct.

—That brings me to my second point. I am pleased that Senator Lees asked that question because it was to follow from my previous statement. Minister, are you aware that already your own agency, Medibank Private, in announcing its new tables, has excluded certain benefits within those tables—
—It is not passed yet.

—I appreciate that. The agency has jumped the gun, I suppose, in that regard. That also poses the interesting question of when it thought the legislation would go through and whether those changes were to be announced saying, `Here we are, we have responded very quickly to the passage of legislation and we have introduced new tables'. Minister, can't you see that, in essence, by allowing that to occur, the community rating principle is destroyed. If some things can be excluded from tables—I think one in seven Australians in a lifetime can expect to get some serious mental illness requiring care—you are already chipping away at a community rating principle, if not destroying it because that opens up competition between funds in relation to tables that are provided.

PARA.TAB: I accept the assurance that this is in relation to benefits as they currently exist and the intent of the amendment is to include palliative care, rehabilitation and psychiatric care. Could you respond as to the exclusion. It still allows insurance companies to offer coverage on certain tables, but excluding certain benefits. Another example I can give is the exclusion of knee replacements. That is one of the very expensive items.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once this legislation is passed, insurance companies will not be able to exclude these categories from their packages.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (47)Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, proposed subparagraphs (bf)(i) and (ii), omit the subparagraphs, substitute the following subparagraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(i)benefits that are payable in respect of such an episode of hospital treatment, provided in a hospital or day hospital facility with which the organisation does not have a hospital purchaser-provider agreement covering episodes of hospital treatment of that kind, in situations of emergency; and

(ii)benefits that are payable in respect of such an episode of hospital treatment, provided in a hospital or day hospital facility with which the organisation does not have a hospital purchaser-provider agreement covering episodes of hospital treatment of that kind, otherwise than in situations of emergency.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment clarifies the position of a hospital which has a purchaser-provider agreement with an organisation for treatments other than those agreed to in paragraph (bf). The inclusion of the words `of that kind' ensures that the emergency and default entitlements are not compromised. Conceivably, funds will have contracts with hospitals for specific treatments.

PARA.TAB: As the bill currently stands, it could be interpreted that where a contributor enters a hospital for treatment and is not subject to a contract between the fund and the hospital, no emergency benefit would apply due to the existence of any other contract under the hospital purchaser-provider arrangements. The amendment overcomes this interpretation by clearly removing the general application of the contracts to specific treatments. In these cases, normal benefits would be payable in accordance with the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that that would cover all situations of emergency. Can you give me a categorical assurance, Minister, that it covers all emergencies? I would expect you to follow that with your definition of emergency.

—I am advised that I can give you a categorical assurance that, yes, it does cover all emergencies. The definition of emergency may be `admission through an emergency department'. This definition is something we wish to assist you with but it is important that it be clarified further with the industry. If it is not written down, it probably needs to be—or at least further determined. Even the words `admission through an emergency department' would not always constitute an emergency. People may be rushed to hospital but you would certainly know that sometimes that turns out not to be an emergency. That sort of thing might be what you are looking at for the clarification of everybody involved.

—That is correct. If you, Mr Chairman, or Senator Crowley were to have an acute, severe and agonising abdominal pain, it would be an emergency for you; but it may not be if we have not got a definition of what constitutes an emergency. It is important that this definition be clarified because it opens up a whole spectrum of possibilities.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Crowley said, `admission through an emergency department' is not sufficient. There might not be an emergency department. It may well be that `emergency' is indefinable. What is an emergency for you or Senator Crowley may not be an emergency in the mind of the treating medical practitioner or for the hospital concerned. If we are to put things into legislation, we need to have our definitions clarified; and I think it is important that that be done. Do you have an answer to that; or are you just going to leave it up in the air?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had said that we would be discussing that with the industry and seeking that a definition be included in regulations.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 33Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, proposed subparagraph (b)(i), add:

PARA.TAB: "or in a State in which the organisation does not otherwise operate".

SPEECH.PARA: 34Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, proposed subparagraph (bf)(ii), add:

PARA.TAB: "in a State in which the organisation normally operates".

SPEECH.PARA: These new amendments propose a new paragraph to schedule 1 of the National Health Act by adding `or in a state in which the organisation does not otherwise operate'. Closed funds are not national. That has not been considered in the legislation. I would say that the majority are not national. That is the purpose of introducing this amendment.

PARA.TAB: While we do not oppose this bill's removing of state based registration for funds—we are obviously in favour of that—in practice most funds would continue to operate in their current areas of operation, at least for the time being, even with national registration. Therefore, we are proposing that being outside the funds' normal state or states of coverage would equate with an emergency situation and therefore attract the average level of benefit for the types of episodes. The government may well say that the funds can have national registration under the legislation. Most funds do not have it now, but they can have it under the legislation. That still does not cover the situation with closed funds, which we have agreed will be phased out. We need to cover that by legislation. That is the purpose of this amendment.

Amendment No. 34 adds `in a state in which the organisation normally operates', therefore defining the physical jurisdiction of the provision more tightly. I would be interested to know why this amendment is not acceptable, given that closed funds are not national and currently some funds are not national.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill is effectively eliminating state boundaries from the operation of insurance funds. This amendment would reintroduce the pattern where the state has importance. Travellers are already protected when they require emergency treatment, and the clause would open up the possibility for abuse where a contributor specifically travels to another state for services that would attract higher benefits than had been purchased under the contributor's policy.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the emergency benefit is to protect people who, through no fault of their own, find themselves in a hospital with which their fund does not have a contract. This amendment would set the emergency benefit in all situations, having the insurer open to contributors shopping around for the best payment. The insurer should at first instance package the appropriate product rather than attempt to manipulate the system. The government-Democrat amendments Nos 47 and 48 as they relate to item 94 in the bill include extensive provisions to set the default benefit level or levels.

Finally, I am advised that a number of the closed funds are seeking to go national or to make provisions or arrangements across the country. While that does not cover all of them—I would not want to be understood as saying that—a number of the funds are looking at ways to cover their members in states other than their own. The concern we have is to not recreate the state limitations nor to encourage people to cross state boundaries shopping around for cheaper provisions for elective care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Crowley, that argument is a bit fatuous. Are you really suggesting that people are going to go interstate to shop around for medical care when you have already assured us that default payments are already covered by their closed fund? It may well be that some of the closed funds are attempting to go national, but there are many that are not that are state based. Mount Isa Mines is probably an example. I think the majority of the contributors there are based in Mount Isa for obvious reasons. It is hard enough for them to get out of Mount Isa now without suggesting that they will go interstate because of some perceived need for medical attention. I do not accept that your reply covers this amendment.

—This is about elective surgery. I ask you to consider the case of Albury-Wodonga. It may be that people do shop around. We may prefer different language. They may be advised of certain things. As you yourself said, people who have elective surgery in another state are covered by the default payment. The government is not persuaded by your amendment. We are concerned that, if it were introduced, it would open up possibilities for abuse. It may be fatuous and it may not be realistic, but there are communities in our country that live close to borders where moving across the border is a usual practice. I can also refer you to Broken Hill. Again, I suggest that the argument I have given you is sufficient to explain why the government is not accepting these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (48)Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, proposed paragraph (bg), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(bg)Subject to the condition set out in paragraph (d), the level of benefit payable in respect of an episode of hospital treatment under subparagraph (i) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) must equal or exceed:

TAB.TAB: (i)the average level of benefit payable by the organization in respect of an episode of hospital treatment of that kind in the hospitals or day hospital facilities with which the organization has hospital purchaser-provider agreements; or
(ii)the level of benefit that would have been payable if subparagraph (ii) of that condition had applied in respect of the episode of hospital treatment;
whichever is higher.

PARA.TAB: (bga)Subject to the condition set out in paragraph (d), the level of benefit payable in respect of an episode of hospital treatment under subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) must equal:

TAB.TAB: (i)the level of benefit determined in writing by the Minister for the purposes of this paragraph in respect of episodes of hospital treatment of that kind; or

(ii)if more than one level of benefit has been so determined in respect of episodes of hospital treatment of that kind (see paragraph (bgb))—whichever of those levels of benefit is applicable to the circumstances in which the episode of hospital treatment was provided.

PARA.TAB: (bgb)A determination for the purposes of paragraph (bga) may specify different levels of benefit in respect of the same kind of episode of hospital treatment, each such level of benefit being applicable to the circumstances specified in the determination to be applicable to that level of benefit.".

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment provides for the following—paragraph (bg) of schedule 1 of the National Health Act will remove any conflict between the level of default benefits and the restriction contained in existing paragraph (d) of the schedule which provides that benefits must not exceed fees or charges. Two new paragraphs, (bga) and (bgb), are inserted in schedule 1 of the act determining a default benefit.

PARA.TAB: New paragraph (bga) requires funds to pay default benefits as determined by the minister. New paragraph (bgb) allows the minister to determine different levels of such benefits. This allows for different benefit structures in different states and in both public and private hospitals. These amendments ensure that funds pay the benefit determined by the minister to non-contracted hospitals. This benefit will be determined at a level equivalent to the basic table, and it will maintain consistency with current arrangements.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add that this was another amendment that the Democrats felt was very important. Firstly, this ensures that there is a default benefit and, secondly, it provides a process for the determination of that default benefit.
—The opposition will not be opposing this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (49)Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, proposed paragraph (bh), omit the paragraph.

As initially proposed, the arrangements for payments of default benefit were to remain until 1998, at which time these arrangements would be further considered and retained or repealed. The amendment ensures the continuation of the default arrangements of the bill beyond 1989.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We insisted upon this amendment after consultation with the Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Catholic Hospitals Association. The Office of Parliamentary Counsel advised that this was the cleanest and simplest way to make it very clear that the default benefit continued unless the other amendment that we moved earlier concerning a ministerial determination came into play and then removed it. It was always the intention of the Australian Democrats that the default benefit continued and that only if there was a determination should it cease for that particular hospital. So I hope that this does make it very clear to the opposition.
—Is the default benefit the basic table?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The default benefit is initially the basic table, yes, and then there is the ability, as it is a disallowable instrument, for us to alter it. I understand that once casemix comes in the private hospitals will be very keen to revisit this and to perhaps look at some different arrangement. That is possible as this will be a disallowable instrument.
—I appreciate what Senator Lees said, but it has not been stated by the minister—and I presume the minister accepts your statement, Senator Lees—that the default benefit will be the basic table.
—Initially, it will be the basic table.
—Obviously, initially, Minister, because in the passage of time the basic table will disappear.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 35Schedule 2, page 39, item 94, omit proposed paragraph (bh), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: " `(bh) The level of benefit payable in respect of hospital treatment under subparagraph (ii) of the conditions set out in paragraph (bf) must be no less than 50 per cent of the average level of benefit payable by the organisation in respect of an episode of hospital treatment of that kind in the hospitals or day hospital facilities with which the organisation has hospital purchaser-provider agreements, including the coverage of psychiatric care, palliative care and rehabilitation services.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deletes the government's proposed new paragraph (bh) which puts a sunset on default benefits of 1 July 1998 or a later date if specified by regulation.

PARA.TAB: We propose a new (bh) similar to (bg) imposing a default level of benefit of 50 per cent of a fund's average per type of episode. And by opting for averaging rather than the basic table option preferred by the government we may be imposing greater costs on insurers, but this is balanced by allowing a benefit level to be set in the marketplace rather than determined by government.

We have been advised by the government that the 50 per cent of average may impose some complex statistical and analytical problem, but we believe it is important that default benefits are linked to the marketplace and not some arbitrary level as determined by government and averaging is a way of achieving that.

I draw the minister's attention to the fact that the previous amendment that she proposed, and which was passed, refers to the averaging, and it is referred to in the legislation itself. So it is interesting to have that argument put to us as it proposes a complex analytical problem when referring to the legislation itself. Page 39, clause 94 after paragraph (be) of schedule 1, (bg) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The level of benefit payable in respect of an episode of hospital treatment under subparagraph (i) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) must equal or exceed the average level of benefit payable by the organisation in respect of an episode of hospital treatment of that kind in the hospitals or day hospital facilities with which the organisation has hospital purchaser-provider agreements.
So the government itself accepts the averaging and we are proposing in this amendment that we refer that to the average per type of episode.

PARA.TAB: There is also a logistic problem that the basic table is abolished from July 1997 as previously mentioned. Even if the default was fixed at the level of the basic table payment, the real value of this figure would inevitably diminish as inflation increased.

But of crucial importance is the removal of the default time limit. The availability of a default is the key to the voluntary nature of the proposed contracting system. That was supported by the Democrats and we pushed it within the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee and it has now been accepted. Without a default the hospital or medical provider would have to lock into the contract system to put a solid floor on their income components not covered by Medicare rebates. The financial pressure to join the system could then become overwhelming.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That the question for the adjournment be proposed at 7.20 p.m. today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on the role of national sporting coaches in the international transfer of Australian players be extended to 29 June 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice I have just given.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The soccer inquiry has required more time to complete than was anticipated when the terms of reference were given to the committee on 8 December 1994 and 2 February 1995. Ten days of hearings have already been held, and the committee proposes to hold another six days of hearings between now and 9 June. An extension of time to report will give the committee the extra time it needs to complete its program of hearings, fully consider the evidence it has taken, and prepare its final report on this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on arts and cultural education in Australian educational institutions be extended to 29 June 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice I have just given.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry into arts education has proved to be somewhat larger in scope and more complex than was anticipated when the terms of reference were given to the committee on 24 February 1994. Twelve days of hearings have been held, and 185 witnesses heard. This year, the committee has had to give attention to the soccer inquiry which the Senate asked it to undertake on 8 December 1994. An extension of time to report will give the committee the extra time it needs to fully consider the evidence it has taken on arts education, and to prepare its final report on this reference.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE COMPLAINTS LEVY BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron, your proposed amendment sets the default benefit at half the average contract payment for the type of episode in question. As has already been discussed, this is a very complex arrangement. It is a more complex arrangement than that proposed by the government. It would require a great deal of data across the full range of cases.

PARA.TAB: There are technical problems with averaging out and reflecting fairly those cases which have many short stays as against those with long stays. The level of 50 per cent is likely to be well above the basic table. That would certainly increase fund outlays and would weaken motivation to enter into contracts.

The government amendment achieves the intention of your amendment in a much more flexible way. It allows the minister to set different benefit levels for different patient groups, as well as to take other factors into account. On the evidence that you have given us, the government is not persuaded to support your amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has already said that in the emergency situation it will need that data anyway. As to the point that the amendment is complex, I do not see that it is any more complex than the government's proposal. The argument put to me by one of the officers is that there would be outlays at the extreme end of the range. The reality is that the majority of things that occur will be common situations. With the introduction of casemix, I do not see that this measure is any more complex in averaging out than taking 50 per cent of a fund's average for a particular type of episode. The complexity of the measure is not a strong argument.

PARA.TAB: Minister, you then used the argument that the figure of 50 per cent would be well above the basic table. That is something that will need to be checked but my information is that at the very most it might be 7 per cent above what is being proposed in the legislation. We do not know that for sure because we do not have the data, although the government must have some idea of what it is.

You have previously accepted averaging in relation to emergencies. It may be that getting that data might impose a somewhat greater cost on insurance but that is balanced by the benefit level being set by the market place rather than by determination of government. Surely that is in the best interests of the patients. The points you have made about complexity, the fact that the benefit might be well above the basic table and that you do not accept averaging are negated by the points I have made in moving this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The averaging that we accept for emergency cases is likely to be for far fewer and simpler cases. It will not require the same complexity of calculation and will not be setting a floor price.

PARA.TAB: The other point that needs to be made about why the government prefers its way of arriving at the new basic table is that it is likely to be above the existing basic table. The information provided to me says that benefits will be well above the basic table. It is important to remember that this will increase fund outlays, which is likely to be a significant cost to the funds and could be a factor contributing to the weakening of the motivation of other hospitals to enter into contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —This illustrates my point that the government is concerned that it will not encourage coverage through the proposals in this legislation. The level imposed is being arbitrarily set by government rather than being determined by the market place. The minister has already accepted that averaging occurs in emergency situations. I cannot see why the government does not let it occur in non-emergency situations.

PARA.TAB: The minister has already stated that the government has had to revisit what constitutes an emergency. She might be leaving the door wide open for the applicability of this legislation to a default benefit lower than 50 per cent of the average. That in turn would mitigate against people taking up private health insurance because, using her argument, the refunds could be lower.

I suspect that the whole purpose of this exercise is to kick people out of private health insurance. I have heard nothing that would attract people to taking private health insurance. The minister is saying that the government will not average the default level of benefit to 50 per cent of the fund average for type of episode; it will make it lower by decree. The budget has given us an increase in the Medicare tax. People with private health insurance will pay five times for their health care: through the Medicare tax, through general taxation, through state tax, through private health insurance and then through out-off-pocket expenses.

By not accepting our amendment, the minister is saying that, in a situation requiring a default level of benefit, these people will get a lower refund than that which the market determines. Yet she says that this legislation will encourage people to take private health insurance. As I have stated, I have never believed that it would do that but that, in essence, is what the minister is saying now.

I cannot see the logic in saying that there will be a lower benefit and that, therefore, people should be covered by private health insurance. The default payment, determined by the government, will be lower than the cost of the average per type of episode. Could the minister explain that to me?

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably not, Senator, since you start off by being absolutely clear that you know what this legislation is for—to drive people out of private health insurance. I am perfectly prepared to hear you say that you do not think that this bill will encourage people, but you do not stop there. You are saying that this government is determined to drive people out of private health insurance. Your attitude means that we cannot expect to come to an agreement. You are determined to know something contrary to what the government is saying. I will certainly give you an explanation but it is not assisted by that clear statement of your attitude to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I can only reiterate the points I have already made. The other point that needs to be made is that it is the intention of this legislation that there be contracts. We do not expect that all hospitals will be allowed to come and go, cheerfully accepting your definition of market forces applying to the basic target. The idea of a 50 per cent averaging out being defined as letting the market run its course is straining the definition of letting the market run its course.

We are quite clear that we want that flexibility in setting the different benefit levels. We want that flexibility as much as possible to keep the cost down because that will keep the cost against the funds down—that is, the claims against the funds—and it will certainly encourage people not just to take the basic cover, to risk it, but to take the more comprehensive cover that happens under contracts. So, Senator, there is nothing further that can be said. If you want to start from your position—and I can understand your position—then I do not believe that we will be able to make anything clearer because we do start from quite different positions here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Lawrence disputes what I said. I will quote from her second reading speech. Minister Crowley says that is my interpretation. What other interpretation could there be of the words of the minister herself? Minister Lawrence said:

SPEECH.PARA: The real test now is whether the funds can actually negotiate good prices with hospitals. A lot of the agitation that we have seen from hospitals and doctors alike has been frankly because this—
and I italicise this—
. . . is about reducing the amount of money which goes to doctors in hospitals and therefore reducing the premiums.
The minister goes on:
. . . they will do so by actually, basically, reducing the amount that they pay hospitals and doctors because it is actually a way of reducing their income.
That is the purpose of the legislation in the minister's own words. The minister continues:
. . . frankly, this is about reducing the amount of money which goes to doctors and hospitals—

On the other hand, if that is the reason for the legislation—and we can but believe the minister's own words—by not accepting this amendment, you are also going to reduce the refund to the patients. I will accept the minister's words that this is about reducing the amount of money that goes to doctors and hospitals—and perhaps that is why they are objecting—but you are saying to me now that you will accept the averaging for emergencies but you will not accept it for the default level of benefit; you do not accept that there will be a fall in the number of those privately insured.

PARA.TAB: Time will tell which one of us is correct. That is a debating point, but I wanted to draw to your attention that statement by the minister herself. She in that statement did not refer to the number of people who are going to take out private health insurance, although—and this is the laughable point about it—in her second reading speech, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: These reforms focus on consumer rights and provide:
.Value for money in private health insurance;
.A wider choice of products achieved by enabling health funds to make contracts with hospitals and doctors; and
.The reforms also provide for efficiency measures and equitable access.

If that is what she said in her second reading speech, and it is, and she also said subsequently that it is about reducing the amount of money, can you understand, Minister, why there is a certain amount of scepticism on the part of the opposition about what is hoped to be achieved by this legislation when you tell me that the purpose is to increase the number of people who are privately insured?

PARA.TAB: They were your words, that it was to increase the number privately insured, and I think the Australian Health Insurance Association representative said that it was to slow the rate of increase in premiums, implying that that, in effect, would mean that people would be more likely to stay in private health insurance than not. On the other hand, as of the budget announcement last night, the increase in the Medicare levy overall, regardless of income, inevitably will force people out of private insurance. I think that I should respond to your statement with Minister Lawrence's own words, and they are on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Herron has quoted the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). I would like to quote the shadow minister, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), and suggest that the opposition perhaps does not have quite as many problems with this legislation as he has been suggesting. On the front page of Australian Medicine the shadow minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the critical area of offering contracts to doctors, the changes had the potential to be "beneficial on all sides".

I think that if we begin looking at your amendments here to push up the point at which we are even going to be encouraging people to get into contracts at all, we are actually undoing what this legislation is all about. The article continues:
Asked specifically if the Opposition would repeal the provisions for contracts with doctors, he said:
No, we would not. I have said that if doctors wish to sign contracts freely, they should be allowed to do so.

I am concerned that some of your amendments are actually going against what the shadow minister seems to be suggesting; that is, that we should get this legislation through and give it a chance to allow those contracts, voluntary on all sides, to actually be put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow minister made those remarks in the context of the amendments that we were proposing. We are not proposing these amendments for fun. It is on the presupposition that we achieve our amendments. That is point number one. PARA.TAB: I heard today that Medibank Private, just using that as an example, said that it now had this 100 per cent cover for private hospitals. TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that we have already done this in amendment No. 46. Indeed, in this legislation, we are looking, as casemix is introduced, for far more than just psychiatric care being able to be given outside the hospital. PARA.TAB: It is one issue that I have taken up extensively with the funds over the last couple of weeks. I have been able to have a number of very productive meetings with them. They explained their version of where they see this going, which in many ways virtually matches the hospitals' version; that is, as casemix is introduced, hospitals and doctors will be deciding whether it is appropriate for part of the treatment to be given in the home on a day basis or in some other way.
