SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government-Democrat amendment No. 46 specifically states:

SPEECH.PARA: "`(bea)Each applicable benefits arrangement of the organization must provide for benefits to be payable in respect of all kinds of hospital treatment that are one or more of the following:

It does not refer to out-of-hospital treatment. I know that Senator Lees has mentioned that in the debate. In that debate I asked what benefit it was. She assured me that it would be the applicable benefit that is currently available. This amendment enables it to cover outpatient care as well.

PARA.TAB: The current situation is that it is clearly defined whether care occurs in a hospital situation. Various hospitals, particularly psychiatric hospitals, have been developed to be used for domiciliary care and for the intensive management of patients. Virtually all they provide is domiciliary care. There is very little of an acute nature of treatment available in those hospitals. As part of that, they have outpatient treatments. In other words, the patient may live in the establishment or, on the other hand, stay at home at night and come back for day care. That is not provided for in item No. 46.

Another example relates to palliative care. There is a very serious concern by palliative care providers that it is almost by grace and favour of insurance associations that any coverage is given. There is a requirement, as Senator Lees knows, for patients in the home who are receiving palliative care to be under the care of a medical practitioner for the purpose of prescribing drugs, even though the treatment may be carried out by a nurse in the home environment. So specifically this amendment covers outpatient care.

There is no requirement for outpatient care in item No. 46. I know that Senator Lees said in debate that it would enable that. It specifically refers to all kinds of hospital treatment. There is certainly an overlap, particularly in these three areas. There is an overlap with regard to other situations as well. As I understand it, it is unlikely to be offered within tables developed by private health insurance organisations. Those three areas are not ones that any of us can predict we are likely to need, so they can be excluded from tables. As I mentioned previously, it chips away at the community rating principle in so far as, by excluding items such as these from benefits tables, insurance companies can certainly compete with each other. That was the purport of the statement by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in relation to the insurance organisations, when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: It very much depends on the extent to which now that they don't have to be price takers, the funds can genuinely negotiate a better deal, because we have seen a rapid escalation in the cost of private health care and premiums and out-of-pocket costs way out of line with input cost increases and I think any reasonable assessment would reach the conclusion there is room for the funds to get a better deal for their holders.

As Dr Duckett said before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee, if they do get a better deal for their shareholders, then that better deal can either go to reducing premiums or to reserves. It can go to wherever they like; it will not necessarily lower premiums.

PARA.TAB: Our amendment ensures that where there is an overlap in this regard between, on the one hand, hospital care and, on the other hand, completely outpatient care provided by medical practitioners, obviously there will be no contract, as I see it. If it is totally outpatient, then there is no provision in amendment No. 46 moved by the government and the Democrats for that situation. It may well be that there is an opportunity for hospitals to have an outreach situation. Certainly, it gets very complex when you get into that.

In some cases, specific Commonwealth grants are given to hospitals to provide, for example, post-acute care in the home situation so that patients can be discharged earlier from an acute hospital and looked after in their homes. But they are specific grants that on the one hand may be part of Commonwealth-state agreements but on the other hand may be directly from the state governments to specific hospitals. I instanced in the Community Affairs Legislation Committee a particular patient who was unable to get domiciliary care. Because she had come from a private hospital, gone back to her home and had not come from a public hospital, the nursing association that provided the domiciliary care had no funding from the private hospital.

There is a need for an amendment such as this to allow for outpatient coverage not specifically related only to hospital treatment. That is but another example of the same thing. It may be in relation to psychiatric care, rehabilitation care, palliative care or even acute or post-acute care as an outpatient. It does not seem that these particular matters are covered in either the original legislation or amendment No. 46. If I am correct in that assessment, and I believe that I am, I ask the minister: how does a patient get covered for care outside the hospital as an outpatient?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke about this matter last time we discussed this bill five or six weeks ago. I have done a considerable amount of work on it in the intervening five weeks. I am assured by the various parties concerned that, if it is a medical decision that people are better cared for in their homes, the funds will do everything they possibly can to facilitate the hospitals and support them through that process.

PARA.TAB: In my home state, one of the funds is looking at the moment at working with a home nursing service—the biggest one in South Australia; it has been running for six years—and is starting to set up processes. It will get from the home nursing service its recent data on who it has been caring for. I have looked through some of the de-identified data which shows they are indeed caring for people who are very seriously ill, such as people needing intravenous drips and people with burns that have not healed properly and which need high intensity dressing.

The funds are looking at helping the hospitals access these services by providing the hospitals with greater information, as we move to casemix, on what is available. In my home state there has been some reservation in the public sector to move into this because of the geographic nature of some of the trials in other states that have not worked. We need to be looking at a far greater area covered by these nursing services. The one in Adelaide covers the entire city. It has now worked successfully, as I said, for six years, with many nurses being employed.

Senator Herron mentioned competition. The funds want this for that reason alone, as well as wanting to work in the best interests of their patients. They get a negative reaction from people who are insured through them if those people learn later on that they could have been treated at home instead of being stuck in hospital. So they want this because they want to give the patients what they want and also for competitive reasons, because treatment at home is obviously a lot cheaper. With regard to this nursing service, if they only need to make one visit a day it is a matter of $60 or $70 at the most, depending on the level of nursing, compared to hundreds of dollars in a hospital bed. They have assured me for both those reasons that they will be working with the hospitals through the options available as they move to casemix payment.

Their reason for not wanting a separate payment to go to nurses directly from the funds is that you will end up still with your six days in hospital and nursing, rather than looking at what the actual episode of care needs to be and the doctor making the decision, `Okay, that person can go out after four days but then will need another four days in the home.' So it is a matter of basically going back to the medical practitioner to make the decision in line with the hospital. Then, whatever mix of service is considered desirable will be funded through the casemix payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember that we had a submission to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee in relation to that large nursing agency in South Australia. They were objecting to the legislation at the time. Has that been resolved? Are they now supportive?

—It is not totally resolved. They still have major concerns. I was present at the meeting between them and the funds to sort through some of this. As I said, they are now working actively with the funds on a number of issues. I believe it is one of the things we will have to monitor very carefully through the Community Affairs Committee. I think it will be a learning process on both sides—as it has been in the public sector as we move to casemix—deciding what is best done in the home and what is not practical in terms of the location of patients and their particular home circumstances. Of course, we will still have the provision from the funds to allow doctors to refer directly home. About 12 per cent of this nursing service's activity does not go via the hospital. It is intense care nursing that the doctor refers directly home. That provision is still in the tables.

—I accept the statements from Senator Lees. We did have that objection, particularly in Adelaide, because I think it is the only city that has one dominant group of nurses providing domiciliary care. But at present the major incentive for people to get out of private hospitals is the cost. I can assure you that there is no difficulty in discharging patients from a private hospital. They want to get out of the place as fast as they can. Provided they are not so ill that they need to be there for their own benefit, and they can be persuaded on occasion to stay in a hospital, it does become a medical judgment and it is of necessity a medical judgment. By and large, that occurs.

PARA.TAB: How do you cover the situation, for example, of a patient who goes without medical agreement? They can do that. They sign a discharge form from the hospital and zap off. I well remember—and he will not mind me telling you—a current government minister whose mother-in-law did that two days after a colectomy. She decided she was much better off at home and went home. It was against medical advice. How is that eventuality covered? It is not covered under amendment No. 46.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I do not believe it is covered under your amendment either. I would again go back to the casemix payment that the hospital gets. It is something the hospital is going to have to discuss with the doctor and the fund. If the hospital has the payment on the DRG basis for that episode—and maybe it is a five-day episode—surely it would be a very strange hospital that pocketed the money. That is in spite of the fact that the hospital did not want the patient to go home. I would expect that the hospital would put in train what the doctor sees as the second best option—but nevertheless an option—rather than leaving the patient out on a limb.

—I accept that that is a rare and uncommon occurrence. I am not introducing this just to throw up a theoretical example. However, there is no requirement in this legislation for outpatient coverage to occur. It certainly would be desirable that that whole episode was covered under casemix funding and that the care in that particular instance would be covered by arrangements made with the health insurance association entity. But item 46 is in relation to hospital treatment and it does not cover outpatient treatment. There will be overlap.

PARA.TAB: None of us can predict what will occur to us in relation to health matters. My amendment covers the outpatient situation specifically and not, of necessity, as part of the inpatient acute care. I suppose we have to know what goes on in the market. Not uncommonly it is the public hospitals that have the problem, particularly under the current government, with waiting lists increasing and people dropping out of private health insurance. I take it the minister is trying to keep people in private health insurance to take pressure off the Medicare system in relation to public hospitals.

It is the public hospitals that discharge people often prior to their medical requirements. It is not uncommon for the medical superintendent of a hospital to go around the hospital and say, `We need 10 beds. We have 20 admissions coming in. Turf people out'. That is very common. It is one of the major problems for public hospitals. It is a matter of trying to find beds for patients coming into hospital the next day because of operations that have been booked perhaps six months ahead—in fact, it is two years ahead in relation to knee replacements and three years ahead for tonsillectomies at Royal Brisbane Hospital.

What happens in relation to private patients in public hospitals? This is equally applicable to them. There is nothing in this legislation that covers outpatient care for private patients in public hospitals. In some states those patients are designated private while occupying a public hospital bed. There is overlap in all of this. We cannot say that we are hopeful that this will occur. The opportunity for outpatient care needs to be covered in the legislation. It is with that in mind that I have moved this amendment. We have previously mentioned psychiatric care, palliative care and rehabilitation services.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam war the dramatic and unexpected comments of the former US Secretary of State, Robert McNamara, have inevitably taken centre stage, inflaming once again the deep-seated arguments for and against Australia's involvement in that war. In doing so, those headlines have tended to set aside our first duty as a nation and as individuals at this time, whatever our view may be or may have been of that conflict.

PARA.TAB: The first obligation on the occasion of an anniversary of a war is to pay tribute—just tribute—to all the men and women who served in our defence forces in that war. The quality and dedication of their service are not to be measured by the success or failure of a particular conflict, or by the final judgment by history, or otherwise, of the cause. We do not fail to pay tribute to the Anzacs at Gallipoli or to the 2nd AIF in their involvement in Greece in World War II. Indeed, for those comparatively distant battles, the length of the telescope of historic judgment may not yet be long enough. In our democracy our servicemen and servicewomen obey the decisions of their elected governments. Our regular defence forces are there to respond to any call upon them, as they do today in many conflicts, controversial or otherwise, well planned or grossly mismanaged, which encircle the world—Cambodia, Rwanda, Bosnia, and Somalia, to name a few. Whether they are conscripts or volunteers, that same commitment has always been made. In New Guinea, as in Vietnam, Australians worked and fought together in no way differentiated in their commitment and in their valour by the method of their recruitment.

As I understand it, in the Vietnam conflict all those whose names came out in the so-called `birthday lottery' were given the choice of going to Vietnam or serving part-time in the then forces for five years—a form of conscience release. All Vietnam commanders have acknowledged the unity of purpose of both the regular soldiers and the conscripts. All have paid tribute, without distinction, to the fighting qualities of both. Indeed, there was abundant evidence that, working alongside the South Vietnamese people and learning from them of their cause, the great majority of our Australians on the ground believed in the justice of that cause.

Against that background, it is our duty and, indeed, it should be our pride as a parliament and a people to express to everyone who served in Vietnam our great indebtedness and our deep sadness at the sacrifice in suffering and death paid—and still being paid today—by them. They did their duty in both spirit and quality of commitment. No-one can ask for more. They stand today in full equal merit alongside those who fought in two world wars, in Korea and in Malaysia. Let no-one denigrate their efforts.

That the Vietnam war was a particularly ugly and dirty conflict by the nature of the jungle, the booby traps, the guerrilla type fighting and the difficulty—often inability—to distinguish friend from foe is true. And true it is that innocent civilians—men, women and children—were caught up in the slaughter; sometimes, however inadvertently, in our own fields of fire. But all wars are ugly and dirty no matter how hard we may try to sanitise them by international conventions on human behaviour. We must not detract from our tribute to our defence forces by wrongly condemning them for the unavoidable ugliness, accidents and tragedies of war.

As one who was not in Australia in those years and who was not caught up in the debates and the emotions of that time, may I make some comments on the broader issues—not in an attempt to be judgmental, but to raise matters for some future reflection? Firstly, many Australians and others were led to believe that the Vietnam conflict was simply a civil war within one nation of people, and therefore one which did not merit external influence or have any external consequences as to its outcome. But, as I read history, North and South Vietnam were never, in the past 2,000 years or so, essentially one country.

Indeed, the textbooks tell us that North Vietnam for a thousand years was a province of southern China, absorbing the culture and the religious characteristics of that country. As far as I am aware, the only times North Vietnam and South Vietnam were joined together were for short periods by the force of arms of the French and the Japanese. The history books are full of attempts by the north to invade the south in order to get to the richer river deltas. Vietnam, sometimes described as a necklace of pearls, has its richer treasures, like pearls, below. From recollection, the south in past centuries had built a wall across its centre to resist invaders.

The textbooks tell us also that the south had developed over the years a distinctive culture and religion of its own, influenced by Indians and by other travellers. I have read, for example, that the south had adopted Small Wheel Buddhism, as distinct from the north. Again, I read that after the rout of the French by the Viet Minh in 1954 and the international attempts to settle the conflict—the Geneva Accords—a dividing line was drawn. Subsequently, the media tells us that more than one million people fled from the north to the south—a modern day Rwanda. Today, in searching our consciences as we do in relation to Rwanda, we ask the same question: are we our brothers' keepers or are we simply an international grouping feeding and medicating those who are to die while we watch?

If it is so complex today and so far from clear cut, why have the revisionists painted the issue of Vietnam as so black-and-white? What parallel today is there to the request by Cambodia for the supply of Australian military trainees? How will history judge the role, the intentions and the horizons of Ho Chi Minh, the leader of the north? Was he simply and wholly a fervent patriot of his country or were his motives more influenced by the extensive and lengthy training and commitment to international communism in Peking?

Today, with the USSR, the Warsaw Pact and the Cold War no longer a serious world threat, and with Russia's military expenditure and exploitations limited by the economic collapse in that country, it is very difficult to realise the measure or the reality of the domino theory which, if honourable senators remember, predicated a steady downward march of international communism into the Pacific and through Vietnam to Indonesia.

Thirty years ago there was abundant evidence of Russia's desire to increase its military presence in the Pacific—a desire greatly frustrated by the fact that its eastern naval base, Vladivostok, locked into the Sea of Japan, was icebound for the major part of the year. In that context, how attractive was the warm water port of Haiphong in North Vietnam? Certainly the Russians were quick to use that port after the end of the war. Only history will judge the full extent of Russia's intentions.

What, too, of Chinese communism? What of the PKI and Indonesia? What would have been the consequences to us here if the PKI's attempted coup in 1965 had succeeded and all Indonesia had come under international communist control? What effects would communist rule in Irian Jaya have had on the stability of Papua New Guinea? What a slender thread determined the success or failure of that coup.

General Nasution, Suharto's fellow general in the 1965 uprising, when asked why the non-communists had stood against apparently overwhelming odds, is reported as saying that he and his colleagues assessed that the one chance they had of resisting international communism was while America was maintaining a shield against communism in Vietnam. A fortunate decision indeed for Papua New Guinea and for Australia.

The Australian government of the early 1960s had been warned of the danger of a successful PKI coup. Indeed, I believe it was a major influence in the decision to order the then state-of-the-art F111s—the only aircraft with the range and quality capable of long-range interdiction. Again, does the PKI coup support the domino theory? Only history will judge. Was Vietnam from the outset an unwinnable war or was it eminently winnable but lost by the restrictive and unimaginative decisions of its politicians and its generals? If the war had been won, would the slaughter of more than one million Cambodians by the Khmer Rouge have occurred? Again, history must judge.

But it was not competent for any Australian service man or woman to have such foresight or final judgement. Decisions are made on the events of the day. For our defence forces there was simply a commitment to be discharged. The massive effort and the sacrifice of the South Vietnamese troops in defence of their freedom must not be forgotten. Their sacrifices were immense and the wounds and divisions with the north have not be settled fully to this day. The boat people themselves are a message to history in themselves.

The neglect of the returning Australian servicemen from Vietnam and the utterly wrong association of them with the justice or otherwise of the war created a psychology of guilt which in many ways has caused more suffering and more casualties than the war itself. This anniversary gives us all, in a totally bipartisan way, the opportunity to draw the line on the argument for the moment and to make a unanimous judgement on the quality and dedication of every Australian who served in Vietnam. That judgment is very clear. They deserve, one and all, our praise and our gratitude for their commitment and our pride in the quality of their service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech I wish to give tonight is rather too long to give in 10 minutes and it may have to be given in episodes. I want to raise a number of issues in relation to the conduct of CSL over a number of years and the failure of its manufacturing process to guarantee safety of its products to the Australian community. Ultimately, a parliamentary inquiry of some sort is required to ascertain exactly what has been going on and the risks to which the Australian public has been exposed. Moreover, I believe that, when CSL was sold, a lot of information was kept from the public and possibly from ministers and also was certainly not disclosed to potential shareholders through the prospectus which CSL published.

PARA.TAB: So the question is: is the public interest adequately served by CSL Ltd as manufacturers of biological products such as blood products, growth hormones and vaccines and by the federal health department as the chief regulator of CSL? I believe the answer is no and that this question demands an open and very full inquiry. I believe the parliament has been misled on a number of occasions concerning the manufacture of these biological products and has been denied information it needs to keep a watch on this activity. It is also very likely indeed that government ministers have been kept deliberately in the dark, including during the debate over the sale of CSL.

In recognition of their value to individuals and to public health, products of biological origin are supplied to millions of Australians annually under Commonwealth community service obligations. They are quintessentially public interest services, because human blood plasma fractions are used by millions of Australians. Blood is indeed a very scarce national resource. For instance, there are only 144 million litres of human blood available from the whole human population of this country.

Blood is supplied to the Red Cross by unpaid donors. In a democracy, public trust in the delivery of and the regulatory systems for the surveillance of the quality of biological products must be extremely well founded. Biological products must be of the highest possible quality. They must be affordable and available when needed. But when mistakes are made—and, as I will indicate later on, considerable mistakes have been made—government and manufacturers must take full responsibility for these mistakes. Government and manufacturers must be open, accountable and subject to regulatory scrutiny and scrutiny by the parliament. The commercial-in-confidence provisions which apply to some information provided by pharmaceutical companies—that is, private pharmaceutical companies—cannot be applied in the same way to the products of biological origin supplied free to the government in the public interest.

Blood is not a standard material. Every sample from every donor is different. This has enormous ramifications when donations are pooled to make blood products. The use of blood and blood products, therefore, carries some risk. There is no completely foolproof laboratory test or screen for disease. There can be no absolute guarantee that virus-inactivating techniques will always work. There are diseases which cannot be detected in blood. The Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, for instance, is one such known disease.

It is axiomatic, therefore, that there must be other unknown and yet to be discovered diseases. The point at which the blood donor goes into the blood bank to give blood is an important point. Those who give blood should be carefully scrutinised as to their general health, the presence of any diseases and, as far as possible, the quality of the products which go in and are then pooled. Blood products should be protected at that point.

For these reasons it is fundamentally important that blood banking material at the point of donation must always be of the highest possible quality. The way to achieve this is to harvest blood from regular donors who are themselves tested and carefully questioned concerning their state of health. The lack of familiarity with these facts has made it difficult for the media and the public to sort out fact from fiction during recent discussions following disclosures last year about dangers associated with the use of human growth hormones, blood products, and the fate of CSL's anti-venom production which was cast off shortly following the sale of that company.

I turn to a brief sample of the events, practices, omissions, specific allegations and unanswered questions which have arisen recently and which raise extremely serious doubts that the public interest has been and is not being adequately served by CSL, CSL Ltd and the health department as its regulator for biological products.

CSL and the health department have resorted to secrecy and cover-up to avoid accountability for past practices and the limits of its virus inactivation techniques. The practice of CSL and the health department when faced with information which could bring public criticism upon them and incur liabilities for past product failures is too often to withhold important information from the public and those who have been exposed to risk. There are many examples of this secrecy and I wish to offer only a few in this brief delivery.

Within an hour of CSL and the health minister's office being informed of the imminent publication of last year's major independent report criticising CSL, the department and the minister for their part in failing to regulate blood products, a whispering campaign of lies about the author of that report had been seeded in Parliament House and in the financial sector. This had the effect of casting doubt on the integrity of her motives for publishing the findings of her five-year study. The source and motive for this whispering campaign of lies should be uncovered. The assertion—and I make this point very strongly—behind these rumours had no basis whatsoever in truth.

Professor Allars reports that the terms of reference for her inquiry did not allow her to examine CSL's product liability and the information in CSL's material therefore could not be properly assessed. Further, the Allars report, which triggers many unanswered questions about the role and liability of CSL over hormone products, was scheduled to be tabled in parliament on the day of the sale of CSL—the Red Alert document to which I referred a moment ago. Yet it is CSL as manufacturer which bears ultimate responsibility for the products and the harm which they cause. Does this suggest complicity on the part of government or, indeed, a cover-up?

Could the following facts, known to government and provable, along with others, in an inquiry setting, have influenced its decision to leave CSL out of the picture? For example, during the period of manufacture of human pituitary hormones, CSL did not subscribe to the code of good management practice, as with all of its products. CSL did not submit a manufacturing protocol or product standard to the health authorities for human pituitary gonadotrophin and human growth hormones. CSL did not carry out an assay of its follicle stimulating hormone or its luteinising hormone ratio. The failure to do this was blamed for the excessive number of multiple births, including nonuplets—that is, nine children being conceived.

CSL claimed to determine the follicle simulating hormone potency but did not have an authenticated standard substance for the assay and so did not carry out one valid assay. CSL distributed hormones that were subpotent in their specification. There was no proper selection or screening of glands; pituitary glands were received from overseas and unknown sources and pooled with glands from known sources. A microbiologist was not part of the team manufacturing the hormones, as required under the good manufacturing practice code. This led to a number of unsterile and pyrogenic batches, many of which were distributed. CSL distributed hormones that were known to be contaminated with the hepatitis B virus. I will continue my remarks at a later time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is no need for me to tell you about the importance of the Senate.
—Well, sit down then.

—The minister might wait as I think he might learn something. I have spoken on previous occasions about the importance of the Senate and its position as the only forum for true debate on and scrutiny of legislation. Some may allege that this can be taken a bit far. I could give no better example of what is occurring in relation to the health legislation at the moment. The government introduced 54 amendments and the opposition 42, when obviously that should have gone to one of the standing committees. Instead we are doing it through the Committee of the Whole House. That notwithstanding, the committee of the whole has a very legitimate place in the overall procedure of the Senate, as do the other committees, the Selection of Bills Committee, for example, and the select committees that I have referred to.

PARA.TAB: In addition to the importance of the Senate—and there is no question about the major role it plays in relation to the Australian constitution—equally, it is important that we consider the quality of the senators who are here. Specifically, I refer to the Liberal senators from Tasmania who are up for pre-selection at the next pre-selection procedure. The three that I refer to include Senator Jocelyn Newman, the shadow minister for defence. She is a member of the shadow cabinet and is the most senior woman in the history of the coalition occupying a position within the shadow cabinet. Secondly, I mention Senator Paul Calvert, who is deputy whip and chairman of the waste watch committee. He is the opposition's spokesman in the Senate for Commonwealth-state relations and privatisation. He is also an expert on local government and rural and regional affairs.

Thirdly, I mention Senator John Watson, Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. He is our expert on taxation and superannuation matters. In fact, he was part of the lock-up on the budget yesterday, from the opposition's point of view—a very unusual situation for a senator to be in. It is certainly an acknowledgment of his importance to the party and the weight that we place on him, as does the government on many occasions; it certainly listens to what Senator Watson has to say in relation to these matters. I am proud to say that these three senators are colleagues of inestimable value to the opposition. I look forward to the continuation of their representation of Tasmania.

Having said that, they are now being challenged by one Robin Gray. Mr President, I stand before you today as a victim of Robin Gray. Nearly 12 years ago I was president of the Liberal Party in Queensland. If you cast your mind back, Mr President, you will remember that this was before the Fitzgerald inquiry which revealed the corruption that existed in government. The then Premier, Bjelke-Petersen, refused to recognise the leader of the Liberal Party, who had been duly elected by the Liberal Party as its leader. Of course, that then broke the coalition agreement.

What happened? What happened is that the aforementioned Robin Gray dealt a major blow to the Liberal Party in Queensland. He campaigned for the National Party in Queensland. In the Hobart Mercury of 11 October 1983 there is a headline which says `Gray defiant on poll trip—rotten apple, says Qld. Liberal.' The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier, Mr Gray, was rebuked by the Tasmanian Liberal Party and accused of `treachery' by Queensland Liberals for deciding to campaign in the Queensland State election with Premier Bjelke-Petersen.
In the Courier-Mail, Terry White—an extraordinary man, our leader at the time—was quoted in a heading which read `Liberal Premier disloyal—White'. The article stated:
The [Queensland] Liberal Party leader, Mr White, accused the Tasmanian Liberal Party Premier, Mr Gray, of treachery and disloyalty.
On 12 October 1983, an article appeared in the Mercury entitled `Gray defiant on poll trip'. The article stated:
Mr Gray yesterday defiantly reaffirmed that he would go to Queensland next Sunday to campaign with the National Party . . .
An article in the Australian of that same date under the heading `Liberals weak link' stated:
It is difficult to imagine why Mr Gray should wish to make matters worse for his beleaguered fellow party members . . . by intervening against them in the current Queensland election.
Whatever its virtues, Mr Bjelke-Petersen's Government has shown itself unsympathetic to a great many fundamental Liberal policies.

Our policy was public accountability. That is what we were running on, as history has shown. That is the very thing that that government would not have. Terry White was running for public accountability; and we had Robin Gray up there campaigning against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are we fighting?

—Senator Collins, you can wonder why I am incensed at that. If the Queensland Liberal Party is `mortally wounded', as we were, there will be much less chance of a federal coalition government in the foreseeable future. An editorial in the Age of the same date under the headline `Put an end to Gray's folly' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: His decision to go to Queensland is mischievous . . . Mr Gray's eccentricity—what could be more eccentric than one State Liberal leader opposing another—poses a problem for the party's Federal leadership.
On 13 October, an editorial in the Adelaide Advertiser headed `Liberal Party in disarray' stated:

Mr Gray seems intent on worsening the disarray within the Liberal Party by his foolhardy decision to campaign for the National Party in Queensland. His action is presenting Queensland voters with the spectacle of one Liberal leader campaigning against another.
On 17 October, in an article entitled `6 days to go and Libs do it again', the Sydney Morning Herald stated:
Mr Gray went to Brisbane yesterday to support Mr Bjelke-Petersen and flew straight into a crippling new leadership crisis.
On 23 October 1983, an article headed `Bjelke gets Gray's vote in Qld poll' in the Australian read:
Mr Gray yesterday dealt the Queensland Liberal party a devastating slap in the face with a glowing endorsement of the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, for the State poll on October 22.
On 25 October 1983, in an article entitled `Top Libs sharply divided over party's Qld defeat' the Australian reported:
Swing to National Party of 11 percent, ALP 2.9 percent, and against Queensland Liberals of 12.3 percent.
And you wonder, Senator Collins, why I stand before you tonight!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still wondering; you have not told us how you became a victim. You have only two minutes.

—To answer your question, I became a victim of that because of the treachery of Robin Gray. We lost 12.3 per cent of the vote, as I mentioned. I was a volunteer working for the party, as I had done for 15 years prior to that. I would have expected loyalty from the premier of another state, a Liberal premier, but he did not give it. It was not only then that this occurred. In 1987 the Australian reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gray has raised questions about the leadership of the federal Liberal Party and announced his intention to meet the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen.
Clearly, he is not prepared to support Mr Howard's argument that Sir Joh is damaging the collective conservative push against Labor by his ill-defined crusade.
An article in the Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Another Premier moves on Howard' stated:
Mr Gray conspicuously distanced himself from Mr Howard yesterday as the pressure on the Opposition leadership continued to grow.

On 9 February 1987, on ABC radio's The World Today a headline was `Robin Gray supports Sir Joh's statement criticising the Federal Opposition leadership'. On 13 February 1987, an article in the Australian entitled `Sinclair blames Sir Joh for Coalition slump' said:
(Mr Gray) said that he thinks Mr Howard would do a good job too but he naturally has got to play it 50-50—

This is the man who is considering himself for preselection for the Liberal Party in Tasmania. On 20 February 1987 Gray commented on the coalition. An article in the Australian entitled `Gray calls for end to Coalition' stated:
Mr Gray yesterday called for an end to the Federal Coalition, adding significantly to the crisis in conservative parties.
I could go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll tell you what; if he gets here, it will be interesting to see where he sits.

—I do not believe that he will get here, because I value the judgment of the preselectors of Tasmania. I have illustrated to you—and I will be writing to the preselectors of Tasmania about this—the absolute treachery that he showed a fellow Liberal, without consulting us and without even seeking our advice. He went against the Liberal Party in Tasmania as well. He is not a team player. As I mentioned before, if there is one thing that the Senate needs, it is team players. I think it would be a travesty of preselection processes if such a man—and you can only judge people on their past—were to be preselected.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins, as you know, I am not a person to resile from something. I will take it front on, and that is why I am doing this tonight—on my own behalf, not on anybody else's behalf. As luck would have it, it has taken nearly 12 years for me to be given the opportunity to reply to that man, and I do so tonight. (Time expired)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Convention on the Rights of the Child

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 900 (Senate Hansard, 28 November 1994, p.3372) (a) on what date, and in what form, did the Commonwealth, after the Convention on the Rights of the Child was drafted, consult with each State and Territory Government (i) on the question of Australia's signature of the Convention, and (ii) for confirmation that their laws already enabled Australia to meet all obligations imposed by the Convention; (b) on what date, and in what form, did each State and Territory Government respond; and (c) what was the content of these communications.

(2) (a) On what dates were the Victorian Crimes Amendment Bill 1993 and the Sentencing Amendment Bill 1993 passed by the Victorian Parliament, and on what dates did they enter into force; (b) what were the dates and content of the correspondence concerning the bills between the Commonwealth and Victorian Attorneys'-General; and (c) what action has the Attorney-General taken, and what further action does the Attorney-General intend to take to ensure that these Acts do not infringe Australia's international human rights obligations, in particular those under the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

(3) (a) Has the South Australian Parliament enacted legislation in similar terms to the Victorian Acts; (b) what were the dates and content of the correspondence concerning the Acts between the Commonwealth and the South Australian Attorneys'-General; and (c) what action has the Commonwealth Attorney-General taken, and what further action does the Attorney-General intend to take, to ensure that any such legislation does not infringe Australia's international human rights obligations, in particular those under the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
(4) (a) How many State parties are there to the Convention; (b) which States have lodged instruments of ratification or accession since question on notice no. 900 was placed on notice.
(5) In what circumstances, and with what results, has Australia considered withdrawing its reservation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)&(b) The Commonwealth consulted the State and Territory Governments throughout the 10 years it took to draft the Convention on the Rights of the Child. After the final draft of the Convention was completed, consultation continued with regard to both signature and ratification of the Convention. On the 23 June 1989, the Commonwealth asked the States to assess their laws in light of the Convention. Follow up requests were made in this regard on the 8th August 1989. Replies were received from Tasmania on 31st July and 22nd August, Queensland on 25th August, South Australia on 22nd August and 23rd October, Northern Territory on 21 August and Western Australia on 25th August 1989.

The Prime Minister wrote to each Premier and Chief Minister on 29 January 1990 informing them of the intention to sign the Convention after proper consultation and negotiation. Replies were received from Queensland on 1st March, Northern Territory on l5th and 27th February, Western Australia on 22nd February and 12 June, Tasmania on the 15th March, South Australia on 7th February 1990 and ACT on 23rd May 1990 and Victoria (although it was undated). A note was also sent to Victoria and NSW on the 17th May 1990, requesting that they reply to previous correspondence. Victoria replied on the 8 August 1990.

Another letter was sent by the Attorney-General on the 26th June 1990, about delays in signing the Convention. Replies were received from Queensland on 30th July, Tasmania on 10th July, ACT 24th July and Victoria on 13 August. On the 4th September 1990, the Attorney-General wrote to all the state Attorney-Generals informing them that he would seek ratification as State laws were consistent with the Convention. Replies were received from Queensland on 27th September, ACT on 17th September, South Australia on 27th September, Western Australia on 13th and 28th September, Northern Territory on 11 December and NSW on 14th December 1990. During this time the Standing Committee of Attorneys'-General also discussed the issue several times.

(c) The responses from all States (other than that eventually provided by NSW) were supportive of ratification. Most States raised some concerns about the interpretation of the Convention, particularly in relation to the separate imprisonment of juveniles (the subject of Australia's reservation) and also its implications for abortion and juvenile employment laws. Several States expressed concern about the potential increase in scope of Commonwealth legislative power to override State laws in reliance on the Convention.

(2)(a) The Victorian Crimes (Amendment) Bill 1993 was passed by the Victorian parliament on 14 December 1993. The Sentencing (Amendment) Bill 1993 was passed by the Victorian Parliament on l June 1993. The Sentencing (Amendment) Act 1993 ss.1 and 2 commenced on the 1st June 1993; s.2(1). On the 15th August 1993, the rest of the Sentencing (Amendment) Act (except ss.13, 15) commenced. On the 1st November 1993, ss.13, 15 of the Sentencing (Amendment) Act commenced. The Crimes (Amendment) Act, Pt 1(ss.1-3) came into effect on 14th December 1993; s.2(1). On the 21st December 1993, ss.10 commenced. 0n the Ist June 1994, ss.4-9, and 11 of the Crimes (Amendment) Act commenced.

(b) The Attorney-General first wrote to Ms Wade, the Victorian Attorney-General, on the 7th May 1993. He sought assurances that the Sentencing (Amendment) Bill, 1993 and the Crimes (Amendment) Bill, 1993 were not in breach of our international obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention on the Rights of the Child. On the 10th May 1993, Ms Wade replied and stated that the amendments were not in breach of international obligations, given the safeguards in the legislation. On 17th November 1993, the acting Attorney-General Mr Duncan Kerr wrote to Ms Wade and express concern about its continued potential to infringe Australia's international human rights obligations. On the 29th November 1993, Ms Wade replied and stated her Government's intention not to amend the legislation.
(c) The Government has already expressed its concern to the Victorian Government over the Crimes Act (Amendment) Act and Sentencing (Amendment) Act.
(3) No, not so far as I am aware.
(4)(a) As of the 7th December 1994, there were 168 countries which had ratified or acceded to the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

(b) Since 20 December 1993, fourteen countries have ratified or acceded to the Convention. They are: Afghanistan, Eritrea, Gabon, Georgia, Iran, Iraq, Japan, Kazakhstan, Krygyzstan, Luxembourg, Mozambique, Nauru, Samoa and Uzbekistan

(5) Australia has a reservation to Article 37(c) of the Convention on the Rights of the Child in relation to the separation of adults and children during imprisonment. Although Australia agrees with the general principle of Article 37(c) no consideration has been given to withdrawing this reservation. Australia's demographic and geographic features make it difficult to achieve the total segregation of children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. Furthermore the Australian Government remains convinced that it is appropriate to allow the responsible authorities discretion to determine whether it is beneficial for a child or juvenile to be imprisoned with adults.

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Subsection 5(1) of the Social Security Act 1991 defines a young person as a person who has not turned 16; or a person who has turned 16 but not 25 and who is receiving full-time education at a school, college or university.

A person who is 16 or 17 years of age and who is not receiving full-time education at a school, college or university can still be treated as a dependant even though they are not regarded as being a "young person" for the purposes of the Act. Section 1068-B1A of the Social Security Act provides that, where a single person is receiving a social security benefit and they have a child who is 16 or 17 and that child is receiving a social security benefit or Youth Training Allowance in their own right but is still substantially dependent on the single person, that child can be regarded as a dependant of that person.

(3) The practical effect of the provisions is that in some circumstances a single person with a dependent child aged 16 or 17, can receive a higher rate of payment. The difference, an additional $24.30 per fortnight above the single rate of payment, reflects the fact that the social security beneficiary still has a dependant for whom they are responsible.

(4) The only persons who benefit from this provision are sole parents who are receiving a social security benefit. The person must have a child aged 16 or 17 who is substantially dependent and the child must also be receiving a social security benefit or Youth Training Allowance in their own right.

(5) The information requested by the honourable Senator is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of the considerable resources that would be involved in obtaining this information.
(6) (a) Yes.

(b) Where the person is receiving sole parent pension, the Department will draw to the person's attention the effect on that payment of the young person turning 16 years of age before that event occurs. Their payment options are explained at that time. This advice is also provided by JET officers to sole parent pensioners who are participants in the JET program and whose children are turning 16. A question (Question 6) is also asked in the Job Search Allowance claim form about whether the claimant has a dependent 16 or 17 year old receiving Job Search or Youth Training Allowance. A "yes" response to this question alerts staff that action may need to be taken in this area.
(7) (a) Yes
(b) See answer to part 6(b).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) determined the exact amount by which it will raise the licence fees of amateur radio operators.
(2) On what grounds is SMA increasing fees.
(3) Will any concessions in licence fees be granted to elderly operators or to the unemployed.
(4) Can a guarantee be given that there will be a freeze on licence fees for any period of time after they are increased.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice provided by the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA):

PARA.TAB: (1) On 30 March 1995, the Spectrum Manager determined an annual fee of $51 for an amateur apparatus licence, which came into force on 3 April 1995.

(2) On 8 December 1993 the then Minister for Communications, the Honourable David Beddall, MP directed the SMA to hold a public inquiry into the apparatus licence system and to advise him of the outcomes of the review by 31 May 1994. This resulted from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure (HORSCOTCI) Report on Management of the Radiofrequency Spectrum in October 1991.

HORSCOTCI concluded that the existing approach to levying charges for access to spectrum had little if any effect in managing demand, did not promote efficient use of the spectrum and was not transparent to users. HORSCOTCI concluded that any changed structure should:
(a) ensure that actual costs incurred by the Spectrum Manager on behalf of individual users are identified and recovered from the individual users;
(b) enable costs not attributable to any specific user to be recovered using a flat charge, or based on some measure of amount or value of spectrum used; and
(c) clearly identify the taxation component.

The SMA inquiry included an extensive process of public consultation. The inquiry concluded that the apparatus licence fee framework should be equitable, efficient and transparent, with licence fees reflecting the demand for and the amount and location of spectrum used as well as the level of SMA costs.
Under the new apparatus licence fees structure, some fees have increased while others have decreased, with overall licence revenue from licensed equipment remaining roughly the same in real terms.
With the introduction of the new licence fees structure, each licence fee will generally consist of three identifiable components relating to:
the cost of issuing or renewing the licence;

the spectrum maintenance cost, which covers the ongoing cost of managing the spectrum, including protection from interference. For amateur radio operators, the cost also includes the SMA organising the international operator's accreditation;

a spectrum access cost that provides a return to the government for the use of a community resource. This cost reflects the amount and type of spectrum accessed and the area of communications coverage. Licensees with a large share of the spectrum in high demand areas will tend to pay more than those with a small share in low demand areas.

The SMA has decided to set a flat fee of $51 for all non-assigned amateur licences. This fee is based on the administration and maintenance services provided to amateurs by the SMA and the minimum tax component in recognition of the unique services they provide the community.

(3) SMA licence tax determinations do not provide for concessions, other than concessions to certain emergency organisations and persons assisting them in the provision of safety of human life services.
(4) The SMA has advised that it intends to review licence fees on a regular basis in line with the normal course of budgetary processes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why does the recently released Ministerial Policy Paper and Annual Report to Parliament on Australia's development cooperation program, entitled New Directions in Australia's Overseas Aid Program, make no mention of the contribution of Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research activities to the overseas development program.
(2) Does the absence of any mention of agriculture or agricultural research from this report signify that these aspects of development are not priority areas in Australia's aid program.
(3) What financial commitment is the Government intending to make to the area of agriculture in the forthcoming aid budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Ministerial Statement to which the Senator refers is the fifth in a series of annual reports to Parliament on Australia's development cooperation program. The purpose of these reports is to inform Parliament of significant developments in the aid program and to provide an analytical discussion of current aid and development policy issues. The statement is not intended to provide a detailed list of each and every aid activity. AusAID's reporting to Parliament on all aid activities, including those of ACIAR, is done through a number of other documents the DFAT Portfolio annual report; the budget related paper on the development cooperation program; and, in 1995, the program budget statements which now report at all sub-program levels, including ACIAR. I should also point out that ACIAR is, for the purposes of government administration, a statutory authority and as such provides its own annual report to Parliament.

The most recent policy paper addressed two areas carrying important implications for Australia's development assistance. These are, firstly, the range of social development issues such as population, health and education which have, over the last year, been the subject of concerted international attention at the Cairo Conference on Population and Development in September 1994 and the World Summit for Social Development which took place at Head of Government level in Copenhagen in March 1995. Secondly, the statement focused on new directions in humanitarian relief which built on the findings of a review undertaken early in 1994 in response to the complex humanitarian emergencies in Africa and Europe. That review has led to a new initiative to help address humanitarian needs, the details of which will be announced in the forthcoming budget.

The previous Ministerial policy statement, which took as its theme the reduction of poverty, noted the important role of ACIAR and the contribution of international agricultural research to raising production above subsistence, stimulating employment, slowing rural-urban migration, raising incomes and expanding national wealth.

(2) No. Agriculture is clearly one of those sectors where Australia has internationally competitive goods and services to offer and where our expertise in research is widely recognised. The fact that ACIAR has received real increases in funding in each of the past four budgets and, indeed, has received an increased share of the total aid program, testifies to the importance the Government attaches to agricultural research and the regard in which it holds ACIAR.
(3) Information on financial allocations within the aid budget for 1995-96 will be available in the Budget Related Paper on Australia's Development Cooperation Program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to comments made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the ABC Radio `AM' program on 26 January 1995 concerning people from the United Kingdom (UK) now living in Australia and stating that the Australian social security system is being drained by former UK residents who are now in receipt of Australian aged pensions:
(1) Why was this matter raised in discussions with the UK Government.
(2) What is the agreement that determines the payment of aged pensions when Australian and UK nationals move between the two countries.
(3) How any former UK residents are receiving Australian benefits.
(4) Does the UK make any financial contribution to these pensions.
(5) Do former residents of Australian living in the UK have reciprocal pension rights.
(6) How does the Australian Government want to change the present arrangements.
(7) Does the Minister realise that he has insulted many UK migrants who resent being told by him that they are a drain on this nation.
(8) What is the cost of the present system to the taxpayer in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government has been concerned for a number of years about the UK Government's policy of not awarding cost-of-living increases to its pensioners in Australia. Many Australian residents formerly lived and worked in the UK and paid contributions to the UK National Insurance Fund. These people can qualify for a British retirement pension and, subject to income and assets tests, also to an Australian age pension. As the real value of British retirement pensions declines over time, British pensioners have had to rely more and more on the Australian age pension to support them during their years of retirement.

It costs the Australian taxpayer about $80m a year in making higher Australian pension payments to British pensioners than would be necessary if the level of UK pensions was maintained through cost-of-living increases.

The UK Government's policy is discriminatory in that it awards cost-of-living increases to its pensioners in some countries such as those in the European Union, USA, Turkey, Barbados and the Philippines, but expects its former dominion countries such as Australia, Canada, New Zealand and South Africa to assist UK pensioners in those countries with income support payments. The average UK pension paid in Australia is about $30 a week below the fully indexed level it should be.

(2) There is a social security agreement between Australia and the UK which dates back to 1958. The Agreement gives people, who move permanently between Australia and the United Kingdom, accelerated access to the social security system of the country to which they have moved.
(3) At 30 June 1994, the following pensions were paid to UK born residents:
Age pension—182,022
Disability support pension—29,781
Wife pension—10,956

(4) The UK makes no financial contribution towards the cost of the above pensions. The UK pays pensions to about 159,000 people in Australia at a cost of approximately $364m a year. The UK Government estimates that it would pay an additional $231m a year to British pensioners in Australia if it awarded cost-of-living increases to its pensioners here.

(5) Australia pays pensions to about 3,800 pensioners in the UK at a cost of $23.5m a year. The smaller number of pensioners who have returned to the UK reflects the migration pattern between the two countries.

(6) The Australian Government wants to negotiate a social security agreement with the UK under which the two countries would share the responsibility for a person's social security coverage during their retirement years, according to the length of the person's connection to each country's social security scheme. Under such an agreement, rates of pension would be regularly adjusted in line with cost-of-living increases. To date, the UK Government has refused to enter into negotiations on such an agreement with Australia.

(7) The reference to the financial drain on the Australian social security system referred to the decisions of the UK Government. The Government appreciates that it is not the fault of UK migrants that their former Government has left them without adequate retirement income by freezing the rate of their pensions. The Minister for Foreign Affairs was simply reporting on a UK Government policy which is of major concern and is causing considerable financial outlay to the Australian Government.

(8) It costs the Australian taxpayer about $80m a year in making higher Australian pension payments to British pensioners than would be necessary if the level of UK pensions was maintained through cost-of-living increases.
Failure to award cost-of-living increases has produced real savings to the UK Government which undoubtedly have been used to offset spending elsewhere.
